Principal arrested in spanking incident 

ASSOCIATED PRESS 
MATHIS — A South Texas elementary school principal has been arrested on charges of simple assault for spanking a 
1o-year-old boy who a teacher said had been fighting with an­ other boy. 

Bill Fricks, a schoolteacher and 
Snafu shaping up over funds 

WASHINGTON POST SERVICE 
WASHINGTON 
- 
Thousands of counties, cities and towns across the country m ay m iss out on their share of 
SI.7 billion in federal revenue-sharing monies next m onth because they have failed to return form s assu rin g the governm ent they will com ply with the revenue-sharing law in disbursing the funds. 
Because of a law passed last year, the governm ent requires a new form from these local governm ents before they can receive federal revenues. 
Of the 39.(MM) or so state and local g o v e r n m e n ts e l ig ib le for re v e n u e - sharing grants, only 25,(MMI filed the required form s by this w eek’s d ead ­ line, a c co rd in g to rev e n u e -s h a rin g officials. 
Without form s signed by the chief executives of these states* cities and counties, the T reasury cannot send them revenue sharing checks on April 
7. The form s were m ailed Feb. IO. 

A spokesm an for the Office of Re­ venue Sharing said that, while March 
IO was the official deadline for receipt of the form s that assure the localities will comply with the revenue-sharing law. the governm ent probably will accept form s until som e tim e next week. 

Some will miss out 

Undoubtedly, however, thousands of localities will m iss out on th e A pril paym ent because they tailed to sign the new form — which was required by 
Congress last year when it extended the revenue-sharing law until Sept. 3o. 
I OHO. 

Officials have not decided w hether to set up an o th er payout d ate for loca­ lities that realize they failed to send in their forms.

Terrorists’ indictm ents are sought 

By DAVID MCLEMORE 
The American Federation of 
Government Employes won t organize military personnel if the union’s local membership has anything to say about it. 

A FOP' L ocal No. IHI7 P r e s i d e n t 
Andy Sanchez said Friday local m e m ­ bership was a waiting official notifica­ tion from the national office on a vote to look into the feasibility of unionizing m ilitary personnel. 

“Our local voted against it last year and i f s q u ite likely they will vote against it ag ain ,” Sanchez said 

AFGE opened its ranks to m ilitary personnel last D ecem b er d u rin g the union’s national convention. 

But th e n a tio n a l e x e c u tiv e c o m ­ m it te e v oted in W a s h in g to n . D C. 
Wednesday to put the issue to the vote of all the union’s locals, Sanchez said. 

“ W e’ve received no official notifica­ tion for the vote from the national of­ fice vet.” Sanchez said. “ As soon as we do. Local No. IHI7 will vote on it." 

S an c h e z s a id local 
A F G E m em bership opposed the idea of un­ 

 ionized m ilitary because of the conflict b etw e e n m i l i t a r y an d c iv ilia n jo b holders. 
Competition 
“ Our local m em bership and all civilian federal em pllyes are in com petition with m ilita ry personnel for jobs," Sanchez said. “ T here would be just too m uch conflict in a union­ ization drive for both m ilitary and ci­ vilian m e m b ers.” 
The specter of soldiers and airm en on the picket line has raised much ne­ 

 g a tiv e r e a c tio n fro m g o v e r n m e n t] leaders and m ilitary organizations. 
J a m e s O. Duncan, president of the 
San Antonio based Non Com missioned I 
Officers Assn., said, "U nionization of! m ilita ry p erso n n el would c a u s e t h e 1 u ltim ate d e stru c tio n of our n a tio n ’s arm ed forces. 
“ If the roots of m ilitary unionism take hold of the defense posture of our nation, they will sink to a level where no am ount of hindsight will ever pull us out. 
“ It m ust not be allowed to happen.”

 of the District of Columbia city hall, one of the three sites occupied by the gunmen. 
However, four of the terrorists were set free without bail and the other eight wen* jailed F riday after they were charged with arm e d kidnaping. 
First to in.* set free was Hanafi leader 
K halifa H am a a s Abdul K h aalis, 55, who had threatener! repeatedly to chop off the heads of his hostages. 
Promised 
Prosecutors prom ised him freedom pending trial in return for release of the hostages. N egotiations w ere h a n ­ dled by th re e Isla m ic a m b a s s a d o r s who quoted to Abdul Khaalis from the 
Koran, the Moslem holy book. 
Also set free were three Hanafis who had seized the Islam ic Center m osque without firing a shot and without in­ juring any hostages. 
Superior Court Judge ll. Carl Moul­ trie said the D istrict of C o lu m b ia ’s liberal bail law left him no choice hut to release them because their charges might be lighter than the rest. 
The law requires release w ithout hail if defendants have com m unity tics arid arc not a threat or liable to flee the court’s reach. “ The judges don’t m ake the law s,” M oultrie said. “ We only carry them out." 
Bail was set at $5o,(MI each for two who took over the D istrict B uilding, where Williams was killed and three others were wounded. 
Of those who helped Abdul Khaalis seize the h ead ­ quarters of the Jewish service o rg a n ­ ization B ’nai B rith , w h ere s e v e r a l persons were wounded, four had bail set at $5o,(KM) ami two at $75,(UM). The higher bail was set because the latter two had previous convictions. 
P rosecutors said ail 12 d e fe n d a n ts could draw jail term s of 15o years or life ll in d ic te d au d c o n v ic te d on m urder charges.

March and St. P atric k ’s Day Saturday. 
M arching bands from L anier and

The prim ary goal of the parade is lo pay tribute to the men and women of 
Mexican lineage who have fought and died defending the United States. 
A total pf 4o entries have been con­ firmed anil the Comite Paseo de Marzo has issued special invitations for all candidates for April elections to p arti­ cipate.

Street and travel up Houston Street, ending with a special cerem ony at the 
Alamo.

Gas prices expected to rise slowly 

By JIM WIK)!) 
L o-V aea ( l a t h e r i n g C o., w h ic h supplies natural gas to City Public 
Service, expects prices to rise slow Iv | during the next year. 
In its an n u al fo recast of p rice s, j 
Lo-V aea e s t i m a t e s cost of g a s to j custom ers, such as CPS, will increase from $2 o3 p er 1,ooo cubic feet this 
‘March to $2 14 by next February. 
Under a tem porary rate approved by the T exas R a ilro ad C om m ission in 
1973, Lo-Vaca is allowed to pass on to custom ers the average cost it pays for! gas plus five cents per UMM) cubic feet. 
•The com pany keeps the nickel for in own operating costs, 
C ost curve 
W hile p ric e s a r e e x p e cted to c o n ­ tinue their upw ard spiral because of m arket conditions, Don Ncwquist, Hic c o m p a n y ’s vice presid en t for public affairs, said the cost curve is b eg in ­ ning to flatten, 
The prices are subject to change be* cause of such conditions us r e d e te r ­ mination clauses which allow the pro­ ducers that sell to lo-Vuca to periodi­ cally a d ju st th e ir p rice s, a lm o st a l­ ways upward

ARTHUR FIEDLER 

Silver lining 

It was a bad day for 
Christella McCloskey. 
She had a row with w orkm en fixing her roof, she was getting a divorce, her baby son had a rash and she was fired for not smiling. 
Mrs. McCloskey took the matter to an indus­ trial tribunal. 
Helen Bond, the boss at Warley Green kin­ dergarten in Birmingh­ am, England, said of her smile rule: "I have to do it and all the other girls have to do it. I will not tolerate miserable people." 
Members of the tri­ bunal decided M rs. 
McCloskey hadn’t much to smile about on the day in question and found her wrongly dis­ missed. 
They aw ard ed her 
$58o com p en satio n . 
Mrs. 
M cCloskey smiled.

Movies, pills filled Hughes’ shaggy years 

WASHINGTON — From secret daily logs kept by attendants, we have been presenting the strange saga of 
Howard Robard Hughes. 

Carter asked stop swine flu program 

DOW NTOW N 9 3o TO 5:3o M O N THRU SAT 
PARKING BEHIND DO W N TO W N STORE 
SUBURBAN 9:3o TO 6:oo MON. THRU SAT. 
A ll MAJOR CREDIT CARDS HONORED 

COMWtFD PHOM WI RE S FI VICES 
WASHINGTON - A special panel advised the 
C arter A dm inistration 
Friday to shelve the na­ tional swine flu vaccina­ tion p ro g ra m but to c on sider su p p o rtin g some lesser im m uniza­ tion efforts. 
However, the panel — convened to m ake r e ­ commendations for the future of federal influen­ za im m u nization p ro ­ gram s — was not able to. 

NATIONAL 
DIGEST 

 reach a consensus the nation’s specific needs for a vaccine for the flu season that begins this fall. 
Dr. 
David 
R ogers, 
P rin c e to n , N .J ., who. chaired the meeting of 
^MARKDOWN 

 doctors, scien tists, b u­ sinessmen and public in­ te re st advocates, said there was general agree­ ment that chances of a swine flu epidemic next season are very low. 

Senate okays disaster bill 

WASHINGTON - The 
Senate has passed and sent to the White House a bill appropriating an ad­ ditional $2oo million for disaster relief. 
The money is to be used in drought-stricken areas of the West and 
Great Plains and in Eas­ tern states plagued by severe winter snows. 

Food stamp change asked 

WASHINGTON 
A g ric u ltu re S e c re ta ry 
Bob Bergland is asking 
White House permission to propose two m ajor ch an g es in the food stamp program. 
No cost changes would be involved. One propo­ sal would increase the n u m b e r of poor and near-poor families in the p ro g ra m . The second would reduce benefits to fam ilies at h ig h e r in ­ come levels. 

Committee gets death evidence 

WASHINGTON 
- 
Memphis officials have turned their evidence in the Martin Luther King 
Jr. murder over to the 
House A ssa ssin a tio n s 
Committee 
The evidence included the rifle and bullet that are the key to whether 
J a m e s E a rl Ray was 
King's assassin in Mem­ phis in 1988 

The late billionaire spent his last years in a series of darkened pent­ houses, often groggy from drugs, watching a constant round of movies. 
He went months, sometimes years, without trim m ing his hair, beard or nails. 
His g re a te s t p erso nal stru g g le apparently took place in the bathroom, where he spent an abnormal amount of time perform ing his ablutions. His bowel movements are triumphantly recorded in the logs. 
The daily records also contain re ­ p eated, m y ste rio u s re fe re n c e s to 
“ 2o-1-1-1,” "th e item ," "B B s” and 
"4s.” These appear to be code names for the drugs that his doctors reluc­ tantly provided. 
Hughes started off New YeaVs Day, 
1972, for example, with a dosage. A notation in the logs reports that "he took 6 of the 25 4s" shortly after he awakened at ll a m. 
Awake 25 hours 
He remained awake, typically, for 25 hours. He spent the time nibbling on chicken and watching "G unfight in 
Abilene," “ Midnight Lace," "Daring 
G am e," “ Once Upon a Time in the 
West" and “ Topaz.” 
He also watched one reel of “ Break­ fast at Tiffany’s." Then this notation appears: “ After one reel, HRH said we could return." 
Apparently, he also disliked “ Once 
Upon a Tim e in the W est.” for this stern notation appears after 
- he watched it: “ HRH says not to get any more Italian wes­ terns.” 
But “ Topaz” pleased him; the log states: "H e said he likes this one.” 
We got wind of H u g h e s’ condition in 197o and published an eye-witness report. The story caused shock waves throughout his $2 billion empire. 
His aides responded with a frantic flurry of denials. Finally in 1972, he came out of seclusion twice within six months to visit briefly with outsiders. 
They contradicted our description of the billionaire as a wildly shaggy ap­ parition. 
Speculation 
We speculated that they may have been greeted by a double; we even es­ tablished that Hughes had used dou­ bles in the past to deceive process servers. 
But the logs reveal that the visitors m et the real Hughes; the logs also show that it took four hours to groom him for the confrontations. It was his first barbering in years. 
His trim, new Van Dyke beard was just beginning to get ragged again when an earthquake shook him out of his penthouse at M anagua’s Intercon­ tinental Hotel. 
The log has him lounging in his re­ clining chair at 12:25 a m., Dec. 23, 
1972. 
T here is no record of the quake, which caused the hotel to heave vio­ lently, except for this terse notat’on: 
“There was no log kept from the time of the earthquake in Managua, Nicar­ agua, until the arrival in Miami." 
Return to U.S. 
The next entry clocks his arrival at 
Fort Lauderdale at 11:45 p.m. on De­ cember 23. 
He remained holed up in his Lear jet for four hours, however, while his aides wrangled with Internal Revenue and Customs agents. 
They had anticipated his arrival and 
.sought to serve him with a subpoena. 
But incredibly, the tax agents were called off by Washington after a few midnight phone calls to high places. 
Only Customs agent Harold Sawyer was adm itted on board the private plane. He found the billionaire behind a blanket, which had been draped across the seats and aisle. 
Saw yer shined his flash lig h t on 
Hughes, who had a “ black hat pulled 

■ Jack 
Anderson 

 down over his head to his ears. His face was extremely thin, and he had a full beard which appeared to be gray and flecked with brown.” The man identi­ fied himself "with a mumbled assent" as Howard Hughes. 
Goes to London 

According to the logs, he spent a two-day C h ristm a s holiday in his 
"M iami house” and then took off on 
December 26 for London. He settled into the penthouse at the Inn on the 
P ark and im m ediately called for a screening of “ The Deserter.” 
The old routines were resum ed — bed, chair, movies, bathroom , with prolonged picking over food, regular dosages of BBs and 4s and triumphant 
BMs and Big Es. (The latter a p p a r­ ently refers to enemas.) 
Hughes agreed, meanwhile, to see 

For the next two years, he watched movies and let his hair grow, a voluntary prisoner o f Xanadu, until he became too feeble to move 

Nevada’s Gov. Mike (^Callaghan and gaming chairman Phil Hannafin to re­ solve a stalemate over his gambling properties. 
The meeting was scheduled the night of March 17, 1973. 
At 11:35 p.m., Hughes’ barber, Mel 
Stewart, trimmed his beard down to a neat Van Dyke and tapered his un ­ kempt hair. It was 1:15 in the morning before Hughes was ready to greet his 
Nevada visitors. 
After the meeting, he shuffled into the bathroom at 3:o5 a.m. 
Wanted to fly 

Three months later, he made his last bid to return to reality. He announced to his startled aides that, despite his fragile h ealth , poor ey esig h t and elapsed pilot’s license, he would like to fly again. He d id n ’t even own any street clothes. 
His aides purchased clothes to h i s . specifications and arranged for him to fly an HS748 private jet. 
On Ju n e 9, 1973, he w atched a screen in g of 
" S tr a te g ic 
Air 
C o m m an d .’’ T hus m e n ta lly c o n d i­ tioned, he had a long, 1o-hour sleep. 
The next m orn ing , Mell S tew art came in at 8:1o and spent until noon grooming, dressing and readying the billionaire for the great event. 
He slipped out of the hotel sh o rty after 2 p.m. for a day of flying with an 
F^nglish jet pilot nam ed 
Tony 
Blackburn. 
Broke hip 

Not long afterward. Hughes broke his hip in a bathroom fall and retreat­ ed forever into his gloomy penthouse. 
He re tu rn e d , i t ’s tru e , to the 
Bahamas and moved into the Xanadu 
Princess Hotel, which he purchased. 
F'or the next two years, he watched movies and let his hair grow, a volun­ tary prisoner of Xanadu, until he be­ came too feeble to move. 
Then on Feb. 1976, his entourage u naccou ntab ly flew the he lp le ss 
Hughes to Acapulco, where he deter­ iorated steadily. 
He died, according to his doctors, on an em ergency flight to Houston on 
April 5, 1976.

WASHINGTON (AP) - The Carter administration on Friday supported the power of federal judges to order changes in school programs if that is necessary to correct the lingering psy­ chological and educational effects of past segregation. 
In a brief filed with the Suprem e 
Court in a Detroit school integration case, the Ju stice D epartm ent said judges have the authority not only to end segregation, but also to use a var­ iety of tools to remedy the effect of the discrim ination on the a ttitu d e s of teachers and children and the learning abilities of black children. 
Courts 
But the department said the courts, 
"w herever possible," should avoid getting involved in the day-to-day operation of the school system. And the courts should not attempt to correct segregation caused by housing p a t­ terns or other "private conduct,” the department suggested. 
The 35-page brief offered the first official clue to the positions the a d ­ ministration will take in several school desegregation cases pending in the courts and on the issue of racial inte­ gration in general. 
But it was hardly more than a clue because the Detroit case involves none of the most controversial issues of integration, such as the busing of chil­ 

 dren and the opening of white neigh­ borhoods to minority residents. 
The government argument suggests that the administration will go along with the authority of judges to use a variety of measures to correct proven practices of racial bias as long as the courts confine their orders to those proven acts. 
No hints 
But there were no clear hints to t|je administration’s views on a question facing the Suprem e Court in other cases and likely to have a g r e a te r long-term impact on racial mixing 
That issue is whether the courts must require proof that officials intended Ao discriminate against minorities w h|n they took actions that produced se ­ gregation. The high court is moving in the direction of requiring such proof and that makes it more difficult fir minorities to win court orders requ^- ing integration. 
The department brief in the B eirut case was signed by acting Solicitor 
General Daniel M. Friedman and Asst. 
Atty. Gen. Drew Days, the first blagk to run the departm ent’s civil rigtUs division. Days was n o m in ated |>y 
President Carter. 
Atty. Gen. Griffin Bell had received an oral report on the brief before it w^s filed but had no direct involvement in writing it, a department official said'

Southwest Texas State University square dancers do their thing 
Friday at North Star Mall during a 37-hour marathon that began earlier in the day. The Wranglers, a SW TSU square dancing group, is trying to raise funds to pay their way for a State 
Department sponsored tour to Rumania, lf they reach their goal, the dancers last steps should end at I I p.m. Saturday. — Staff 

Photo by H. M. Dean Jr. 
Clayton: Texas must be better ally to M exico 

By JERRY DEAL 
Texas cannot sit back and wait for the federal wheels to turn in the government’s new cam ­ paign towards better relation­ ships with 
Mexico, 
Texas 
Speaker of the House Bill Clay­ ton said Friday. 
Clayton, addressing the 5oth anni­ versary convention of the Pan Ameri­ can Student Forum of Texas, said the state's interdependencies "with Mexi­ co are m any and we m ust a ttem p t daily to improve our situation." 
Also on the convention agenda and speaking of U.S. - Mexico relations was 
Mexican Consul General Haul Gonza­ lez Galarza. 
Clayton told the several hundred 
PASK student m em bers at the Con­ vention Center that policy measures by both nations, in many cases, have been passed with little attention to their impact to the people in Texas and oth- ar border states. 

"D irection, coordination and hard information is needed from the state level.” the House speaker said. "It is clear to most people that there is no one, at any level who can accurately state how im p o r ta n t are the social and political situations which affect the borders. 
"I think he Texas Legislature needs this inform ation, the Congress c e r ­ tainly needs it, because without it, re­ lationships suffer and we often miss discovering the solutions to common problems." 

Noting there has been a lack of good neighborliness with Mexico at the na­ tional level as was enjoyed when Lyn­ don Johnson was president, Clayton said Presidents Carter and Lopez Por­ tillo offer that new hope. 
He said Mexico is a good neighbor, citing, among other things, its help in selling the nation natural gas during the recent crisis. 
PASF and its 1o,ooo m embers, who are the future diplomats and interna­ tional business representatives, are vital to m a in ta in in g a frie n d sh ip between the U.S. and Latin American nations, he said. 

Learn culture 

"Continue your implementation of bilingual and bicultural program s," he said. "For too many years our country has been criticized for its slowness in a tte m p tin g to learn the languages, c u ltu re s and h isto ry of o th e r countries." 
G onzalez G a la rza w as given a standing ovation as he emphasized in both Spanish and English the im por­ tance of friendship between Mexico and the U.S. 
"We are learning from the younger generation to understand that even though our world is divided into na­ tions, human beings must be united,” he said. 
Some 5,(HK) m em bers from 2oo Texas high school and junior high chapters are expected to have attended the con­ vention by the time it concludes Sa­ turday. 
Cave-in probe sought 

Gov Dolph Briscoe and 
Secretary of Labor F. 
Ray Marshall were asked 
Friday to investigate the deaths this week of four laborers in San Antonio in construction cave-ins. 
Making the request in m ailgram s sent to the two public officials was 
Henry Munoz Jr., execu­ tive d ire c to r of the 
American Federation of 
State. County and Muni­ cipal Employes, District 
Council 99 
Munoz also asked the two officials to enforce existing laws designed to 

 protect workers in jobs where there is "eminent d a n g e r .” 
T he law s, 
Munoz said, have been e n a c te d to p ro te c t w o rk e rs’ lives, "M ex i­ cans included." 
There was no shoring on the trenches in which the accidents occurred 
Monday and T uesday, 
Munoz said. 
“ It is obvious that con­ tractors doing business in San Antonio, Tex., fi­ gure that Mexicans are ch eaper than plywood and two-by-fours," Mun­ oz asserted.

KINGSVILLE, 
(AP) — Lawyers for Roy 
A guilar P a rris h asked 
Friday for a psychiatric examination for the un­ em ployed tru c k d riv e r accused of taking six hostages and holding more than 8o South Texas police o fficers at hay before his capture.

Border Patrol agent,

RRC asks more data in frozen gas funds 

 urn ss n e w s a u s t in su m a u 
AUSTIN — The state Texas Railroad 
Commission is asking for more evi­ dence before making a final decision on $1.6 million Lo-Vaca Gathering Co., has earned from the interstate ship­ ment of natural gas. 
The commission has called a hearing for March 22 to take more evidence and hear additional arguments on the money which is now being held in escrow under commission orders. 
The money represents earning by 
Lo-Vaca as a pipeline link in moving emergency gas supplies from Texas to the energy short Northeastern U.S. 
Halt 
In early February, the RRC halted 
Lo-Vaca from spending any part of an estim ated $2o million in profits the company expects to earn in 1977. 
H ow ever, on M arch 7, the RRC amended this order freeing all but the initial $1.6 million earned on interstate gas shipments by the company sa) far. 
The RRC heard testim ony earlier from both Lo-Vaca and several of the company’s natural gas custom ers in­ cluding San Antonio. 
Lo-Vaca officials told the com m is­ sion it would go bankrupt if all its es­ tim ated profits were frozen. It also threatened to go to court if the com­ mission didn’t free the estimated pro­ fits. 
The customer group has argued Lo* 
V aca’s profits as well as what they allege is a windfall from interstate gas shipments must be at least partially shared with them in the form of re­ duced gas prices. 
W oman to head court 
SAN FRANCISCO (A P ) - Rose 
Elizabeth Bird, a 4o-yearold attorney, was confirm ed F riday as the first woman to serve as chief justice of the 
California Supreme Court, 
At a news conference soon after a judicial commission voted in her favor, 
Ms. Bird said, "I hope to dedicate my professional life in terms of this posi­ tion to ensuring fairness and that jus­ tice is done." 
Of the heated and som etim es per­ sonal comments registered against her by some w itnesses during the co m ­ mission’s hearings, Ms. Bird said the system " is a process that req uires openness and a great deal of discus­ sion. and in the long run, although it s difficult when you’re in the middle of it, ifs probably healthy for our politi­ cal system." 

By DICK MERKEL 
CHIEF, EXPRESS NEWS CAPITOL BUREAU 
AUSTIN — A bill that would pump millions of dollars an­ nually into San Antonio for con­ struction and maintenance of city streets and roads was in­ troduced here Friday. 
HB1995 was filed by freshman San 
Antonio Rep. Frank M. Tejeda. 
It calls for the state to retu rn to 
Texas cities and towns 3o per cent of all taxes collected on the retail sale of gasoline, oil, parts, accessories and tires. 
These funds would be placed by the state in a special city streets fund and returned in an amount proportionate to the taxes collected by each city and town. 
Dead aim 
T ejed a’s bill takes dead aim at a portion of the new funding established in the governor’s highway bill intro­ duced as HB3 by Rep. Jim Nugent of 
Kerrville. 
HB3, which passed the House e a r­ lier, is now stalled in the Senate where 
Lt. Gov. Bill Hobby says it will be considered at a later date when the total state appropriations picture is clearer. 
* Tejeda’s hill is not dependent on the passage of the highway funding hill. 
While it stands on its own, it does take part of the funding plan of the 
Nugent hill and apply it to local street and road needs. 
Under I1B3, one-fourth of the retail gasoline, oil, parts, accessories and tire taxes are earmarked for public school funding. 
Another one-fourth would go to the 
County and Road District Fund of the state Highway Department. 
Highways 
The remaining 5o per cent would be earm arked as new funds for the con­ struction of state highways. 
The Tejeda bill would slice 3o per cent out of the general state highway construction funds in the Nugent bill and put them into the City Streets 
Fund. 
The State C om ptroller’s office has not been re q u ire d to m a in ta in a breakdown of the taxes collected by 

 ft calls for return to cities o f 
.3o per cent o f nil tuxes collected on retail sale o f g a solin e, o il, p a rts, acces­ sories and tires 

 cities and towns individually. 
However, figures prepared to show- statew ide estim ated revenues from these sources in 1978 indicate they will generate a total of $4o9.6 million. 
Under Tejeda’s bill, 3o per cent of this or $122.8 million would go into the 
City Streets Fund for distribution to cities and towns across the state. 
Since San Antonio is the third largest city in the state it is fair to assume its proportionate share of this fund would add into a m ajor boon for new con­ struction and maintenance of the city’s streets. 
For the year 1977, San Antonio has 

 budgeted $176,42o for right-of-way ac­ quisition for new streets, and $4.6 mil­ lion of all phases of street construction and maintenance. 
Tejeda said Friday his 3o per cent figure in the bill is based on informa­ tion supplied to him by the City of San 
Antonio. 
“ It’s estimated,” he said "about 3o per cent of all the d rivin g done in 
Texas is done on city streets. It seems only f a ir," Tejeda said, " th a t this portion of the cost of maintaining city streets should be borne by the state." 
Tejeda said his bill is p ro m pted mainly "by the deplorable condition of some streets in San Antonio, particu­ larly on the city’s South Side. 
"They are filled with chug holes and areas where water will not drain off, but stands for days at a tim e. This condition is a m enace to driving as well as health and exists not only in 
San Antonio but in cities and towns state-wide." 

Elizabeth “ Bitsy” Ruiz, center, 23, holds her trophy after being crowned Miss Kelly AFB Friday. Flanking her are first runner-up 
Jeanne M arie Troberm an, right, and second runner-up Alm a 
Canales. Miss Ruiz, who represented the 2851 st Air Base Group, is choir director and band assistant at Burbank High School. 
State court will move to old federal building 

By DEBORAH WESER 

Commissioners court voted 3-2 
Friday to shift one state court to available space in the former federal building on Alamo Pla­ za. 
The move came after close to two weeks of space juggling and debate, particularly over quarters for the last of the four new co u rts c re a ted for 
Bexar County last month. 
Three of the new courts already had space under the Bexar County Courth­ ouse roof. District judges had objected to reducing the size of the central jury room there to allow room for the fourth court 
Space 
They argued additional courts meant a need for more, not less jury room space. 
Tapped to m ake the move across town to the former federal building is 
175th Dist. Judge Preston Dial. Dial, earlier this week, volunteered to make the move, despite some acknowledged problems with transporting prisoners and jury back and forth. 
Favoring the shift to the former federal building were County Judge 
B lair R eeves and C om s. A lbert 
Bustamante and Jeff Wentworth. 
Wentworth, in fact, initiated conver­ sations with federal officials here leading up to the offer of the frit* space for the fourth court. 
Opposing the move were Coms A. J. 
Ploch and Tom S to lhan dsk e. Both wanted to see all the courts housed under the same roof. Stolhandske at one point even suggested letting one of the c o u rts take over the C o m m is­ sioners Court room and finding a n ­ other location for the commissioners, 
Building 

Meanwhile, commissioners agreed informally to wait until May 27 before making any firm decision on a deve­ lo pm ent plan for a p roposed new county office building. 
The waiting period was requester! by city officials lo look al prospects for a joint city/county office building a* a feasible venture . 
• 
County Commissioners will decide 
W ednesday if they need to u pdate 

 county space needs to coincide with the 
Fred Soele, the civil jury assignment city study. clerk, a reclassification that hikes his 
In other action, commissioners gave pay to $2o.3(H) a year from $17,6oo.

San Antonio EXPRESS-NEWS— Saturday March 12 1977 

SASD says union can sue but it has no case 

By LIZ SWEET 

San Antonio School District Board 
President William Elizondo said F ri­ day the teacher’s union has a right to sue but will not he able to substantiate charges of mailroom spying. 
Calling charges made Tuesday by 

Paul Giamona, San Antonio Federation of Teachers. AFL-CIO, president, ba­ seless and irresponsible, Dr. Elizondo said the union organization had never been harassed by the board. 
Giamona claimed district mailroom employes were directed to open the personal mail of teachers in six select 

 schools to determ ine w hether they were receiving SAFT literature. 
The SAFT spokesman said the group plans to sue the board of education. 
Although Dr. Elyiondo said district policy was in the hands of the admin­ istratio n , he said the board would never tolerate censorship. 

The SAFT representative also ac­ cused board representatives of apply­ ing pressure to encourage support for the district’s $49 million bond election. 
Giamona claimed a SASD attorney told the organization harassment of its members would be relaxed if the group would guarantee union support for the 

 bond issue. 
Dr. Elizondo said G iam ona, r e ­ presenting the SAFT, came before the board and volunteered support for the bond issue. The hoard p resid en t, stressed Giamona did not ask for and did not receive any special favors. 
The claims, he said, were made by 

 those who were not happy with the results of the last board election. 
The claims were made by dissenters in order to manufacture disenchant­ ment within the district, he said. 
“They are preparing for the next 
(school hoard) cam paign," Dr. Eli­ zondo said. 
Bill would put 
.IL state tax funds into city streets

Saturday on grounds they are “ frivolous and social affairs.”

A fter the city begins alleviating problem s in 
D istrict 6, E stala said, 
“ th a t’s when I’ll dress up in a costum e and parade down Houston S treet.”

Al R o h d e. K o h d e h as been known to w ear an 
“ Uncle S am ” costum e on occasion, such as the 1978 
Bicentennial year.

Cisneros calls for new council rules 
City Councilman Henry Cisneros said Friday night new ground rules will have to be estab­ lished with the seating of the new City Council. 
“ The old rules — top-down dictation, one-way discussions, being talked to and not with, m on­ ey-centered powder — those days are gone,” he said at a cam paign party in his honor at Sacred 
Heart Civic Center. 
“ In its place will he a balancing and co-ex­ isting of several key power centers — business’, governm ent, labor and the community groups. 
The instability, the u n c e rta in ty , the tensions m ust give way to a new o rd er.” 
Cisnero running for re-election from District 
I. 
The cam paign function was sponsored by R. 
E. “ Bob” Montalvo.

Saturday March 12 1977 
W here is m y w ife ? 

STE. THERESE, Que. IAP) - 
The audience broke into laughter when Canadian Prime Minister 
Pierre Trudeau asked: “ Is my wife out there?” 
Trudeau was speaking at a 
French-language college where the audience of some 6o1 apparently was mindful of week-long rumors concerning his 28-year-old wife, 
M argaret, and Rolling Stones 

 leader Mick Jagger. 

Mrs. Trudeau attended a Stones recording session in Toronto last weekend and stayed in the same hotel as the group — then turned up in New York City, as did Jagger. 

Trudeau earlier announced his wife is canceling all official en­ gagements for a while in hopes of taking some of the pressure off. 

Probe sought in saccharin ban 

WASHINGTON (AP) 
— Leaders of two nation­ al diabetes groups 
Friday called for further investigation before the government bans the ar­ tificial sweetener sac­ charin. 
Dr. D. D. Etzwiler, a 
Minneapolis pediatrician 

2o% Oft 
Custom Orders 

Prices ore reduced 2o% through March 19 on custom made Parsons tables, cubes, and other custom designs. 
C overe d in your ch o ice of plastic lam inate co lors and built to your size specifications. M aster Charge, 
BankAmericard or revolving charge plan.storehouse 

6547 San Pedro at the corner of Jackson Keller (in Village Plaza) tel. 341 -2281. 

 who is president of the 
American Diabetes As­ sociation, said his group would concur with the 
Food and Drug Adminis­ tration’s ban “if evidence supports that i t s dangerous.” 
But Etzwiler and Bea­ trice Ducat of Philadel­ phia, founder of the 
Juvenile Diabetes Foun­ dation, said they are not convinced that Canadian tests that produced cancer in saccharinfed rats indicate that the sweetener is dangerous to humans in normal doses. 

The FDA announced on 
Wednesday that it will ban saccharin, the only approved sugar substi­ tute in foods and soft drinks, as soon as it can complete administrative procedures which are ex­ pected to take about four months. 
Rep. Jim M artin, R- 
N.C., a former professor of organic chem istry, announced that he will introduce legislation to amend a section of the 
Food, Drug and Cosmetic 
Act that prohibits m ar­ keting of any food addi­ tive known to cause 

 cancer in humans or an­ imals. 
The so-called Delaney 
Amendment is the provi­ sion under which the 
FDA announced its ban. 
Martin said “tests have shown that many harm­ less, everyday foodstuffs produce tumors” if fed to animals in large-enough 

Zaire claims recapture of small towns 

COMPILED FROM WIW SERVICES 
KINSHASA - Zaire claimed Friday that its forces recaptured two towns from Angola-based invaders. 
U.S. and other m is­ sionaries were reported unharmed in the invaded area although some of the Americans were said to be under house arrest. 
Eight Americans asked to be evacuated.

 quantities. 
He told a news confer­ ence that saccharin is 
“ absolutely safe in nor­ mal doses” but that the law gave FDA no option to consider the relative risks of taking small amounts of artificial sweetener in the diet. 
There are about five 

 million known diabetics being treated in the 
United States for their condition, which prevents them from eat­ ing sugar. 
For them sugar can be fatal, and the diabetes groups argue that it is unfair to ban their only source of sweetener.

 reported anywhere, but 
Zaire officials said their troops had retaken the small towns of Divuma and Kasaji and were moving on to the occu­ pied towns of Dilolo, Ka­ palua and Kisengi — all within 15o miles of the 
Angolan border. 

Tito considers nuclear bomb 

BELGRADE - A sen­ ior Yugoslav m ilitary com m ander says that world conditions will shape the Tito govern­ ment’s decision whether to develop nuclear wea­ pons. 
The officer, Col. Gen. 
Ivan Kukoc, said in a published interview that any armed attack against 
Yugoslavia would mark the beginning of World 
War III. He gave no indi­ cation of where he thought an attack might come from. 

Chile extends state o f siege 

SANTIAGO - Chile’s military government has extended the state of siege for six more months and said it will use its authority “ with m axim um en erg y ” to maintain order in Chile. 
The state of siege has been renewed every six months since the armed forces overthrew the late 
Marxist President Salva­ dor Allende in 1973. 
Among other things, it empowers authorities to hold prisoners without charge or court order and to apply military justice. 

Brazil cancels 
U.S. aid treaty 

BRASILIA - Brazil, traditionally the staun­ chest U.S. ally in South 
America, has canceled its 25-year-old military assistance treaty with the 
United States in a dia- pute over human rights. 
The Brazilian Foreign 
Ministry said a State De­ partment report on hu­ man rights in Brazil constituted an intolerable interference in its inter­ nal affairs. Congress re­ quires the department to prepare human rights reports on all nations scheduled for U.S. mili­ tary aid. The document 
— not yet released to the public — allegedly docu­ ments several human rights violations, includ­ ing torture of political prisoners. 

Carter nuclear plan disputed 

TOKYO - Prime Min­ ister Taken Fukuda has spoken out against Pre­ sident Carter’s intention to ban the spread of nu­ clear fuel reprocessing plants. 
He said he expects there vt ill be disagree­ ment with Carter when they meet March 21 in 
Washington Fukuda said he uants U.S. approval for Japan to go ahead with plans to test its first reprocessing plant in Ju­ ly. 

Actor buried 

BUCHAREST - Thou­ sands of m ourners jammed a cemetery for the funeral of Toma Car- agiu, one of Romania's leading entertainers and a ileu m of the quake 
Abidi killed at least 1,3oo persons

Page . 7-A 
W elfare chief says budget looks brighter 

By DAVID HENDRICKS 

The next yearly budget for the State 
Department of Public Welfare may not be cut as much as it first looked. State 
Welfare Board Chairm an Jam ie Cle­ ments said Friday. 
Clements was in San Antonio to visit this region's welfare office and to hear rep o rts on p e rfo rm a n c e in this 
21-county region. 
This is the fourth regional office he has visited, Clements said, and he 

 hopes to visit all 12 state regions. 
Clements said the earlier budget recommendation by the Texas Legis­ lative Budget Board in Austin had reduced the agency's budget substan­ tially. 
However, a House committee has recommended restoring some of the cuts, he said. 
The final decision will be made by the House Appropriations Committee and the Senate Finance Committee. 
He said he was generally pleased 

 with performance reports he had heard at the San Antonio office, and intends to carry one local idea to other state regions. 
A program referral service booklet prepared for all welfare offices in the region for general distribution im ­ pressed Clements, and he said he will send copies to all regions. 
Clements said he could not speculate on the recommendations now being put together by a special 47-member com­ mittee studying Medicaid problem s. 
Leader in preservation o f Longhorn dies at 9o 

SPECIAL TO THE EXPRESS N E W S 
CHRISTINE - Graves 
Peeler, 9o, the leader in the preservation of the 
Texas Longhorn breed of c a ttle in the 
U nited 
States, died Friday in a 
P le a sa n to n n u rsin g home. 
M ore than 4o y e a rs ago. Peeler started a s­ sembling a herd of Texas 
L onghorns. 
T he idea cam e from the late J. 
F ran k Robie and was boosted financially by Sid 
Richardson. 
Many of the T exas 
Longhorn cattle a ssem ­ bled came from Mexico. 
O thers were bought in lots of one or two head from ra n c h e s in the 
United States. 
Descendants of the ori­ ginal herd assembled by 
Peeler form the state- owned herd of more than 
KM) Texas Longhorns at the state park in Albany. 
Peeler was born and reared in the Campbell­ ton area. He was an in­ spector for the Texas and 
S o u thw estern 
C attle 
R a ise rs A ssn. for 17 years with a commission as a sp ecial 
T ex as 
Ranger in that work. 
Until recently Peeler had lived at the home of 
Mr. and Mrs. Alton Rugh here. M rs. Rugh is a

Legislators don’t show for m eeting 

By VICKIE DAVIDSON 
What would you do if you gave a party and the honored g u ests d id n ’t show — even after they said they would? 
Some .‘lh San Antonio insurance agents found out first hand F rid a y night 
They drank coffee and talked among themselves after eight Bexar County legislators failed to make the meeting. 
The session, sponsored by the Insurance Women of San Antonio, had been scheduled so insurance agente could talk with le g isla to rs about the more than I.IKM! in su r­ ance related bills c u r ­ rently before the legisla­ ture. 
State Rep. Don Cartw­ right was the only one to call and say he couldn’t make the session, which had a lre a d y been rescheduled once so the elected officials could at­ tend. 
“ I find it hard lo be­ lieve that out of seven people — no one showed u p .” said 
Rosa 
Lee 

Evans, past president of the o rg a n iz a tio n th a t represents LII) insurance agents in the city. 
“ I don’t know how you feel. . . I feel very, very let down and disappoint­ ed 
I ’m very e m b a r ­ r a s s e d ,” she told the group at almost 8 p.m. 
The session w as scheduled for 6 45 p.m. in a rented room at the San 
Antonio In te rn a tio n a l 
Airport. i think it’d be well if we d phone or w rite th e m .” she told the group of men and wo­ men 
Who were the missing guests of honor? 
State 
Sens. 
G lenn 
K othm ann and F ra n k 
Lotnbardino, along with 
State Reps. Hon Bird, 
Frank Madia, Jim Now­ lin, Abe Rtbak and Frank 
Tejeda never made it to th e ir scats at the speakers’ table. 
“ We should have held ti in an election year.’ cracked one woman in the back. “ Then they’d all have been here.”

Refinery threatens move if tax passes 

I * ' 

 uC X. 

.WWUllllll 1111% 
%V/l 

6 'o ^ 
Z . 
« 
J 

Saturday Only 
SAVE 
1o% to 5o% 
ENTIRE STOCK 
CHINA AND 
GLASSWARE 

CO RPUS C H R IS T I 
( A P ) - 
Coastal States Petrochemical Co. of­ ficials Friday threatened to close the 
$3oo million plant and discard plans for a SKM) million expansion if the state legislature approves a proposed five per cent refinery tax. 
“ This is not blackmail.” Albin VV. 
Smith, senior vice president of re fil­ ing, said at a news conference. “ We are merely stating the facts.” 
Smith said that the refinery would be unable to absorb the tax and operate economically. 
“ If we cannot add capacity econ­ omically here, we will take our invest­ ment elsewhere,” Smith said adding that the company would prefer to ex­ pand in Corpus Christi. 
“ But we don’t have to,” he added, 
“ and we won’t if the refinery tax bill chases us out of Texas.” 
The bill calls for a five per cent tax on the gross value of crude oil and distillate feedstocks used by Texas refineries. It was proposed to replace about $85o million a year that will be 
.lost if the ad valorem taxing ability for 

 public schools is eliminated. 
The House version of the bill, spon­ sored by Rep. Jim Nugent of Kerrville, is now in the Ways and Means Com­ mittee headed by Rep. Joe Wyatt who opposes the tax. 

The Senate bill is also in a commit­ tee. 

The company is a subsidiary of 
Coastal States Gas Corp. of Houston. 

Smith said a recent study had deter­ mined that it would be economically feasible to expand the 17o,ooo-barrel capacity of the refinery, but if the bill is approved, “ we will have an entirely new set of economic facts to take into account. I can tell you right now that the refinery tax bill would so alter tty* economics of expansion here for Coas­ tal that the answer would be changed to ’no’.” 
The company, he stated, “ cannot justify spending $1oo million for refin­ ing in Texas if the advantages we have been counting on are to be eaten up by new taxes.”

EDITORIALS 

W illiam J. Reddell

Pane I. Burt 
M an a g in g Editor 
Debate on growth is useful for city 

City Council prudently de­ layed formal action on its plan­ ning com m ission’s first-phase projections for housing an esti­ mated 3oo,ooo new San Anton­ ians expected to live here before the year 2ooo. 
There rem ains much confusion and a considerable amount of opposition to com ­ prehensive city planning. It is a remarkable advance to see the planning commission even sur­ vive this far, let alone offer pro­ jected growth ideas. 
So, mark it down to perse- verence and hard work that a growth sketch has moved into full public debate. 
Planning decisions about to be made will involve very ex­ pensive installation of utilities 
— sewers, water, streets, drain­ age. One pending decision cuts directly athwart the public re­ ferendum decision of the Jan. 
17. 1976, vote on building on the aquifer’s recharge zone. 
That vote cannot lightly be brushed aside by council and should not be interpreted to be a com m unity stand against the free enterprise system. 
And by no m eans is the growth sketch a no-growth po­ licy. 
It is the first part of a conscious-decision approach to asking city tax-payers and rate-payers to bear the cost of often extensive installation of 

 services (water, sewers, streets and drainage). 
Water is an issue. There is no debate about the public respon­ sibility for protecting the water supply, though there is a differ­ ence of opinion about how that ought to be done. 
Clean water is a fundamental issue in the City Council elec­ tions and, to the extent that voters perceive candidates to be in favor of clean water, the aquifer referendum is a com ­ pelling bit of political history with a present application. 
Since developm ent north­ ward involves the aquifer’s re­ charge “ hot zon e’’ 
(which straddles FM 16o4, according to the U. S. Geological Survey maps), it is appropriate to in­ terpret the aquifer referendum to require best-possible advice in pursuing that development. A part of that pursuit is clearly- stated public policy about who will bear the cost of develop­ ment. 
In view of a Supreme Court decision on City Water Board policy (since changed) that held 
CWB reimbursement for certain water mains was double pay­ ment for the mains, the need for clear policy remains. There are hardships to overcome, to be sure. There is also need to overcome them with policy that can be supported over the long term. 
Cool heads in W ashington abort terrorism , save lives 

The people who handled the 
Washington terrorism crisis did a superb job. 
Considering the potential for tragedy, the incident was de­ flated with relative speed. The one fatality was an unwary radio news reporter-trainee who walked into the first dangerous minutes of the capture of the 
District (City Hall) building in the nation’s capital. 
Training of police and their special units in dealing with des­ perate persons has advanced encouragingly in recent times. 
Handling of potentially-explo- sive incidents has moved from the terrifying practice still vivid in m em ory that was used at 
Kent State, Jackson State and other places just a few short years ago. 
Stand-off was m aintained and confrontation was averted. 
Child porn can be slopped 

Two bills are moving through 
Congress that deserve careful speed and cooperative support of the members. They are aimed at the abuse of children as ac­ tors in pornographic films. 
One bill deals with the mat­ ter as child abuse legislation. 
The other w ill come under child labor laws. 
Rationale is that children ar­ en't consenting adults. They are, as the law acknowledges. 

Double standard 

While it is startling to see the leader of the assault freed on his own bond —- a name on a form — one may be assured that he is under surveillance and will ap­ pear as the court has ordered. 
And — the prime goal of the whole operation — the hostages are free without bloody violence. 
There is likely more deter­ rent effect in a dram atic a s ­ sault’s abortion than in a show­ down in which persons are killed. In the Washington inci­ dent, the assault was a failure. 
The assault leader’s forum for trying to enforce his own brand of justice was effectively taken away from him. 

Washington officials and the ambassadors of Egypt, Iran and 
Pakistan did a skillful job and probably saved a num ber of lives. 

 pawns of adults who control them. They are victims of peo­ ple who seek fortunes preying upon exploitable people. 
Fortunately, laws define children ’s rights, even to re­ m oving them from fam ilies which abuse them . There are no 
First Amendment questions in­ volved and, we assume, no lobby able to slow the legislation to stop an evil already too far spread. 

Sir. In reference in article (March 
8), “ Court decision on aquifer,” I ani going to ask a question: 

Is is not true that city, county and state condemnation procedures on properties owned by our citizens have been unjust as far as property rights are concerned?. 
How many home owners have found their homes condemned overnight “ for the sake of p r o g r e s s ” ? 
Your newspaper has carried story after story about these cases, even the peo­ ple who have been bodily removed by law officials from homes legally owned under all property rights. 

The Water Quality Board staffers' attention to property rights is one of the double standards of justice in a state over 2o(1 years behind the times 
— our time, our grandchildren’s time. 
I would like to see Texas Atty. Gen. 
John Hill initiate condemnation proce­ dures on all lands located over the 
Edwards aquifer. Not only can John 
Hill take this action, he owes this sort of responsibility to all Texas citizens. 
If not, then I want him to answer this: 
Where are the health rights of all citizens affected by polluted water? 
John Hill should tell us why builders* rights have priorities over the health rights of so many human beings. Texas does not need a court verdict to protect the health of its people. Common horse sense, or is that too simple, tells Hill to condemn all this land and let s neither hear nor read any more about the 
Edwards aquifer. 
Mrs. Gloria Alicia Kubio 

An open letter to Am erica 

Sir. This is ail open letter to Ameri­ ca: 
I have watched you suffer since 1921 
. . through the depression of the 3os, 
VVVVII, Korea, Vietnam, etc. And. yet. in spite of all your other burdens, frustrations and d ise n c h a n tm e n ts you’ve never failed to reach the out­ stretched arms of poor people in dis­ tressed and ravaged nations who cry out in want of food and freedom. You seem to Im* the only one they despera­ tely turn to for help and guidance whenever they are in the brink of starvation or everytime a hostile na­ tion holds tin* threat of military ag­ gression against their civilization. 
But how many times have you been abused by some of those same nations and others (who still deceive you and accuse you falsely) in order to defame your good faith, frie n d sh ip and good-will? 
Yes. I rem em ber once when you were the strongest and most respected nation in the world. But back then you had loyal and dedicated country men who bravely stood by you whenever a foolish nation dared to slap you or to make the mistake of inflicting a stab- wound on your back (as at Pearl 
Harbor). But how about now? God forbid a recurrence of another disas­ trous blow upon people not prepared 
(mentally). 
Wake up America! How many more heartbreaks and how much more pun­ ishment can you endure i i i the event a foreign power attacks you again? Who is going to protect and defend you?

 highly on adequate linguistic skills in the prevalent sta n d a rd language, nothing can he concluded from this about the relationship of ignorance and dialect. 
Certainly knowledge, the supposed, counterpart to ignorance, is gained through experiences other than com­ municating in standard English. And while the relationship between cogni- t it ion and language is a hazy one at best, those functions which presuma­ bly m ark the adequately intelligent person from the ignorant one, namely the ability to gain knowledge through abstraction and reasoning, depend on facility with a symbol system . . . not the standard English symbol system. 
I fully agree with Miss Pabst that to 
“succeed” in this society a command of standard English is necessary, and that it is the role of the public schools to teach such skills. But let this speak to academic and economic success — the opposite of which is not ignorance. 
Dialect and poverty, maybe; dialect and ignorance, no. 
Barbara T. Sykes

English, how can these students ever hope to break the cycle of poverty and ignorance?”

Carter missile trade bad deal 

WASHINGTON - President 
( arter has said the United 
States would forgo develop­ ment on the MX intercontinen­ tal ballistic missile if the Rus­ sians would do the same on a new mobile missile — the SS2o. 
On its face, Carter’s proposal looks like a fair tradeoff. 
I'nder closer inspection, however, it appears to involve both complex­ ities and disadvantages from the I S. point of view. 
S u p e rific ially , the two weapons system s have much in common — both will be mobile and both will have multiple (MIRV) warheads. But here the iesemblance slops 

First for U.S. 
The U S MX is not only the first mobile land-based strategic missile system we have ever programmed, it is also the first and only ICBM of any kind we have developed since tile ob­ solescent Minutemen went into place nearly two decades ago 

MX is intended to update and re­ place M inuteman, which is totally vulnerable to a Russian first strike. 
During this sam e period, the So­ viets have built and deployed mort than half a dozen ICBM system s, each more formidable, heavier and accurate than its predecessor. 
The SS2o, a solid-fuel weapon about 
IO tim es as accurate as models it succeeds, is a tw o-stage m issile 
(which the Russians claim makes it a niedium-range weapon aud, thus, nm subject to SALT). 
Transformation 
What the Russians don t say is that the SS2o is subject to rapid transfor­ mation into a three-stage, full-range 
ICBM simply by bolting on compon­ ents of a sibling mobile weapon, the 
SSIH 
The only difference between tht 
SS2o and the SSIH - a full-fledged 
ICBM — is that the SS2o is about five feet shorter because it has only tht two-stage firing canister. 
Even without adding the SSIH third stage, intelligence analysts say, with an alternate light warhead, the SS2< 

Col. lf**IBI Robert D. 
Heinl Jr. 

 can fly 4,ooo miles and hit many tar­ gets in this country — quite a feat for a “ medium-range * missile. 
What m akes P resid en t C a rte r’s proposed tradeoff disadvantageous is that the MX is supposed to Ik* a sur- vtvable fu tu re ICBM in the U.S. stralegic-weapons “ tria d ” (ICBMs, strategic b o m b e rs and b allistic- missile submarines). 
The MX is not, like the SS2o (or even the SSIH) merely one of a huge family of ICBMs, several models ol which the Soviets could d isc a rd without crippling or unbalancing their strategic weapons array. 
The MX is specifically designed to 
Im* able to survive and hit back at a 
Russian first strike and thus neutra lize their inventory of such weapons. 

 lf the MX is to be used as a barter item in future SALT negotiations, it can only be logically equated w ith tin 
Soviet weapons that now menace our 
Minuteman — their mighty SSIH and 
5519 — not with the lighter, though highly capable, SS2o aud SSIH. 

Serious m isgivings 
In its own rights, simply as a so­ called m edium -range m issile, the 
552o has aroused serious misgivings in the U.S. intelligence community. 
Nominally, the SS2o is supposed til replace two earlier model MR BM* which, according to satellite photo­ graphs, number 54o. 
But 1,2oo SS2os are programmed. which means a more than two-for-om replacement margin 
If this mass of new mobile missiles were concentrated in southwest Rus­ sia so as to m enance NATO, SS2< could hit any target in Western Eur­ ope or Britain, thus further weaken­ ing the already enfeebled U.S. nu clear shield for NATO. 
In fact, the Russians already pus se ss. with existing inedium -rangi 

Sir Re: HAV. Ball (Letters, March 
3). I have been reading of your prob­ lems with people who want to be paid for having your yard and flower beds worked. Why should you feel so bad about it? Do like me. 

I do all this and save money. I do not do it in one day; I do a little here today; tomorrow some more trimming. 

Yes I have lost my belly weight in doing so. 

People on welfare really face a lot el investigation before getting welfare, so do your digging and cleaning. 
Rosalia N. Martinez 

 missiles and some 7(H) medium-range nuclear capable bombers, a type ot aircraft for which we have no equi­ valent, regional nuclear superiority. 

Concern voiced 
Fred C. Ikle, the able scientist who has just stepped down as head of the 
U.S. Arms Control and Disarmament 
Agency, voiced his concern over the 
MX developments before his resig­ nation earlier this year. 
“ If Soviet programs were merely a reaction to ours, their strategic-wea- pons budget would have declined over the past 15 years because that is what ours did,” lkie said. 
“ They would have stopped deploy­ ing ICBMs when they reached 1JHM); they would have stopped at 71o bal­ listic sea-launched missiles, as wt did, instead of building up to 95o 
"W hen we d ism a n tle d our in- term ediate-range ballistic missile* and bombers, the Soviets did not fol­ low suit . . . Why are they adding to this arsenal? What — we must ask with deep concern — is the political purpose?” 

Terror drowns news of 
President 

WASHINGTON - The latest outrage here demonstrates that terrorists have figured out how to use the newspapers, radio and television for their own purpose. 
It also shows that we still haven't puzzled nut how to handle them. 
It is a hard and dicey problem. 
The main objective of most terror­ ists is to get worldwide publicity from precisely the institutions they hate the most. 
They are using the free and compe­ titive instincts of democracy to destroy it, and we are cooperating by giving them even more publicity than they expect. 
Tyranny 
The Hanafi Muslim sect has demon­ strated here the tyranny of the minor­ ity. and the fragility of democracy. 
For by taking hostages at gunpoint and committing murder within sight of the White House, they have disrupted the normal life of the federal capital, and diverted the media from the larger essential news of the nation to the immediate violence in the streets. 
By any test of news, this was clearly spectacular. 
L arge a re a s arou nd the Isla m ic 
Center, near the B’nai B’rith head­ quarters and at the City Council head­ quarters were cordoned off by the po- 

The interesting thing about the violence in W ashington is that it came at almost the same time as a most remar­ kable press conference by l*resi<lent Carter. 

Hee, with h e lic o p te rs c irc lin g the center of the city and rattling every­ body’s hack teeth. 
It was almost a perfect local gee- whiz story, with dramatic pictures for the evening network news and with hour-by-hour reports on local radio and television it commanded the attention of this city. 
The interesting thing about the Han­ afi Muslim violence in Washington is that it came at almost the same time as a most remarkable press conference by F*resident Carter. 
He proposed, among other things, a 
$1.5 billion youth employment bill to deal with the fact that more than half the total unemployed are less than 24 years old, and among these, say from 
1H to 19 years old, we have over 18 per cent unemployed, and in some of the minority groups in urban areas, more than 4o per cent. 
Youth corps 
In the same press conference. Carter proposed a Youth Community Conser­ vation Corps for people on the land; a 
Youth Conservation Corps for young unemployed people in the cities; a new proposal for c o m p ro m ise betw een 
Israel and the Arab states in the Mid­ dle 
East; a phased withdrawal of 
American troops from South Korea; a series of compromises with the Soviet 
Union for a military arm s agreement, 
“ leading ultimately to the complete elimination of atomic weapons from the face of the earth.” 
It is hard to rem em ber at any time since the last W'orld W ar when any 
Am erican president m ade so much news in a press conference or an y ­ where else, proposed so m any p ro ­ gram s on the home front, suggested so many com prom ises and innovations abroad, some of them almost offhand and maybe premature or unwise, and yet still got so little attention in the newspapers or on radio or television. 

Not on Page I 

The violence in the streets by the 
Hanafi M uslim s drow ned him out. 
With all these serious presiden tial suggestions, he didn’t even get on the front page of The Washington Post, except in a footnote. 
So far as I can d isco ver a fte r a careful check, few, if any, newspapers printed the text of this rem ark able news conference except The New York 
Times. 
There were all kinds of things in this 
C a rte r p re ss co n feren ce to a rg u e alHiut. 
He was curiously and unnecessarily combative with the Senate about the confirmation of Paul Warlike as his disarmament chief 
He was alm o st casu al and even reckless in proposing a Middle East compromise between Israel and the 
Arab states — just alter seeing the head of the Israeli governm ent and before his forthcoming meeting with the Arab leaders. 
Timetable 
Ile gave a tim etable for th drawai of American troops froi 
Korea and he was combative negotiating an arm s agreeme the Soviet Union. 
Neither the President nor th has figured out this problem of news in the modern world of ter propaganda, and ambiguous |n 
The men with the guns have ated the* news here this week 
The media have followed thei principle that what is new is rn what ( arter said, right or wi clearly more imimrturit and ii during — but imbody could Iii for the noise and the hcadlint the terrorists

Wrestler wants to put his daughters in college 

THIS professional wrestler believes in himself — Leo 
Seitz — and Jesus Christ. staff photo «y pat hamilton 
S.A. nurses warned about supporting new nursing bill 

Moments after his 24o pounds of muscle and blood are flung from the wrestling ring. Leo 
Seitz is back, carrying on like 
King Kong — charging his op­ ponent, bellowing “WAANNHH, 
WAANNHH, WAANNHH.” 

It's all in vain — if, winning is his goal. 

But his goal is to put his daughters in college. 

Seitz loses the W ednesday night match in four minutes to a man who calls himself the Iron Sheik and stalks to the spotlighted ring in a robe and a burnoose. 

“ Hey, that guy got me completely by surprise. I was gonna get him by sur­ prise and he got m e," explains Seitz 15 minutes after his defeat. 

Seitz, one of the mainstays in San 
Antonio professional wrestling, is sit­ ting backstage at Municipal Auditor­ ium smoking a cigarette and discuss­ ing his life as a professional wrestler. 

His voice and manner are subdued, nothing like his ring manners. 

W hile h e ’s ta lk in g his fellow' wrestlers are 3o feet away peeking be­ hind the stage curtains at the match in motion. Sounds of jeering spectators soak through the stage curtains. 

Saturday 

WM, 
Vickie 

7 think there's probably more doctors and lawyers in prison fo r dishonesty than wrestlers' 

Is that match in the wrestling ring real? Or fixedo Some people say pro­ fessional wrestling is as phony as a $3 bill. 
For real 

“ No way,” says Seitz. 

"I think there’s probably more doc­ tors and lawyers in prison for dishon­ esty than wrestlers. 

“ Any blood I ’ve ever shed in a wrestling match has been my blood. 
“ Look at my eye," he says. 

His left eye — at first glance — looks bruised. On closer inspection, it starts looking like make-up. 
He says the bruise is real. He even moves into the bright lights of the dressing room. "Touch that — it’s not makeup — that’s meat. 

Leo Seitz, who’s a coach at Southside 
High School during the day, wrestles professionally nights weekends and summers. 

Why? 

“ For the money." 

It’s good money, he says. “ I would have gotten $2oo or $3oo more if I'd won tonight." 

The 3o-year-old Seitz says he wants the wrestling money to send his three daughters to college. 

But money isn’t the only lure holding 
Seitz to wrestling. 

Competition 

“ I enjoy competition — one to one competition. 
‘ If you do good, it’s what you have done and if you make mistakes, there’s no one to blame but yourself,” says the former professional football player. 
“ I’m only happy when I'm compet­ ing. I like to see my opponent beaten and I’m the victor." 

Are you serious? 
“ Yes.” 

Why? 
Satisfaction 
“ It’s a drive. I don’t know why I have to beat people to feel satisfaction," he says always talking softly, articulate­ ly. 

You m ight guess Seitz would get some satisfaction from the fans who recognize him on the street or the ones who call out “ Heey. Leo,” and cheer him on during a match. 
Seitz would say you guessed w rong. 
“ Makes no difference at all whether the fans are booing or cheering. 
“ Why should I care? I know- where 
I'm going and what I’m doing." 

That seems like an unusual attitude. 
“That’s the only way I’ve survived this long in athletics. I can do without peo­ ple very easily ,’’ the w restler says seriously. 

“ I’ve seen a lot of hypocrisy out of people . . . if I broke my leg tonight, my opponent wouldn’t care. My fans would say, “ that’s too bad.’ ’’ 

“ I think I really like dogs better than people," he says explaining about his pet German Shepherd. 

Then he says his students are an ex­ ception. 

"I really get off on my students. I 
'eel like I can help them ." 

But. who helps Leo Seitz, who does he believe in? 

“ I believe in Leo Seitz and .Jesus 
C hrist,’’ he says without hesitation. 
“That’s the only thing I believe in.” 

By DAVID MCLEMORE 
EXPRESS NEW S MEDICAL WRITER 
A Dallas nurse, alle­ gedly fired for her sup­ port of the proposed Tex­ as Nursing Practice Act, w arned 
San 
Antonio nurses Friday the same thing could happen here. 
Pat Driscoll, form er vice president of nursing serv ice at D a lla s ’ St. 
Paul’s Hospital, spoke at a press conference held in the local Texas Nurse 
Assn. office. 
TNA is supporting the nursing act, which will eliminate the hiring of u n licen sed n u rs e s by 
Texas hospitals. The act is currently under study by the Texas Senate. 
“ I was fired Feb. 28 over what Administrator 
Sister Louise Schesley said were differences in philosophy,’’ Mrs. D ris­ coll said. 

 her job if she becomes too vocal in support of the bill,” she said. 
“ It’s simply a m atter of con tro l. 
H ospital adm inistrators fear pas­ sage of the act because they believe it will cause th em to lose som e aspects of control over nurses." 

Mrs. Driscoll said she supports the act because it will improve the high standards of nursing care and because consum ers now are paying for a le­ vel of care they don’t re­ ceive. 

“ The patient expects and pays for professional nursing care, but doesn’t always receive it. Unli­ censed nurses should not be p assed off to the 

 c o n su m e r as a profes-, sional nurse. 
“ It should not be legal for hospitals to hire unli­ censed nurses to perform p a tie n t c a re at levels beyond their capabilities. 
That’s what the act will change, if passed," she said. 
T he use of foreign trained nurses is a large part of the problem, she said. “ T e x a s H ospital 
Assn. estimates there are 
9,ooo unlicensed foreign trained nurses in Texas. I feel that’s a conservative estimate. 
“ In 1975 alone, 1,3oo foreign educated nurses took the state exam ina­ tion for registered nurse. 
Only 4oo passed, which still leaves 9oo still c ir­ c u la tin g a ro u n d the state,” she said.

THE SLEEP SHOP 

“ She said my vocal supp ort of the n u rsin g act w as a sy m p to m of that difference.” 
M rs. 
D riscoll said many San Antonio nurses fear the loss of their jobs if they support the bill. 
“ It would not be un likely that any nursing supervisor in San Anton­ io or elsewhere could lose

The defenders had the right number in their intricate defense of today's touch and go gam e. P layed in the 
Australian National Cham­ pionships. Australia’s George 
Havas has subm itted the hand for the Charles Solomon 
"hand of the year" award At the defensive controls were 
J eff Lathbury and John 
Lester of Australia. 
Declarer won his diamond queen, cashed two high trumps and then played the remaining top diamonds to throw away one of his losing spades Next a low club from dummy produced East's king w hich d ecla rer captured with the ace A low club was led to dummy and West play­ ed the seven, dummy the ten and East discarded 
On this trick had West either taken his queen or had 
East ruffed, the d efen se w ould be over 
D eclarer would lose only a trump, a club and a spade and the game would succeed 
After winning the club IO in dummy another club was led from dummy. East discarded again and declarer's eight went to West’s nine Now the defenders had to cross the major hurdle and there was no problem West led a low spade, dummy's king was played and East won the ace 
The high trump was cashed and East exited with a dia­ mond This gave declarer a ruff and discard but it did him no good One more trick had to be lost for down one 
After winning the third round of clubs had West sw itched to the “ob v io u s’ spade queen, declarer would have made the hand Dummy would have played low and now the defenders could not prevent declarer from using all his trumps for a successful crossruff 
Hut what if dummy had played Iovi on West s low

Good Turn

Handy Andy, H E B 
M agnam art, Skaggs Al­ b ertso n and 
Century 
Paper Company all day 
Saturday.

March 19.

Good Turn Day ever.

Saturday March 12 1977

 slaying of his children four years ago. 

Muhammad has denied responsibili­ ty for the slayings but said Friday he would not have stopped them if he had been given the chance, because Abdul 
Khaalis had threatened the late Mus­ lim leader Elijah Muhammad. W al­ lace’s father. 

 fund at Howard U niversity in his memory. 
Barry, recovering from a chest wound inflicted in the takeover of city hall, was released. 

Atty. Gen. Griffin Bell also has said he believes authorities should honor promises made to terrorists to gain release of hostages. 
In other developments: 
• Six of the gunmen’s victim s remained hospitalized, two in serious condition. City Councilman Marion 

Continued from Page JA granted pretrial freedom to Abdul 
Khaalis only as part of the bargain “ to save a human life.” 
He asked that the others be jailed with high bail set because they “ in­ flicted a reign of terror not only on these people (the hostages) but on this city, the nation’s capital.” 
The freeing of Abdul Khaalis drew expressions of outrage Friday. Sen. 
Lloyd Bentsen, D-Tex., said on the 
Senate floor that prosecutors should not have honored their promise to free him. 
“ A promise made at the point of a gun has no moral force whatsoever,” he said. “ Khaalis was free, ... at liberty with family and friends, even before his hostages were home, even before the funeral of the assassinated reporter.” 
Disagreement 

But there was disagreement from 
Police Chief Craig Merchant of W ar­ rensville, Ohio, who negotiated release of two hostages from a gunman in a 
45-hour siege earlier this week. 
“ If hostage-takers get the idea that they can’t trust you to do what you say you'll do, then you’re in trouble and that puts hostages’ lives more in danger,” he said. 

• Black Muslim leader Wallace I). 
Muhammad said in Chicago he feared for his life because Abdul Khaalis is free. Muhammad is among those Ab­ dul Khaalis blames for the brutal

134 hostages early Friday in Washington and sur­ rendered. When they took over three buildings in the nation’s capital Wed­ nesday, they demanded that the film , which opened in New York the same day, be halted and 
“ removed from this county” on the ground that it was offensive to 
Moslems. 
Akkad, a naturalized 
American who came here 
25 years ago, said the, film took five years to make and cost $17 m il­ lion. A native of Syria and himself a Moslem, he said the main purpose of the film was to educate. 
On Thursday, while the hostages were still being held, Akkad offered to show the film to the 
Hanafis, promising, “ I will destroy the film if it is (ffensive to them.” 
Asked the status of his offer on Friday, he said: 
“ The offer still stands, not only to the Hanafis but to any legitim ate 
Moslem organization. 
They can come forward and (if they) show me any inaccuracy, historic or religious, I will des­ troy the film.”___________

Ghost town died in fear 

This is the story of a Texas ghost town that lived and died in fear. 
It lived a short time — 16 years at the most. 
And maybe it never had a chance to live. 
Its leading historian, for the subtitle to her book about it. described it as: 
'‘The Impossible Dream by the Rio 
Grande.” 
There is no more romantic spot in 

Texas. For the ruins of a dozen or more, of the stone buildings these brave 
Spanish pioneers were forced to aban­ don 15o years ago are in existence to­ day. 
Ruins 
Most of the ruins are simply piles oi stone and rubble. But at some a sub­ stantial part of one or two w alls is standing. And occasionally a jagged section of a wall will rise like a great snaggled tooth along a ridge line. 

O n the La M esa Ranch — 25 miles up the Rio Grande from Laredo 
— is one of the most appealing ghost towns in Texaa. It is the old 
Spanish frontier town of San Jose de Palafox that died a violent death from Indian raids more than I 5o years ago. Rancher Guy H. 
Smith has a lease on I 3,ooo acres of the la M esa Ranch con­ taining the ruins. 

And who could look down into that great cistern beside the largest of the ruins and not dream of the people who once drew water from it. 
Adding to the romance of this town is that little was known of its history until a dram atic discovery of docum ents about it was made in 1969 — in San 
Antonio. 
Even as recently as 1968. another leading Texas historian had written: 
“ Details of its tragic story, appar­ ently, have been lost to posterity.” 
But found they were! 
The town is San Jose de Palafox. 
Its story lies at two places. 
Ranch 
One is the lonesom e — yet haunt­ ingly beautiful — site of the Villa de 
San Jose de Palafox on a ranch about 
25 m iles up the Rio G rande from 
Laredo. 
The other lies in a dozen pure white folders in the imposing library of St. 
Mary’s University. 
In these big folders — divided by years between 181o and 1827 — are about 4o handwritten docum ents in 
Spanish. Most are faded, some water- stained to a deep brown and others jaggedly torn by the wear of the years. 
Bonnie and I have visited both places that tell the story of San Jose dc Pala­ fox. 
Guy H. Smith — who has the ranch leased where stood San Jose de Palafox 
—graciou sly spent last Saturday showing us all the ruins. 
Then last Tuesday we met with Car­ men Perry, who translated the docu­ ments found at St. Mary’s University for her remarkable book, “San Jose de 
Palafox.” Carmen was archivist at the 
St. Mary’s library and present when the first document was found. 
She went through more than 13.ooo pages of other old Spanish documents to find the relatively few dealing with 
San Jose de Palafox. 
Letters 
We met at the St. Mary’s library. 
There Carmen carefully opened those big w hite folders and one by one showed us the time-browned letters and documents written to and by Pa­ lafox officials. 
' 
Carmen gave us a general explana­ tion of the contents of each document. 
We were moved that so many of them closed with the traditional ending that translates as: 
“ May God keep you many years.” 
Then we have Carmen’s book which translates all that can be deciphered of every document. 
With us at the library meeting — and showing us secondary reports with bearing on this historic town — was 
Anita C. Saxine, St. Mary’s director of libraries. 
On our trip to the site , we met 

There was Indian trouble from the start. M any o f the documents discovered deal with Indian raids and a t - tempts at defense 

 rancher Smith at the little camp that is ranch headquarters. No one loves and wants to shield the San Jose de Palafox ruins more than he. 
We got into his pickup and headed for the Rio Grande. 
Though the day was gray — and the wind out of the north — spring was coming to this wonderful land beside the river. Later in the story I want to tell you of its beauty — and of a few things we saw en route to the ruins. 
Across country 
After a few miles across country, we w'ent down a draw cutting through a high, stone bluff that back in geologic time must have been one bank of the 
Rio Grande. It is believed we were traveling the same trace used by the 
Spanish pioneers of Palafox. Once we crossed an old, old culvert made of stones. 
In front and below us was a broad, flat plain — a great pasture 
“ I’ve seen the grass here in wet 

 years coverin g every inch of the ground and as high as the hood of a truck,” Smith said. 
That sam e lush grass m ust have grown back in the days of San Jose de 
Palafox. The grass must have been one reason for the settlers coming here back in 181o. 
What high hopes they m ust have 
’had! 
As we drove across the plain, we started spotting a ruin here — another there. We stopped twice beside some stone work once part of an old irriga­ tion system — that could have gone back to the old Spanish town. 
Indian trouble 
San Jose de Palafox was founded in 
18to. There was Indian trouble from the start. Many of the documents Car­ m en'has translated deal with Indian raids and attempts to defend against them. 
There seemed to be a major raid by the Comanches in 1818 and fam ilies started abandoning the town. There was talk of stronger defenses and even of moving new families in. But ap­ parently the town was abandoned per­ manently in 1826. 
Reports are the Comanches burned the deserted town in 1829. 
Smith, Bonnie and I drove across the

A:

/
