This is part of the earliest document known ta exist de alin g with the now ghost town of 
San Jose de Pala­ fox. Archivist C ar­ men Perry gives its date as April 
1o, 
181o. It is signed by an official lo­ cated in the Presi­ dio of the 
Rio 
Grande — now the town of Guerrero, dow n the 
Rio 
G rande from Pie­ dras 
Negras. 
The official, Jose de Je­ sus 
Rodriguez passes on instruc­ tions concerning the town’s founding. 
■ 
/ 

 big pasture and soon were walking about the largest of the ruins. The big stone house stood facin g the Rio 
Grande. Plainly it had been the resi­ dence of one of the town’s important men. 
Only parts of the thick stone walls were standing and these had great jagged gaps. Grass was growing inside the house and grass and thorny brush almost covered the piles of tumbled nicks outside tke walls. 
“ There is one m ystery about all these houses,” Smith said. “There is no trace of a fireplace or a chimney. 
Where did they cook? How did they keep warm in the winter?’’ 
Stone for the houses came from the high bluff back from the river. As with the bluff itself, stones in the ruins were of many colors —several shades of red, others so dark they were almost pur­ ple, shades of yellow and gray and even a few dark green rocks. 
The thick walls were made of big stones — many too large for one man to lift — and stone slabs. Laboriously chinked between the large stones were hundreds of smaller ones. 
.Some of the inside w alls were co­ vered with plaster. 
The first room was L-shaped and had six rooms. Two were large. There was a seventh room at the end of the base of the “ L” that could be entered only from the outside. 
But the most remarkable thing was the big, stone-line cistern. It was se­ veral times deeper and larger in cir­ cum ference at the bottom than any cistern I ever saw. 
Looking down into it, who could help but wonder about the fate of the people who once drew water from it? 
Most of San Jose de Palafox had been down here on the river. From this first ruin, we drove up what plainly had been a dirt street between two rows of houses facing it. 
First there was another ruin back of the big house. Smith thought it may have been a barn or something simi-

T H E B I B L E 

No. 282. The Storm at Sea 

The Lord commanded Jonah to go to Nineveh and cry against the wickedness of that city, but Jonah attempted to flee God by booking passage on a ship bound from Joppa to Tarshish. The Lord sent a great storm Into the sea, and eventually the sailors discovered that the storm had been sent to punish Jonah. 
"Then said they unto him. What shall we do unto thee, that the sea may be calm unto us? for the sea wrought and was tem­ pestuous. And he said unto them. Take me up, and cast me forth in­ to the sea: so shall the sea be calm unto you; for I know that for my sake this great tempest is upon you.” (Jonah 1:11-12) 
Nevertheless, the men tried with all their might to steer the ship to land, but their efforts proved futile. "So they took up Jonah, and cast him forth into the sea; and the sea ceased from her raging. 
Then the men feared the Lord exceedingly, and offered a sacrifice unto the Lord, and made vows." (Jonah 1:15-16)

EMS lifesavers need more help 

Son Antonio EXPRESS-NEWS— Saturday March 12 1977 
Page * 3-B 

A major test of the quality of life in a city is the city’s concern for saving lives. By that test, the city of San Antonio is a caring city. 
The evidence has been in the establishment of the Emergency Medical 
Service which marked its third anniversary on 
March I. 
Four years ago the medical society called to the citizens’ attention the fact that people were dy­ ing because of a hapha­ zard ambulance response to critical need. 
People were dying be­ 

 w z 

 r n 

I 

 cause they needed immediate help rather than waiting until they got to a hospital for help. 
The Emergency Medi­ 

 cal Service was estab lished at considerable cost and effort to the city. 

The response time now averages six minutes with 33 minutes to com­ plete the call. Those cru­ cial minutes save lives. 
More than that, the pre­ sence of medical equip­ ment and trained techni­ cians in the module also saves lives. 
Now the doctors are calling another matter to the city’s attention. It is the matter of the saving of the lives of those who are saving lives. 
The stress factors in 
Big winds cut through Texas 

A SSO C IA T E D PRESS 
Powerful winds roared across 
West 
Texas 
Friday afternoon and showers and thunder­ storms soaked portions of 
East and Southeast Texas while a cold front made its way across the state. 
Falling humidity and the gusty winds prompt­ ed fire danger warnings for North Texas which had not received much moisture. 
The cold front was al­ most out of the state causing tornado watches in Louisiana and Arkan­ sas, but the remnants 

 were still sparking some trouble in Texas. Twis­ ters were reported 19 miles southeast of Mar­ shall and also near Was­ kom. 
No damage wa5 reported. 

Heavy winds also caused some trouble in the Panhandle. The State 
Department of Highways reported that several 
Panhandle highways had been closed due to blow­ ing dust and wind gust­ ing to more than 65 miles per hour. 
The highways closeo 

 were U.S. 287 between 
Dumas and 
Stratford; 
U.S. 54 between Strat­ ford and Dalhart and 
U.S. 87 between Dalhart and Texline, a depart­ ment spokesman said. 
Texas 1o2 was closed west of Dalhart due to irrigation equipment and grain elevator wreckage that has been blown onto the highway. 
Temperatures dipped into the 3os in the Pan­ handle early in the morning, but moved up steadily during the day. 
Brownsville had 
74 degrees at noon.

82 28 
Monterrey — . . . i i 

 the calls and hours of service have proved to be gargantuan. 
A number of techni­ cians have dropped by the wayside simply be­ cause they are unable to deal with the constant challenge and the hours involved in their duty. 

Stress 

Others are feeling stress emotionally within their own personalities and some in their family relationships. It is ob­ vious that a beefing up of the corps of persons in­ volved as emergency medical technicians needs to come. 
Additional training needs to be done. A rota­ tion system needs to be established. Two classes of about 4o each have been trained. 
Other training classes are now needed among the firemen and addi­ tional cost of paying sub­ stitutes in the fire fight­ ing while the training is taking place needs to happen. 
The estimate for train­ ing another class is 
$612,ooo. It is money well spent when the lives of people are being saved and the people who are saving lives are being helped. 

Gratifying 

It was a gratifying ex­ perience a few weeks ago to visit with an elderly lady who had been picked up by an EM S to be rushed to the hospital. 
After the crisis had passed, we were thank­ ing God together for the extension of her life. 
She said, “ I want to thank you pastor for the fact that you were one of the voices in our city calling for the EM S to be established. Little did I know then that I would be alive now because it hap­ pened.” 
I then thanked God for a city that cares. 

Romania wants 
American help 

A SSO C IA T E D PRESS 
B U C H A R EST 
- 
A series of specific re­ quests for aid to over­ come the effects of the severe earthquake that hit Romania last week was forwarded to W a­ shington Friday. 
Just why the Roman­ ians appealed to the U.S. instead of their Soviet allies was not immedia­ tely clear. 
The Bucharest govern­ ment wants new data processing systems for a heavily-damaged com­ puter center, instru­ ments for cardiology and other branches of medi­ cine, replacements for destroyed machinery, spare parts and much other special equipment. 

Country and church music mix in the background of W ill Eeeley, left, a member of Concordia 
Lutheran Church. He is shown here giving free guitar lessons to members of his congregation. 
Beeley, who writes and sings country music, has made an album, “ Jamestown Ferry, and a song soon to be released, “ But I D o n ’t Even Know You.” 
Class will study religious issues 

Starting on St. P a ­ trick’s Day, Thursday, a 
‘‘Contemporary Issues in 
Religion” class will be 
~ taught from 7 to 9 p.m. 
Thursdays through May 
12 at St. Mary’s Univer­ sity. 
Robert B. O’Connor, a native of Ireland and St. 
Mary’s Theology Depart­ ment chairman, will in­ struct the class. 
At the first meeting of the class, those regis­ tered will discuss what topics will be taught in the eight-week course. 
Some topics O’Connor will suggest include bio­ medical ethics, Biblical interpretations, religious education, relations of 
Church and State and other items in the fields of theology, religion, morality and related to­ pics. 
Tuition for the course will be $3o. For more information on the course and registration call 
436-3321.

Old Hebrew laws are still applicable 

JERU SA LEM (A P) - 
Jewish laws originating in Biblical times may be interpreted now to mean that modern chain supermarkets arc illegal because they have an un­ fair advantage over corner grocery stores. 
These laws also demand quick payment of debts in an inflation­ ary period. 
There were some of the conclusions that came out of a recent conference of rabbis OB a n c i e n t 
Jewish laws in modern times. 
The conference was not 

 intended to formulate new laws binding on all 
Israelis or Jews, but to determine what Jewish tradition says is legal in today’s business world. 
Only regulations passed by parliament stand up in court, notes Rabbi 
Abraham Dolgin, a con­ ference coordinator. 
The Congress on Oral 
Law will publish its find­ 

 ings as recommendations to the chief rabbinate. 
The rabbinate makes rulings binding on religious courts, which could arbitrate a busi­ ness dispute if voluntari­ ly submitted by both sides. 
Rabbinical courts u- sually deal with prob­ lems like marriage and divorce. 

 sical program at 6 p.m. 
Sunday at the church at

Gevers Avenue.

Eugene

'•ost of the music.

A flickering of light at the end of the long tunnel of rising cocoa prices burst into an inferno this week as both London and 
New York prices col­ lapsed under the imposi­ tion of a 1o.ooo-pound sterling deposit requirement per IO tonne lot on all non-London Co­ coa 
Terminal 
Market 
Association trade members and non­ members holding over 
IOO lots. 
Its effect was imme­ diate as prices fell 4o cents and 3o cents per pound in London and 
New York, respectively, since liquidation of long positions was preferable to many in lieu of meet­ ing the new deposit re­ quirement. 
The collapse was not restricted to cocoa, how­ ever, as sympathetic selling quickly spilled into coffee dealings and those prices fell as much as 25 cents and 17 cents per pound in London and 
New York, respectively, deapite the absence of negative news. 
25 per cent 
Brazil reported that exports during January and February totaled 
3,o4o,ooo bags which is 25 per cent of her desired export target for calen­ dar 1977 and also indi­ cated that minimum ex­ port prices starting in the second half will be sub­ stantially higher than those prevalent in the 
•first half. 
Commodity specula­ tors figuratively fell over one another in the mad dash for the window marked “ sell” and when the dust settled there were 2.572 orders to sell cocoa and 422 orders to sell coffee that could not be filled because prices had declined their per- missable daily limits and 

 ff buyers at lim it down prices could not be found. , 
Even metals were af­ fected when collapsing cocoa and coffee prices caused liquidation in copper so severe that news bulletins of an An­ golan incursion into neighboring Zaire, an important copper pro­ ducer, were not able to foster any sustainable rally. 
Nor was a Commerce 
Department report of a 
o.9 per cent increase in the wholesale price index during February, 1o.8 per cent annual rate, able to support raillies in gold and silver, two favorites as hedges against infla­ tion. 

ANALYSIS BY CHARLES E. CARDEN 

M O N D AY - The Dow 
Jones Industrial Average did not vary as much as a point off dead center un­ til the final hour, when it squeezed out a small gain of 1.66 on the day. In the absence of fresh news, all 
Dow changes were frac­ tional and volume was relatively light. In the whole market, advancers ran ahead of declines by

168, and the NYSE index of all common stocks posted a small plus of 
o o4. 
T U E S D A Y — A strong opening pushed the DJIA up nearly 3 points in the first 3o minutes, but thereafter the trend was downward. It closed pff 
3.o8. Brokers said the decline represented a correction of last week’s 
2o point advance which lacked conviction be­ cause it was not accompanied by impres­ sive volume. All Dow stocks closed within fractions, except East­ man Kodak which fell 
IMI 

WEDNESDAY - The market was on the down­ side from the start and the DJIA closed off 9.14. 
Traders found nothing in 
President Carter’s press conference to stimulate either buying or selling. 
Rather, they were appre­ hensive over wholesale price figures expected to show an increase when released Thursday. De­ clining issues ran more than 2 to I over advances. 

THURSDAY 
- The government reported wholesale prices rose o.9 per cent in February, about in line with expec­ tations, and the market stayed in a narrow range 

 in slow trading until mid-afternoon. 
Then came news that retail sales jumped 1.8 per cent in February following a drop of 2.3 per cent in 
January. The Dow Jones average closed up 3.83. 
Trading picked up as prices advanced. Upside volume totaled 1o,96o,ooo shares vs. 
4,9oo,ooo shares on the downside. 
FRIDAY 
- The late rally of the previous day carried over in early hours but met little sup­ port and prices drifted for the rest of the day. By the close the Dow Indus­ trials posted a fuzzy gain of o.99. 

SUMMARY 
- At­ tempts to extend the rally of the previous week were futile. Whenever prices moved to the up- 
'side, trading dried up. 
The Dow average held within a narrow range of 
23 points through the week. The market was still troubled by fears of renewed inflation and rising interest rates. 

RANGE 
— High was made on Tuesday at 
96o.36. Low was made on 
Thursday at 
938.oo. 
Close, Friday, 947.72. 
Loss on the week. 5.74. 
Volume, all shares trad­ ed on the NYSE, 93.46 million shares.

San Antonio EXPRESS-NEWS— Saturday March 12 1977 
Mart fails to hold gain pattern 

NEW YORK (AP) - 
The stock market got off to a strong start Friday but wound up the session with only a token ad­ vance. 
The Dow Jones average of 3o industrial stocks, up about 3 points in early trading, was ahead just 

.99 at 947.72 by the close. 
That left the average with a 5.74 loss for the week. 
Gainers outnumbered losers by a 4-3 margin on the New York Stock Ex­ change. 
Big 
Board volume plodded along at 18.23 

 million shares, against 
18.63 million Thursday. 
Brokers said the early strength represented a carryover of buying from late Thursday, when the 
Dow rose 3.83 points. 
After the initial buying subsided, the market settled into an aimless 

 pattern for the rest of the 
Session. 
Stauuara at Poor’s in­ dex of 4oo industrials posted a .o4 loss to 111.96, and S & P ’s 
5oo-stock composite index was off 
.o2 at 1oo.65. 
Sony was the most ac­ tive issue as of the 4 p.m. 

 close of the NYSE, up % at 9%. 

Inmont, second on the active list, slipped % to 
22. Esmark said it bought 
22o,ooo shares, adding to its previous holdings of the stock. 

Esmark rose M1 to 32 

The NYSE’s composite index of more than 1,5oo common stocks was up 
.o2 at 54.72. 
On the American Stock 
Exchanre, the market value index added .32 to 
111.64. The NASDAQ composite index of over- the-counter stocks gained 
.13 to 96.o7.

Continued from Page IB la r. 
T hen we w ent between the ruins of two houses and then in front of two houses. 
F a rth e r down, atop a low ridge, jagged pieces of walls looked like two rough pyramids silhouet­ ted against the sky. 
T h ere are few ruins scattered across the big pasture. But Smith next drove us back to the bluff. T here are four ruins at its base. 
Two seem to have been small homes. Around the point of the bluff were the ruins of a larger house and an outbuilding. 
Smith thinks the larger house m ay have been that of a landowner with the smaller houses for the families who worked for him. 
“ Here’s an interesting thing,” Smith said as he led us up to a big rock partly up the bluff. “ I think this m ight have 

CARMEN PERRY 
. . . wrote book 

 been where this family hid when there was fear of an Indian raid.” 
Back of the big boulder was a little rock s tru c ­ ture built so it was hard to see until you were right on top of it. 

Romantic 
There’s something ro­ mantic about a ghost town. But there also is something sad. 
You think of the chil­ dren at play — the family gathered around the din­ ner tab le — m o th e r teachin g her d a u g h te r how’ to spin or sew or cook. 
But m ost of all, you think of fathers and m o th ers — and th e ir hopes and d re a m s for themselves and for their children. 
There was som ething p a rtic u la rly sad about the broken dream s of San 
Jose de Palafox. 
One of the documents 
Carmen translated was a census of Palafox made on June 6. 1815. It showed 
238 people. Of these, 125 were boys and g irls — from babies to 16 years old. 
What did life eventual ' ly hold for those boys and girls counted in Palafox on th at long ago J u n e day? 
In the quiet of the big archives room of the St. 
Mary’s library. Carmen told us the d ra m a tic story of the finding of the 
Palafox documents. His­ torians had given up the hope of finding them, As 
C arm en w rote in her book: 
“Obviously any hope of discovering the lost ar- 

You can't buy better than 

Indians robbed and k illed 

San Jose de Palafox apparently was subject to 
Indian raids almost from its founding. 

Among the documents translated by Carmen 
Perry was one dated April 1813. It spoke of the 
Indians — “ not only theft and pillage which they commit but also the deaths.” 

Even the viceroy in Mexico City in 1814 knew of* the troubles. He asked for “a detailed list naming ail the individuals residing in the'Villa from the age of 16 to 5o years who in an emergency can bear arms.” 

That year hope arose, Carmen reports in her book, when Gov. Cordero wrote peace was about to be concluded with the Lipans and the com­ manding general was to start a campaign against 

 the Comanche Nation. 

It was believed to be 1818 when the Comanches struck their fiercest blow —and many families started leaving Palafox. 

Some fam ilies wanted to move hack in 1824. 
They were told they must have arms and am ­ munition to defend themselves from hostile In­ dians. 

Apparently as late as 1826. there was an official order to station 6o soldiers at San Jose de Pala­ fox. But it seemed they could not be properly equipped. 

And San Jose de Palafox died. 

 pages of the Spanish do- 
S m ith drove Bonnie country. For a P** "J cuments on Laredo. That and me for many miles trip we were joined y she did. a cro ss th is w onderful the Smiths s o n ^ a j^ ----- 

 ch iv es of Palafox had become the ‘the impossi­ ble dream ’ of Texas his­ torians.” 
For five years. Carmen was St. Mary’s archivist. 
Amid the lib r a r y ’s a r ­ chives was a large col­ lection on Laredo’s early days. 
These docum ents had been collected and saved from destruction by a li­ 

 felong historian, Seb S. 
W ilcox, long official court reporter at Laredo. 
The collection was pre­ sented to St. M ary’s in 
196o. 
‘‘F a th e r 
H abig, a 
Franciscan priest from 
Chicago, has been com ­ ing to San Antonio for re se a rc h o ver m any y e a r s ,” C arm en said. 
“ He knew of the fruitless 

 search for Palafox docu­ ments. He was here in St. 
M ary’s archive section that day working with the Laredo Archives. 
“ Suddenly I beard him cry out. He was so excit­ ed he had trouble talking. 
He kept punching down at the table beside a do­ cu m en t he held in the other hand — saying — 
‘Palafox!’ — ‘Palafox!’ 

“The miracle had hap­ pened — ‘the impossible dream ’ became a reality. 
After a century und half, here was a Spanish do­ cument on Palafox. 
Big task 
That opened the gate. 
Carmen then set to work and what a task faced her. 
She had to go through more than 13,ooo 

Scattered among those thousands of pages were about 45 docum ents on dealing with San Jose de 
Palafox. From these — with help from visits to the site by Tim Tobin and photographer Courtenay 
Wyehe Beinhorn — came 
C arm en ’s book. It was published by the St. 
Mary’s University Press in 1971. 

Though San Jo se de 
Palafox is dead — life goes on beside the Rio 
Grande. Few places are more beautiful than this part of the Rio G rande country in spring’s first stirrings. 

The little w in n o w e rs are just starting to break through in blankets of yellow or purple. And the dark of the brush is dot­ ted by the tall, cream y white blossom s of the 
Spanish dagger.

1/2 Price 
Bookcase 
Bargain! 
...cover T}i St. of wall space! 
• ••or buy singly at half price! 

Paul Broyhill called Herb and Lucille Fisher a few weeks ago and said, "I've got 32o beautiful glass shelf, lighted bookcases in the warehouse that we've got to move to make room for new merchandise. Can you take them all at half price?” 
Naturally the Fisher's said, 
"Sure, send them right rn . . . and thanks!” So three solid carloads arrived this week and we're offering them to you at half price while they last. Come and get 'em!

SOC smothers 
Burbank hopes 

J O H N B E G Z O S o f Spurs, center, p re se n ts se a so n tick­ e t s to Leonard, left, an d M e y e r, right 

PHOTO BY JOE BARRERA, JR. 
Coaches honored by peers 

Bv H A R RY PA G E 
Of t m e x p re s s n f w s s t m t 
Earl Meyer of Burbank and James Leonard of Clemens were 
' chosen by their fellow peers as the San Antonio Spurs/Ex- press-News’ 197H-77 basketball Coaches of the Year. 

John Begzos, general manager of the Spurs presented the pair with season tickets for tin' 1977-78 campaign for the dual honor. 
Meyer gained nine of a possible 4o votes to nose out Armando Balderra- ma of Kennedy-by two votes for the boys' coach's honor. 
Leonard was an overwhelming choice for the girls* mentor’s laurels. The 
47-year old Johnson City native polled 24 out of 27 votes. DeAnna Richard­ son of Ja y was runnerup with six votes. 
Other choices 

In the boys' coach balloting. Don Perkins of Judson received five votes, and Jim m y Towers of Memorial four. Newton Grimes of Lee had 34 votes. 
Ron Lloyd of Wheatley three, and Je rry Tyson of Roosevelt and Stun 
Bonewitz of St. Gerard’s, the top vote-getter of the smaller schools, each had two. Charles “ Ike” Harris of Healy-Murphy had 14 votes, and Jim 
Keener of Alamo Heights, Charlie Boucher of Edison.jmd last year's honoree. Tom Anderson of Lanier, each had one. Dan Higgins of St. 
Anthony gained a half vote. 
Eave Best of Houston and Charlene Love of Burbank each had two votes in the one-sided voting for the girls’ coach. Carolyn Taylor of Edgewood, 
Judy Barker of Lee. and Mike Tavitas of Blessed Sacrament each had one. 
Jack Autry of Holmes, along with Anderson, were the Spurs/Express- 
News’ honorees last season. John Kemmcrzehl of Highlands (boys) and 
Patti Kau of Judson (girls) were chosen during the 1974-75 campaign. 
Sadly mistaken 

“ lf you think one man — a coach or player — can win hall games, you're sadly mistaken.” said Meyer. 
“ It is a team effort. My assistants John 
Campbell and George DeLeon have played an important role in our success. Even though Gilbert (Salinas) has gotten the headlines, all the players on our team has contributed to our winning ways. Indeed. I'm grateful at being selected by my peers. The one thing I want everybody to remember is Rial this isn’t a one-man show .” 
The 33-year old St. Mary 's graduate has coached at Burbank for seven years. Meyer, who is married and one child, coached a year each ut Page and R h o d e s junior highs. 
“ I feel real honored,” said Leonard. "The key to our success is a real fine group of young ladies — they have tried to do tin* best they can at what I ve asktsi them to do. Our assistant coach, Lynn Dodge, had a lot to do with it 
— she played a big part in our season. I really don’t believe I could have done ti without her or my wife. Yvonne, who backed me all the way. We’ve tried to instill pride in our young ladies at Clemens arid it has rubbed off.” 
I/Collard coached three years at Banquette and six years at Johnson City before coming to Clemens six years ago. The Southwest Texas Slate graduate, who has three children, was an all-state Class Basketball player for Johnson City in 1947. 

By JOHN H IN ES 
O f THE EXPRESS N EW S STAFF 

AUSTIN — The Dallas jinx continued to haunt San Antonio teams at the Class AAAA state basketball tournament Friday night as South Oak Cliff elimin­ ated Burbank, HB-54. 

South Oak Cliff (34-8) will have a rematch with Fort Worth Dunbar 
(39-1) for the AAAA state champion­ ship game at 2:o5 p.m. 
Saturday. 
Dunbar downed 
Houston Westchester. 
74-88, in the first se­ mifinal Friday. 
South Cliff handed 
Dunbar its only loss, 
8o-78. 
The Class B portion of the tournament will also be held Saturday, with Leggett meeting 
Avinger at 8:3o a.rn. ll) a.rn.

HINES

 and Krum hauling Hedley at 
Finals are set for 8 p.m. 
South Oak Cliff broke the game open by scoring the first eight points of the fourth quarter, all in a span of 1:37. to take a commanding 49-39 lead w ith 5:59 left in the contest. 
Burbank was never able to get closer than eight points thereafter. 
Bulldog coach Earl Meyer empha­ sized. “ There is where we lost t he* game. They forced us to do what they do best the last few minutes, press and run. 
“ Those four straight turnovers we made in that quick span of theirs was what killed us. When you get up here, it’s a matter of mistakes. You can’t make them against the good clubs and that little span was the turning point. 
"Mentally we lest our concentration 
Tin what we were doing. For us to win we’ve got to think all the time. 
“ The whole key to'beating* these guys is that you can’t give them the layups. They hit some long shots that kept them in the game, hut actually it

Fight furor 

By M IK E BRUTON 

O f th e e x p r e s s n r w s 
ABC Sports and King Productions have been “ overruled” by the Texas Boxing 
Commission. 

Just when promoter Don King and ABC Sports executive director Boone Arledge. along with Ring 
Magazine, decided to bring a semifinal of King’s traveling boxing extravaganza to San Antonio on 
April 7, a huge barricade appeared. 
This same group is responsible for bringing a 
'quarterfinal show to Randolph Air Force Base on 
March 27. The quarterfinal show. which features six

 bouts, was originally scheduled at Hit* Lackland 
Ampitheater hut was switched to Randolph’s Han­ gar 41. 
So, what happened when they tried to bring the semifinal to San Antonio? 
Dan Shed rick, vice president of King Productions said the TB< prohibited them from having the se­ mifinal unless their system of judging tin* bouts were made consistent with tin* Texas system. 
“ We do not have a 1o-point must system.” said 
Shed rick from his New York office. “ We judge on a round by round basis." 
The TBF rules say that all professional Im iv mg matches in Texas must he judged on the 1o-point system, hut all of the bouts in King's show to this point have been grudisl round by round. 
“ I think you have to lie pragmatic about this thing.” said Shed rick “ You must have uniform

Texas roll* 
AUSTIN (AP) - Texas remained unbeaten in 
Southwest Conference baseball play Friday with a 14-1 victory over Texas 
Christian, highlighted by a seven-run seventh-in­ ning. 
Designated hitter Scott 
Soden collected three hits and four RBIs and third baseman Rocky Thomp­ son had three hits and three RBIs. It marked 
Thompson’s first game this year after being si­ delined with a broken hand. 
Texas is 17-o for the year and 7-o in league play. TCU is 11-6 and 5-2.

Trinity netters host SMU 

The Trinity men’s tennis team (12-3) will challenge Southern Methodist 
(6-1) in a dual match Saturday beginning at 2 p.m. in the Trinity Tennis 
Stadium. SMU defeated TU, 6-3. in the finals of the Corpus Christi 
Tournament last month. 
Stock car season begins 

Pan American Speedway begins its 1977 Stock Car racing season 
Saturday with more than 5o drivers set to compete in four different events. 
Gates open at 6 p.m. and the races begin at 8 p.m.

Rangers win 

ASSOCIATED PRESS 
POMPANO BECH, Flu. — Texas third baseman Toby Harrah slammed two home runs, including a tie-breaking solo shot in the seventh inning, to lift the Rangers to' a 4-3 victory over the 
American League champion New York Yankees in the exhibition opener for both clubs here Friday. 

Both of Harrah’s homers cleared the 35o-foot sign in left field. 
New York took a 2-o lead in the fourth on a single by Willie Randolph. Roy 
White’s triple down the right field line and a groundnut by Chris Chambliss. 
But Texas erupted for three runs in the last of the fourth off the second 
Yankee pitcher, Dick Tidrow. Lenny Randle led off for the Rangers with a single to right and took second on Mike Hargrove’s infield chopper. John Ellis rifled a single between short and third for one run and. after Ken Henderson fanned, Harrah drove his first homer high over the screen in left for a 3-2 Texas lead. 
The Yankes tied it in the seventh, jumping on lefty Jim Umbarger for three successive singles by Dave Bergman. Jimmy Wynn and Fran Healy. 
The Rangers untied it in the same inning when Harrah clouted his second round-trippcr. The home run made a loser of New York’s Ron Guidry. Um­ barger got the win.

Dan Cook 

Modern 'slavery’, has advantages 

Much has been said and written about slavery m aking a comeback in sports these days. To hear some professional jocks tell it one might think that Abe Lincoln made a terrible mistake, an unforgivable oversight, when he didn’t include infielders, forwards and linebackers in the Emancipation Proclamation. 
Of course, there are a few major differences between this modern form of sports* slavery and the plantation workers of a century ago. 
For one thing, the old cotton pickers couldn't take time to sign autographs, endorse shaving creams or sashay around making personal appearances. 

Fight riff 

Continued from Page IC 

 rules for the whole tournament. People are watching on TV. 
“ We’ve averaged 29 million viewers so far with this package. We can’t just change.” 
The TBC’s jurisdiction can not touch the bouts at 
Randolph, because they will be held on federal pro­ perty. But the semifinal was tentatively scheduled for the Joe Freeman Coliseum and that is in the 
Texas commission’s realm. 
“ We were all ready to go,” Shedriek commented. 
“ We had the unsigned contract for the Joe Freeman 
Coliseum. 
“ Boone Arledge. Ring Magazine and everyone involved agreed to have the semifinal there because we had a feeling that San Antonio was a great boxing tUV 
Sincere tone 
Then, in a sincere tone Shedriek said, “ I think it’s unfortunate for San Antonio. It certainly discourages us from coming to San Antonio again, or even Tex­ as.” 
Shedriek went on explain that if the semifinal show to is prohibited in San Antonio, the city stands to lose most. 
He mentioned the amount of money and exposure that would slip the Alamo city’s grasp just because of a discrepancy in judging rules. 
Shedriek also waved a pointing finger at the North 
American Boxing Federation as the cause of the problem. 
According to Shedriek, N A BF president Bob 
Charley has been openly critical of the King tourna­ ment. And TBF chairman Bob Bussey is the vice president of the NABF. 
“ The N ABF is flexing its muscles,” Shedriek said, calling the whole thing a power play. “ We question how an outside group could influence the decision of the Texas Commission." 
Shedriek also said United States Boxing Commis­ sion chairman James A. Farley had spoken to Bus­ sey but no ground was gained on the issue. 
The TBF still insists that the judging rules be changed and King Productions and ABC Sports say they’ll take their business elsewhere before any changes will lie made. 
Problem 
However, the problem is being examined by the 
Texas legislature and there is still a possibility that a compromise can be found. 
“ I respect Bob Bussey,” said Shedriek. “ I have no quarrel with him as an individual and King Pro­ ductions have no quarrel with anyone. We’re trying to bring Poxing up by its bootstraps. 
"Our package benefits boxing. We’re providing the money arid the exposure. We're featuring smaller weight classes to try and give more people a chance to earn a- paycheck. In the past. all the at­ tention has been on the heavyweights.” 

For another, there wasn’t any "off­ season” around the plantations. 

About the only edge the real slaves had over this modern crop of athletes was a total lack of concern about tax collectors. They didn't sit around each 
April 15 worrying over mounds of pa­ perwork. 

Of course, this whole idea for screaming slavery while becoming fa­ mous and rich for spending half a year playing a game is designed to fetch public sympathy. The designers, how­ ever, give little credit to the mentality of the general public. 
For some reason or other this is re­ mindful of the dumbo who was at­ tracted by an advertisement that of­ fered a Carrlboan cruise for just $5o. 

Moments after the ancient boat limped to sea the tourist was clamped in chains, taken below and seated with one of those huge oars in his hand. He and about 5o others began to stroke their oars to the rhythm of a single drummer. Another dummy, sitting across from him. noticed the puzzled look on our hero’s face after half an hour. “ What's the problem?” The new recruit pulled on his oar and answered, 
“ I was Just wondering, when this trip is over, should we tip the drummer?” 
The guy across from him replied, “ I think it must be included because we sure didn't tip him last year.” 

Another modern form of slavery? 
Who knows? Maybe they enjoyed the trip and needed the exercise. 

High price tags 

At this moment more than a dozen baseball players are holding out. as usual, for more money. Nothing wrong 
* with this because in our free enterprise the idea is to get as much as w e can for our services. 

Pete Rose is angry because the Cin­ cinnati Reds won’t give him $74o,ooo a season on a three-season contract. Joe 
Morgan, we understaNd, has already signed for that amount but Joe hap­ pens to be two years younger than 
Pete. Besides, Joe doesn’t get all those 
TV commercials that Rose does but that's a matter only slightly related to a player's worth to his team. 

Anyone who follows professional sports must have at least a slight opinion on this subject. 
From here it seems that there aren’t more than three* athletes in the world worth half a million a season. O.J. 
Simpson might be one and I can't think ti! Un* other two. Of course. Simpson wakes more money running through airports before TV cameras than he docs running around linebackers. 

The last solid players’ objection, the parallel with slavery, reverts to choice of teams, not the size of checks. As long as one person works for another there shall always be discomfort, to say the least, about short wages. Pro athletes miffed because they have ne say in which club they play for, which city they live. 

 r i'm t i r e d o e 
, Till 
BEINS- • A S L A V E R / a 

WHEELER TIRE SERVICE 
824-4517 
4 3 o 7 B r o a d w a y a t H i l d e b r a n d 

Traded and sold like slaves, they claim. Ah. if this be slavery wouldn’t we all love to bt* in such bondage? 
The slave merchants meet once a year to draft the "fresh meat” coming out of colleges and then they spend days bickering and dickering among themselves, making trades here and there. 

. . -•*>- 

The wise old “ slaves” long ago learned of escape valves. Insiders call it the “ Flap Yap for Flip Flop.” Ifs simple. You Just hassle with your owner or manager long enough and loud enough, flapping your yap each time a reporter comes near and, sooner or later, the flip flop will occur. 
Trade winds will whack you right in the rear. 

How do you suppose Joe Morgan got from Houston to Cincinnati? He got there the same way Bill Madloek re­ cently got to the west coast from Chi­ cago. Pour enough verbal steam up the boss’ tail and he’ll get you a transfer. 
Of course, that act can be habit forming. Dick Allen has been in more baseball camps than adhesive tape and now, finally, he’s beginning to check over his pension papers. Most owners had rather have athlete’s foot. 

History helps 

Presidents, not athletes, usually look to history for passing grades. But his­ tory has proved that pro athletes were, for many years, getting the short end of the sticks opposed to team owners. 

In the last 15 years player salaries have doubled and almost tripled and food and travel expenses have almost doubled. Yet, the cost of admission tickets have climbed only 26 percent in most cases and total gate receipts are up only 22 percent on the general average. 

But you don’t see any team owners bailing out, selling, running for cover. 
This tells me that for the better part of 49 years team owners shafted their players in the salary department. Now the players are taking their turns and common sense and mercy are foreign words. 

To my way of thinking ifs unfortun­ ate that unions are sometimes neces­ sary but it all boils down to one key word, fairness. And which side is unfair? That's easy. Whichever side has the better chance to be unfair. 

Regardless of whether we’re dealing with individuals or groups, human na­ ture seldom changes. Give a guy a hammer and chances are good that he ll use it some day. No. this isn’t to say that basically we’re all unfair. But we do tend to sin* things the way that we d most like to have them seen. 
Astros rom p 

COCOA, Fla. (A P )—Cliff Johnson hit a three-run home run Friday as the 
Houston Astros defeated the Montreal. 
Expos, 8-5, in a game in which the’ 
Astros collected eight stolen bases. 
It was the first exhibition game of the season for both teams 
Johnson, playing in the outfield although carried on the roster as a catcher, overcame a 2-U Montreal lead in the bottom of the first with his 
41o-foot wind-ussisted home run over the Centerfield fence. 

Tony Perez, formerly with the Cin­ cinnati Reds, had a fifth inning home run for Montreal. 
Dan Larson, the second of three 
Houston pitchers, was the winner as the Astros took ll hits off three Mon­ treal pitchers. Dan Warthen was the loser.

O utdoors 

 w i t h D a n K i p p e r 

Sport fisherm en are losers again 

Hog coach gathers fans 

The rew ritin g of the Red 
Drum Conservation Aet by the. b ill’s sp onsor, 
Sen. 
A. 
R. 
Schwartz of Galveston, was not unexpected. Many sport fisher­ men anticipated major changes would be made in the proposal, changes which would be detri­ mental to the redfish of Texas. 

And that is exactly what has hap­ pened. The senate bill, num ber 824, was approved by the com m ittee on natural resources last Wednesday and might com e before the lull senate 
March 21. 
What started out as a real conserva­ tion measure, one which would estab­ lish realistic limits on the daily sport and com m ercial catch es of redfish from the bays, has emerged as a pro­ commercial law which would have lit­ tle or no immediate affect on catches and, in the long run, could be disas trous. 

A number of sections were deleted from the b ill. One m ission section would have increased the mesh size of nets, thus permitting small redfish to escape. Another would have prohibited a fish dealer from buying more than 
IOO pounds of redfish per days from any one person. 

The most dam aging change is the 
(junta system the m easure would es­ tablish. The daily bag limit system would Ik* in effect only during the lat­ ter part of this year. 
Beginning next year, the bill would set up a quota system for the com ­ m ercial harvest of redfish, with the quotas determ ined by averaging the commercial catches reported for tilt 
1971-72 through 75-76 seasons. 
These are, as sport fishermen might have guessed, the five years with the highest catches on record. 

A locked in quota 

Q uotas b ased on th e se y e a rs wouldn’t reduce the annual harvest even a little bit. In addition, the re­ porting of catches would be based on an honor system. 
A ll the Texas P ark s and Wildlife 
Department could do would be to ac­ cept figures on reported catches and hope they were correct. 
The bill would enable the d e p a rt­ ment to close a bay to com m ercial 

 fishing at any tim e the com m ercial catch approached 9o per cent of the allow able, but even this curbing clause has a drawback. 

“Even if all catches were reported, there is a five-day lag in data reporting and a 2o-day lag before the commission could close a bay,” a spokesman for the department said. This would mean that when that 9o per cent figure was reached, fishing would continue for nearly a month before the bay could be closed. 

But the major damage would be the locked in quota, a quota based on the five highest years of catches. There is no provision in the bill to permit re­ duction of the quota once it is estab­ lished . . . except, of course, through legislative procedure. 
And, since it is that same procedure which has gotten us into this mess, I, for one, don’t put much faith in it get­ ting us out. 
The bill, as rew ritten , should be killed. That, at least, would be a step toward conservation of the redfish on the Texas coast. 
Saturday short shots 

M em b ers of the T ex as T rophy 
Hunters Association are gearing up for the second annual conference of the organization. The conferernce is set for March 26 in the Convention Center in San Antonio. 
TTHA m em bers will exhibit white- tails killed last season and will com ­ pete for the Best Buck aw ard. The w in ner will receiv e a K-14 Klein- guenther rifle. 
There will be special awards for the most points and widest spread. Films and speakers will be featured during the day-long conference. Tickets to the meeting are $7.5o for m em bers and $1o for guests. 
★ ★ ★ 
The Bird Dog and Quail Club of San 
Antonio will hold its spring field trial on the Pandora Gam e M anagem ent 
Area March 19, 2o and 21. 

Trial headquarters will be at Union 
Valley. Judges will be F. M. Dyke of 
San Antonio and Fred Maass of Pflu­ gerville. 

Stakes will include am ateur all age, amateur derby, am ateur shooting dog, amateur puppy and open shooting dog. 
Spectators will be welcome to attend. 
Horses are recommended if, watching the trial is desired. 

ASSOCIATED PRESS 
LITTLE ROCK - Arkansas 
Coach Eddie Sutton and Kansas 
State Coach Jack Hartman have made a deal for the NCAA bas­ ketball tournament, but no in­ vestigation is needed. 

Sutton says he is encouraging UA fans to cheer for Kansas State, in re­ turn. Hartman will urge K-State fans to support Sutton’s Razorbacks. 
Arkansas plays Wake Forest Satur­ day night in the first round of the 
NCAA tournament at Norman, Okla., 

 and Kansas State plays Providence in the second game. 
“ If our fans and Kansas State's fans get together, it will be like playing at home,” Sutton said. 

Arkansas, winner of 18 straight, is 
26-1 for the season and ranked No. 8 in the country. Wake Forest was 2o-3 a few weeks back, but lost its last four games. 

“ We’ve got a tough one. but if we can get by W ake F o re s t, w e ’ve got a change to beat any of them,” Sutton said. “ Of course, with a good game, any of them can beat us.” 
Sutton says the Deacons are better 

 than any team Arkansas has faced this year. That includes Houston, Memphis 
State and Kansas State. 

“ They had the Atlantic Coast Cnfer- ence won.” he said. “ All they needed was a win at home, but they lost to 
Maryland by one and to North Carolina 
State by six and wound up in a tie for second. They beat N orth C aro lin a twice. 
“ T hey're a great shooting te a m ,” 
Sutton said. “ I feel we’re about equal. 
Their strength is in their fast break. 
They like to attack with the ball. If we can contain their break, we can beat them. They play good defense, like us, 

 and they change th eir d efen ses on you." 
Sutton says Wake Forest guard Skip 
Brown and ACC Player of the YejJfRod 
Griffin are excellent players and* lh at forward Jerry Schellenberg is a “ great outside shooter.” Sutton calls Griffin the “ best power forward in College basked thai I.” 
Arkansas is the highest-rated teaam in the eight-team Midwest Regional. 
In other Midwest Regional gam es, 
Cincinnati will play M arquette and 
Southern Illinois meets Arizona. 
“ Anything else we get will bd & bon­ us," Sutton said. “ W e're a year ahead of what I thought we d be.”

S ophom ore right-hander Mark Ross hurled a one-hit shutout to pace the Texas Aggies to a 4-o Southwest Con­ ference baseball victory over Southern Methodist 
Friday. 
Ross went the full nine innings in recording his fifth victory of the year against no lossxes. 
Senior rig h t-h a n d e r 
Jim Beard was charged with the loss for the 
Ponies. He is now 2-3.

Mike Hurdle, leftfielder 
R obert 
V erde, designated h itte r Tim 
Feickert.

15-6 for the year and 5-2 in conference play. SMU is 3-8 and o-7.

 was layups that beat us. 
“ They have a real good point man 
(Cullen Mayfield) who hurt us. Gilbert 
(Salinas) had to take him when he drove in and he would pass to the wings behind Gilbert for the layups. 
Meyer speaks 

“ The main thing we had to do was break their press and make them play half court. We didn’t beat the press consistently enough. 
“ I thought we played our bes*, at the beginning of the game, when we were moving well. 
“ I thought Gilbert needed to touch the ball more. We didn t get him the ball enough, especially against the zone. We were moving on the peri­ meter too much and not penetrating.” 
Burbank had its biggest lead of the game at 16-12 on a three-point play by 
Gilbert Salinas with 55 seconds left in the opening quarter. 
Press works 

However, with the aid of the press. 
South Oak Cliff fought back to tie the score at the end of the quarter. 
That outburst typlifled the first three periods, when the lead changed hands eight times and was tied on nine other occasions. 
Burbank took a 31-29 lead at halftime as Salinas hit two buckets in the last 
4o seconds before the break. 
South Oak Cliff took a pair of four point leads in the third period, during which time they posted a 12-8 margin on the Bulldogs. 
Then came the decisive fourth quarter in which the Bears had a 25-15 bulge. 
Ernest Puente led Burbank with 16 points, followed by Salinas with 15. although the* latter drew a blank in the last quarter. 
Still, I he 6-11 star capped his career with 2,2o2 points, leaving an all-time 
Rockets soar 

IN D IA N A P O LIS (AF*) — Rudy Tomjanovieh scored 13 points in the last six minutes of play to lead the Houston Rockets to a 124-1o9 victory Friday over Indiana in the National Basketball Association. 
Tomjanovieh finished the game with 27 points to lead all scorers. 
The victory was the sixth straight for the Rockets.

Nuggets.

TSU advances 

KANSAS C IT Y (A P ) — Alonzo Bradley and 
Lawrence Williams combined for 42 points Friday night us Texas Southern put on a strong second half performance to defeat Grand Valley State of Michi­ gan 69-62 in the opening semifinal game of the NA1A 
Basketball Tournament. 
In the second semifinal game. Campbell. N.C., defeated Henderson State. Ark., 76-52. Texas 
Southern and Campbell will play for the champion­ ship Saturday night, beginning at 8 p.m.

Leonard Lambert added 12 points and settled down defensively after picking up three fouls in the first five minutes.

Puente.

SAN DY STAP returns serve 

PHOTO BY STEVE CAM PBEII 
Trinity ferns stop Lamar 

Trinity’s women’s tennis team hiked its dual match to 2-o by beating stubborn 
Lamar, 7-2, Friday afternoon at Trinity. 

Sandy Slap got things started for Trinity by beat­ ing Maria Hill, 6-1, 6-o, in the number one singles. 
Trinity won the next four singles as Carrie Fleming downed Susan Pridham, 6-2, 6-2; Staey Bowman outclassed Liz Smith, 6-o, 6-2; Ann Sehroeder tripped 
Lynn Koth, 6-1, 6-4; and Shelly Hudson defeated 
Leslie (’arson, 6-1, 6-3. Dru Ann Musehlian, however, surprised Trinity’s Kerry Sterling, 6-2. 4-6, 6-4. 
In doubles. Stap and Fleming beat Carson and 
Koth, 6-2. 7-5; Sehroeder and Hudson downed Smith and Pridham, 6-o. 4-6, 7-6 (5-4 in tie-breaker); and 
Lamar's Hill and Musehlian tripped Bowman and 
Sterling, 6-4, 6-2. 
Trinity’s next match is against Brigham Young at 
IO a m. Monday at Trinity. 

Probe clears 
Monroe 

N EW YO RK (A P ) - 
The National Basketball 
Association said Friday night an investigation had cleared Earl Monroe of the New York Knieks of any wrong-doing in a last-second shot into the wrong basket Thursday night. 
Monroe’s shot at the buzzer didn't affect the outcome, since the 
Knieks defeated the 
Portland Trail Blazers 
1o8-1o4. However, the 
Knieks were ahead 
1o8-1o2 until Monroe’s jump shot from the corner. 
Favorites 
They also were six- point favorites, and ther­ ein lies the reason for the investigation. 
Monroe’s wrong-way shot brought forth a sound described as so­ mething between a roar and a loud moan from the 
Madison Square Garden crowd of 14,527. Those who wagered on the 
Knieks as six-point fa­ vorites lost their bets. 
Had the Knieks won by six, all bets would have been canceled. 

The N BA announced 
Friday it had begun an investigation “ under in­ structions from Commis­ sioner (Larry) O’Brien.” 
Film 
Frid ay night, the league said O’Brien and 
Deputy Com missioner 
Simon Gourd inc had re­ viewed the game film and league officials had interviewed Monroe. 

The 
N BA called 
Monroe’s shot “ a spur- of-the-moment’’ and 
“ unprem editated” act and said the K n iek s’ guard described his shot as a “ whim.” 
“ I forgot which end of the court I was on,” was 
Monroe’s explanation. 
Later, he said, “ I thought the game was over.” 

The incident came on the heels of an NBA in- vestigation into printed rumors that some of its games are being fixed. 
Conteh to fight 

P A R IS (A P ) - John 
Conteh of Britain, the 
World Boxing Council light-heavyweight cham­ pion, is expected to make his next title defense against 
Argentine challenger Miguel Angel 
Cuello.

Continued from Page IC 

Greg Adams in a bantamweight quarterfinal. 
San Antonio’s Felix Castillo lost a decision to Handy Garza, of Wichita Falls in the flyweight class and four other local boxers followed suit in their respective classes. 
The other area fighters who were eliminated are 1976 welter­ weight finalist Alejo Rodriguez, middleweight Derly Cirlos, light heavyweight Manuel Garcia and featherweight Juan Rodriguez, of Eagle Pass. 
All of the San ?\ntonio boxers were beaten on points except 
G arcia, who was T K O ’ d by 
T v e r ’s William Marshall in the second round.

99 (PG) 

By RON WHITE 

Anyone who’s had a fantasy about effortlessly leaving his or her spouse to run off with someone else is likely to enjoy 
“ Cousin, Cousine.” 
It is a romantic fantasy given a sort of semi-doc- tumentary look of rea­ lism by Jean-Charles 
Tachella’s script and 

R j e v i e w 

 direction. The style of the film at the Northwest Six is, in fact, more appealing than the sub­ stance; it is a thin gruel heavily spiced. 
“ Cousin, 
Cousine” 
(male cousin, female cousin) is about-Marthe and Ludovic, a woman and man distantly relat­ ed to each other by marriage. They meet at family weddings, funer­ als and birthday parties, and while their spouses are sneaking off to the woods for hurried, guilty grappling, Marthe and 
Ludovic strike up a plea­ sant, innocent friend­ ship.

Romano Haza 

MARIE-CHRIST1NE 
BARRAULT 
. . . star of film ,.. 

Friendship slowly grows into love altlf?!|igh at first it is more an af­ fair of the stomach than of the heart as Marthe and Ludovic delight in raiding pastry shops to indulge themselves in one of their common passions, eating. 
Platonic 
While their spouses* 
Pascal and Karine, are having a passionate* quickie affair, Marthe and Lucdovic embark on a leisurely, platonic rela-. tionship. They indulge in minor revenges upon their mates. Marthe buys 
Ludovic the kind of loud necktie Karine hates, and 
Ludovic buys Marthe the type of floppy hat Pascal despises. 
At one point they en- ision their relationship remaining platonic the rest of their lives. If they do not sleep together, not only will they have’.no reason to apologize, hut they will amaze thiJt; fa ­ mily. “ We’ll be extraor­ dinary if only welslay that way.” 
And if Marthe and Lu­ dovic had staged that way, “ Cousin. Cousine,” might have been an ex­ traordinary film. But when Marthe’s and L u* dovic’s affair progresses into a sexual one — ail is perhaps inevitable, realistically 
— tlfen 
‘Cousin, Cousine’’ be­ comes a commonplace fairy tale. 
No conflict I 
It is a fantasy becasse 
‘Cousin, Cousine” vio­ lates one of the bajiic tenets of the storyteller’s 
ART: there is no substan­ tial conflict anywhere in the film. mJ 
The cards are stacked in favor of a happy, healthy adultery. The most obvious set-up is 
Karine’s and Pascal’s series of affairs that jus­ tify Marthe’s and Ludo- vic’s own infidelity. But even giving the film that situation as one fre­ quently found in reality, 
“ Cousin. Cousine" still makes it too easy for 
Marthe and Ludovic to live happily ever after. 
When their affair is in full bloom, the couple spend a family Christ­ mas celebration locked in a bedroom while the rest of the family is a only slightly agog at their go­ ings-on. Karine plays at slashing her wrists, but it is only play; when she accidentally nicks her finger, she abandons the idea. 
When Marthe and Lu­ dovic emerge from the bedroom, they announce to the others they’re leaving together. Martha kisses her young son goodby and the scene is presented with no mort) trauma than if his mother were going to the grocery store. 
No guilt 
The film is obviously iii praise of following one s own inclinations and passions without guilt, which is in itself lauda­ ble. But the film is der ceptive in that it suggests guiltlessness comes so easily. lf one w ants to act cpl 
“ Cousin. Cousine” as the fantasy it is, there are moments to enjoy in the film. 
The performances by 
Marie-Chnstine Barrault and Victor Lanoux as 
Marthe and Ludovic are pleasant and convincing. 
They are both slightly over-weight, not that clever or attractive, and their flaws add a sense of realism to the fantasy. ;• 
Guy Marchand is funny as Pascal, particularly when renouncing his string of girl friends and as he becomes the family drunk. 
Georges Lendl's phto- togruphy and 
Agues 
Guillemot s editing — capturing natural light­ ing and creating a frag­ mentary, haphazard narrative — are reminis­ cent of the fragments of life contained in home movies, a concept that reinforces the motif of the family that runs through the movie. 
"Cousin, Cousine" is rated it undoubtedly fur some nudity that is pre­ sented with a minimum of passion and a maxi­ mum of wholesomely#^.

R iv e r to tu r n g re e n 

Anyone interested in* seeing a river turn bright green in the course of an afternoon should be at the north floodgate on the 
San Antonio River at I p.m. Sunday. 
You should also be there if your name Is an­ ything like O’Riley or. 
Shaunessy. 
For the ninth year, the riv er w ill be colored bright green in honor of 

Rio 
Ram blings 

St. Patrick’s Day, which is Thursday. 

The idea was conceived, by the association in 
1969, when 
Robert 
L. 
Frazer was director of 
Parks and Recreation. 

Since all activities in the Riverwalk Park have to have the approval of the park director, Frazer was called about the idea. 

F ra z e r rem in isced about the call at this week’s River Walk Ad­ visory 
C om m ission meeting. 

He remembered think­ ing of the possibilities of stained boat bottoms and the extensive testing that ensued to assure the sa­ fety of the dye product. 

The “ river dyeing” has since been written about in - m ag azin es and newspapers around the country. 
The St. P atrick’s river dyeing barge parade will begin at the north flood gaie and proceed to the 
Arneson R iver Theater, where an entertainm ent program is planned. 

★ Ar ★ 

River Square Market place will be the host to an exhibit by artists from the Mission Art Group this weekend. 
Along with the show, there will be demonstra tions of techniques in se­ veral m edia including sand painting, macram e and transfer art. 
On March 26 and 27 more than 125 paintings by members of the High­ land Art Group will be disp layed at 
R iv er 
Square. 
River Square is located at the co rn er of Com ­ merce and Presa Streets.

MIAMI — Andy Bean, who has a half-deserved reputation as an alligator-wrestler, splashed nine “ 3’s” across his card, composed a errorless, five-under-par 67 and stretched his lead to two strokes 
Friday in the second round of the $2oo,ooo Doral Open Golf 
Tournament. 
"It’s exaggerated,” the 
B-foot-4, 2o5-pound Bean said of his a llig a to r wrestling exploits during the PGA Tour qualifying school less than two years ago. 
Without exaggeration, however, his effort over the w indy, cloudy, 
7,oo5-yard Blue Monster course at the 
Doral 
Country Club ranked as near-perfect, lie didn't even come close to mak­ ing a bogey, hit every fairway and every green. 
Solid 
"A pretty solid round," 
Bean said of his second consecutive five-under- par score that gave him a 
3o-hole total of 134. 
"I just hope I get an­ oth er one to m o rro w ,” said Bean, who will cele­ brate his 24th birthday du rin g S u n d a y ’s final round. “ A win would be a p retty good birth d ay present," said the hard­ hittin g U n iversity of 
F lo rid a pro d u ct who h a s n ’t finished higher than fourth in his brief professional career.

13o total. Ziegler credited his no-bogey, second round o7 to continued lessons from his close friend, form er M asters and PGA champion Dong 
Ford.

A greener lawn is what you’ll notice first— usually within IO to 14 days aftei we first spray your lawn. 
It will be greener because it is healthier. Greener because a-Perm-o-Green's nutrients are promoting a deep root system and strong stems and blades. 
You’ll notice something else tex), no chinch bug or grub worm problems because a-Perm-o-Green applies the correct insecticide at the right time— before damage is done. 
Join the thousands who are enjoying greener, healthier lawns thanks to a-Perm-o-Green applica­ tions last year. Your satisfaction is assured or you don’t owe us a cent. 

Why is a-Perm-o-Green so effective? 

Your lawn :s sprayed w ith liquid fertilizer specially prepared by a-Perm-o-Green to meet current soil, temperature and moisture conditions. 
Nutritional elements plus nitrogen, phosphorus and potassium are seasonally adjusted to promote the growth most beneficial at the time of application. 
Research proves that proper nutrition— rather than the soil itself— makes the difference between success and failure in creating a beautiful lawn. And creating beautiful lawns is what a-Perm-o-Green is all about. 

Average Cost? Less than $2o per application. 

Seems amazingly low, but a-Perm-a-Green is able to buy fertilizers and insecticides in quantity and pass the savings on to you. The average size lawn really 

 does average less than $2o per application— about the same as if you bought materials and applied them yourself (not counting the trips you’d make to the fertilizer store, the time and gamble over the correct mix to use. and the spreader equipment you’d have to rent or buy!) 

When do you join the program? Now! 

Over the next few weeks our lawn care profes­ sionals will take the a-Perm-o-Green trucks out to spray this year’s first treatments on lawns throughout this area. 
Make sure your home is one of our first stops Call us right now! r a-Perm-o-Green 
Lawn Spraying Schedule 

Spring: Balance** application in­ clude* nitrogen, phosphorus, potassium and Micro-Nutrients to give yow lawn a strong, green leaf and stem. 
Early Summer: Another bal­ anced application of fertilizers pius insec ticides for control of grub worms, chinch bugs, and other pests. 
Summer: Hot weather nutrients in seasonally balanced applica­ tion plus Inaacticidcs aimed al second generation chinch bugs. 

F all: Essential nutrients plus a winterizing application lo pro­ mote deep root growth and a helpful fungicide.

HOME CARE OFTEN CHEERS THE ELDERLY WHEN ILL 
H om em akers Upjohn offers a choice in medical care 

Home health care cuts recovery cost 

EXPRESS NEW S 
Scene 

March I 2 1977 
Page 
I -D 

By LOIS HAASE 
Medical costs keep spiraling until serious illness many times becomes a two-fold crisis — emotional and financial. 
“ Families need to take a careful look at th e ir co v era g e for m ed ical e x ­ penses,” Charlotte Anzalone, director of consumer affairs for Homemakers 
Upjohn says. “ Hospitalization costs can financially wreck a family. Home health care is an alternate plan for illnesses that do not req u ire e m e r­ gency or diagnostic equipment.” 
The national d irecto r was in San 
Antonio from her home office in Kala­ mazoo, Mich., to spotlight the local office of Homemakers Upjohn in our city. Many San Antonians are unaware of this optional professional health care service in the home. 
In fact. San Antonio has three dif­ ferent services available. A H om e­ m aker-H om e Health Aid Service is available to keep the home and family functioning on a temporary basis. 
The V isiting N u rses'o ffers reg is­ tered, p ractical nurses and n u rse ’s aides — also on a limited basis. 
And Homem akers Upjohn is a pri­ vate agency offering licensed person­ nel as hom em akers and health care workers. They are available on 24 hour or part-time schedules to work around family mem bers caring for a patient. 
Patients convalescing, who need rest 

CHARLOTTE ANZALONE 

 and personal care more than actual medical treatments, often recover as well at home. Paying a large hospital room rain which includes the cost of emergency and life-susiaimng equip­ ment may be a senseless expense. 
Since many insurance policies and legislation force patients to be hospita­ lized in order to receive payment, medical and insurance costs keep ris­ ing 
“ We offer the public a choice.” Mrs. 
Anzalone savs. “ We believe there 

 should be an option on the type medical care you want or need. 
“The public also needs to express their opinion on insurance and federal medical program s. If more people insisted on coverages for home health care service, medical and insurance costs could be held down.” 
Often a mother stays in the hospital because she isn’t able to care for lier family at home. With homemaking help, she could return home. A savings would be made and she will be happier with her family. But if insurance doesn’t cover home care, she may be forced to stay there for financial rea­ sons. 
About six states so far have made legislative moves to make home health care possible under insurance and federal plans. Texas is not one of these. 
Unaware 
“ I’m always amazed when I travel,” 
Mrs. Anzalone says. “ Many doctors and others in the medical field seem to be unaware of community resources for home health care. Hospitals are slowly adding discharge planners or coordinators who work with the doctor, patient and patient’s family. 
“ Of course planning assessment of the home care program is vital. Spe­ cial equipment and reliable qualified personnel must be lined up before a move is m ade.” 
Often the elderly or terminally ill can be cared for at home. They are content 

 and happier than in an institution. But without proper care, this is impossible. 
This is where Homemakers is ready to step in. Thev have part-tim e or full-time proiessionai or semi-profes­ sional help with a plan tailored to fit individual needs. Sometimes only night care is needed. Another family may need day care only. 
“ Homemakers Upjohn at 1222 North 
Main Avenue is a subsidiary of Upjohn 
Pharmacy wljich has been in the Peo- ple-care business for IOO years,” she says. 

Rethink 
“ We think health care insurance needs to rethink the general overall program and come up with better ser­ vice for consumers who could use home health care,” Mrs. Anzalone says. 
“The federal government is studying 
Medicare and Medicaid coverage — perhaps changes will be made in this arna.” 
P re se n tly h o m e-care p ro g ra m s which are for-profit are not covered by 
Medicare and Medicaid in Texas. 
The Homemakers idea is one tha* stands for good quality care — but without institution prices. 
“ We’re not saying hospitals are not needed,” Mrs. Anzalone says 
“ Of course, they are the only answer to many medical and health problems. 
But what we are saying is that for some health problems there is an alternate plan." 
Farrier s job is shoe-in 

FROST BROS. 

7217 &ourvF*ejcttu&- 
3*1 * 214 - 1’ 
TWO BLOCKS SOUTH OS CINTRA!. PARK MALL______ 

 weighs 2o5 pounds. He played football for John Marshall Sen­ ior High until a neck injury ended his football career. 
“ It helps to be strong when you have a 1,3oo pound horse fighting you,” he said. 
There is a one-fourth inch wall around the edge of a horse’s hoof. The furrier fas­ tens the shoe to the hoof by driving nails into this wall. 
Scott drives the nail up to two inches into the hoof, clinches it and rasps it down. He cannot shoe horses after dark because he needs good light to level the hoof and Hue up the nails. 

Vt est Texas 

Scott started learning to shoe horses at age 9. His uncle who owns a ranch in West Texas taught him. Scott, in turn, is te a c h in g the tra d e to his brother. Norman, a student at 
John Marshall Senior High. 
“ One of the hardest things is learning to shape the shoe to fit the horse’s foot. Each foot is a different size and shape,” Scott said. 
People who ride in parades often have Scott mount barium, a porous metal, on the horse shoe so it will dig into the pavem en t. R a n c h e rs s o m e ­ tim e s want cork on h o r s e s ’ shoes to improve performance. 
Scott operates his mobile bu­ siness from a truck. His vehicle is loaded with about 3(Hl pounds of horseshoes, anvil and tools, ready to make house calls. 
The truck also has a CB radio which Scott uses to get direc­ tion to horse owners’ ranches. 
Every day Scott drives about 
2<MI miles. 
2o minutes 
Although his fee is the same for every horse, the time re­ quired to shoe a horse is not always the same. It takes Scott from a minimum of 2(1 minutes to shoe a good horse up to one and a half hours to shoe a bad one. 
Scott owns a quarter horse. 
Top Deck Dexter, of the Top 
Deck blood line. 
Scott will complete his agri­ culture courses at San Antonio 
College this spring and go to 
Southwest Texas State Univer­ sity this fall to major in animal husbandry. After graduation, he hopes to get a job with the fire department.

Central Park Mall and 
F ro stin g C re a to rs are presenting their second annual cake show at the mall. The show ends Sa­ turday. 
More than KIO entries are fe a tu red and a re competing in five cate­ gories including holiday, 
Easter, novelty, wedding and a n n iv e rs a ry , and special techniques. 
Demonstrations of gum

Yolanda H ernandez at

 paste flowers, marzipan molding, figure pip and creativity with chocolate arc being featured 
The public is im ited tu vote tor their favorite cake entry.

BACK WRAP SKIRT 

SPECIAL 

SOLIDS & PRINTS

1 DACRON & COTTON 
ONE SIZE FITS ALL 
COMPARE AT $16.oo 

Bv EDNA MCGAFFEY 

One who shoes a horse is not a blacksmith. He is a farrier. A blacksmith fashions iron. 

Scott Overlcy, who is work­ ing his way through San An­ tonio College shoeing horses, brought me up-to-date on this. 
“There used to be four or five 

 farriers in this area. Now there are about 2o.” Scott said. 
The horse population is in­ creasin g anti m ore men are becom ing f a rr ie r s , he e x ­ plained. 
“ The young men work part time. It’s a hard way to earn a living, but great for working your way thro u g h sc h o o l.” 
Scott believes. 
Business is inconsistent. It’s brisk prior to the San Antonio 
Stock Show and during the 

 summer, but slow during bad weather, he said. 
Ranchers 
Locally, Scott shoes mostly pleasure horses. Out from town he works for ranchers. 
“ It’s unbelievable how' strong horses are! You have to know what you’re doing,” he said. 
Every now and then he gets kicked, but one gets good at staying out of the way, he said. 
Scott is 6 ft. 2 inches and 

SCOTT OVERLEY WORKS HIS W A Y THROUGH COLLEGE 
...shoeing horses is a good p art-tim e trade ^ o »v urn camail' 

SHOW 

MR. JACK 

Rushing to marry a mistake 

Dear Ann Landers: 
Ten years ago when I was 2o, all my friends were getting married. I was afraid i’d be an old maid so I said yes to a guy I'd known for two months. 
Rod was very sexy and 
I was dumb enough to think the thrill would last forever. 
We had a baby ll months later. Then the fights sta rte d . We a r ­ gued about everything from how to celebrate holidays to how clothes should hang in the closet. 
It wasn’t long before 
Rod suggested swinging with another couple. It was very exciting, so we joined a club and contin­ ued to swing with two and three couples at a time. 
The tro ub le sta rted when Rod fell for one of the women. I didn’t care for her husband and he didn’t like me. 
Rod refused to give this woman up and I re­ fused to have anything to do with her husband. So the fight was on. Now our marriage is a mess. 
We have no respect for each other. We stay to­ gether because I’m not trained to work outside the home and I have a nine-year-old to raise. 
I am not asking for advice, Ann. I just hope you will print this letter. 
Perhaps it will prevent some other young girl from rushing into m ar­ riage with a stranger. It was the m istak e that ruined my life. — Only 
3o And All Fouled Up 
Dear 3o: 
Here's your letter — and a sad one it is. T h irty is aw fully young to write your life off. Get some counseling and investigate the op­ tions. (There are many.) 
I wish you luck. 
Party 

Dear Ann Landers. I’m 
15 and very respectable 
Last Friday I met this boy at a party. We liked each other at first sight and he asked if he could drive me home 
Two other couples piled into the car and suggest­ ed we go for a ride. The moon was full, so Ted 
(my new friend) decided to park for a while. He kissed m e five or six times. 
One of the girls in the back seat, it turns out, has a very big mouth. She spread it all over school the next day that Ted and 
I were making out like crazy. I say five or six kisses is not “ making out dike crazy." 
How m any kisses should lie exchanged be­ fore a girl can Im* right­ fully accused of making 

 i i rn 
Dr. 
Raymond 
1 ^ * * 
Moody, a philosopher and physician, delving deeply into the question in the forefront of man's mind since his existence, analyzes case histories of persons who have been pronounced clinically dead. 
He finds an amazing coincidence in their accounts of leaving their physical bodies with an aw areness of at­ tempts to keep them alive, encounters with a "being of light" who reviews their lives in a panoramic montage, and their "coming back" to the mortal world . . . 
CONTINUES IN THE NEWS 

Landers 

 nut like crazy? — 
Still 
Decent 

Dear Still: You might as well ask me how many angels can dance on the head of a pin. A girl who hands out am m unition has no right to complain when she gets shot. Cool it, kiddo. 
Common sense 

Dear Ann Landers: 
I know you don’t specialize in etiquette, but you have common sense and that's what I need. 
My grandparents are giving Rob and me a substantial sum of money as a wedding gift. We’ve been told the check is in the mail. 
Rob’s m other says a check should never be displayed with the gifts. 
My m o th er th in k s we should display only the envelope. What do you say? — Bethesda, Md. 

Dear Beth: To display a check would be vulgar. 
To display an empty en­ velope makes no sense. 
You could, however, tell friends and relatives that your grandparents gave you a lovely check — and skip the amount.

San Antonio EX P R ESS-N EW S— 
Saturday March I 2 I 977 

Jogging good for women of all ages 

S. C. McAdams gets a shoe shine from M ary Paveglio during a fashion preview of Johnston and Murphy shoes for men at Sid 

Robbins Clothes. 
PHOTO BY RON JON IS 

D EA R DR. LA M B - I would like to know if jogging is a good recom­ mended exercise for wo­ man as well as men? A friend told me it wasn’t good for women. 
D EAR 
R E A B E # 
_ 
Jogging, trotting, walk­ ing and such exercises are good for men and women of all ages if they are in good health. 
I can ’t im agine why anyone would tell you jogging would be good for men but not good for women. 
The truth is that be­ cause women are less in­ clined to have heart and vascular diseases than men they have less dangers of getting into trouble jogging than men do. 
Sensible 
Women are also less inclined to be competitive to the degree men are. 
That means they are more sensible about how they exercise. 
You won’t find the ma­ jority of women racing the clock to better their time every time they run. 
I think women are more inclined to jog or run for pleasure than they are for the score. 

YOUR 
HEALTH 

B y L A W R E N C E 

E. L A M B , M . D. 

The biggest danger in jogging is overdoing it before you are trained to that level and trying to improve your life time. 
It’s the distance you jog at a comfortable rate, not the speed, that really benefits your health. For more information on jog­ ging and its relation to health and dangers send 
5o cents for The Health 
Letter, number 4-2, Jog­ ging. Exertion, Sudden 
Death. 
Send a long, stamped, self -addressed envelope for m ailing. 
Address your letter to me in care of the Express, 
P.O. Box 2171, San An­ tonio. TPX. 78297.

K id n e y s 

DEAR DR. LAM B 
- 
Many members of my fa­ mily have congenital po­ lycystic kidneys. I cannot find any information on this disease. Can you help me? 
D E A R R E A D E R 
- 
This is a fairly rare dis­ ease. The figures vary 

 but for about every 5oo autopsies one case of cystic kidneys is found. 
Because of an inherited or developmental abnor­ mality the kidney has a number of small rounded cysts in it. These are usually associated with enlarged kidneys. 
Sometimes these can be felt on physical exa­ m ination, in other in­ stances they are first noted by an X-ray of the abdomen. 
When relatives are all carefully studied usually about half the relatives of a patient with polycystic kidney also have the dis­ ease. 
How much trouble it causes really depends on how much damage there is to the kidneys. 
If there are a few small cysts and the condition is first observed in adult life the outlook may be fairly optimistic. 
However, the more cysts there are and the larger they are the more likely the kidney function will be impaired early in life. 
These patients may have sudden painless bleeding in the urine or they may have high blood pressure and other evi­ dence of impaired kidney function. 
The treatment really is medical in attempting to control high blood pres­ sure and provide general good health particularly protecting against infec­ tions. 
Interestingly enough 

 restricting the salt in the diet isn’t p articu larly helpful in people with this problem. 
Some individuals with polycystic kidney disease also have cysts of other organs in the body. 
But if general good health is present and the kidneys become suf- ficently diseased that they are not providing adequate function then such techniques as an artificial kidney or even kidney transplants can be considered.

Cambridge 

Cam bridge Elemen- tary School PTO w ill sponsor a workshop from

Parent-ChiId Communi­ cation.” 
Charlene Ortiz, train­ ing coordinator of Drug 
Abuse Central, will con­ duct the workshop. She will discuss the use and abuse of illegal drugs, as well as prescription and over the counter drugs. 
The workshop will be an introduction to how drug abuse prevention relates to everyday liv­ ing.
