Saturday March 12 1977 
AMG: 75 years as automaker 

Ac 
A u t o T a l k 

THE N EW C h e v ro le t Series 6 LU V truck fo r 1977 w ill ap- peal to those w ho se ek both utility and fun in a truck 
LUV is truck for w ork, fun 

SOCIAL TO THE EXPRESS NEW S 
DETROIT — E n g in eerin g im prove­ ments and increased availability of op­ tions highlight the new Series 6 LUV truck for 1977, Chevrolet has announced. 
The versatile m ini-pickup offers in­ creased payload capacity while m aintain­ ing the sam e excellent fuel economy as the ‘76 model. 
“ The LUV com bines the utility of a work truck w ith the sp o ttin ess of a personal usage vehicle, and it’s economi­ cal, too,” .James T. Riley, Chevrolet truck sales m anager, said. “ The Series 6 model has features which will appeal to those who seek both utility and fun in a truck. 
“ LUV sales im proved substantially during the fourth quarter of 1976, up about 
44 per cent com pared to the sam e period jn 1975, a record sales year for LUV. We feel we can sustain that momentum in 
1977." 
Advances 
Among the engineering advances for the new LUV is a variable ratio steering gear which reduces steering effort. Rear shock absorbers have been modified to improve ride and handling. 
A high altitude emission package will be available brr the Series 6 LUV with manual transm ission. 
The LUV is powered by a 11o.8 cubic- inch four-cylinder engine which provides 
8o net horsepower at 4,8oo rpm. 
M easuring 173.8 inches overall on a 
1o2.4 inch w heelbase, the LUV has a 
73-inch long pickup box with space for nearly 38 cubic feet of cargo. The UVU rating is 3,95o pounds and the LUV’s gross 

 payload capacity has been increased to 
1,51o pounds. 
W ith s ta n d a rd fo u r-sp eed m an u al transm ission, the Series 6 LUV attaint'd 
33 miles per gallon highway and 23 mpg city. With autom atic transm ission, which was introduced as an option in 1976, LUV scored 29 mpg on the highway and 21 mpg in the city. 
In California, where it will again be equipped with a catalytic converter, LUV with m anual transm ission got 32 mpg highway and 21 mpg city. It achieved 28 mpg highway and 19 mpg city with an autom atic transm ission. 
Colors offered% 
For appearance, five exterior colors will he offered including red, yellow, blue, white and midnight black. Also available will he a sporty decor treatm ent featuring colorful decals on the sides, hood and tailgate. 
Hi-back bucket seats in red plaid cloth will he available in 1977 with the popular 
Mikado luxury interior option. 
Optional “ western style" below-eye-le- vel rear-view m irrors and sliding rear window arc also new. 
Carryover options include Mikado lux­ ury interior with bench seat, air condi­ tioning, AM and AM/FM radio, E78-14B belted bias white-wall tires, rear chrom e bumper, rear step bum per, front bum per guards and a decor package with mold­ ings and full wheel covers. 
M anufacturer s suggested retail price for the Series 6 LUV rem ains unchanged from the Series 5 model at $3,284.35. 

B y •Vim A b b o tt tai* editor 

Catalytic converter does jo b — more 

People keep asking if they can take the catalytic converter off their car. 
And I answer the question with a ques­ tion — why do you want to take it off? 

The num ber one answer is so they can use reg u lar gas. In second p la c e 'they want more performanc e. 
Regular gasoline now costs about three cents a gallon less than unleaded, so tho desire to pay less is understandable. But if you should rem ove the catalytic con­ verter from your car, you would wind up paying a bundle to replace the exhaust pipe and retune the engine. 
Believe it or not. you would wind up loosing money over the life of your car, unless you drive a lot more than average folks. 
As a secondary benefit of the catalytic converter, cars so equipped arc required to burn the unleaded gas and the result has been longer plug life. Unleaded gas has stretched the tim e between tune-ups, 
• along w ith o th e r im p o rv e m en ts. and means dollars saver. 

Go faster 

As far as better perform ance is con­ cerned, it may he possible to removed the catalytic converter, retune the engine and thereby get the car to go faster. 
The San Antonio Police Departm ent has rem oved the cataly tic co n v erter from some of its freeway patrol cars and the officers feel they do get faster p erfor­ mance; but then they don’t have to worry about gas mileage. 
The m ajor concern about removing the unit is the return to pollution. Removing the device from a few cars is not going to m ake much difference. But if rem oval becam e common practice, we would be 

SPECIAL TO THE EXPRESS NEWS 
DETROIT — American Motors Corp. is observing its 75th anniversary this month 
— the date the first Ram bler automobile was sold at the 19o2 Chicago Auto Show. 
The first one-cylinder Ram bler, which had a retail price of $75o, was built in 
Kenosha, Wis., by the Thomas P. Jeffery 
Co., which in 1916 became Nash Motors, in 1937 N ash-K clvinator, and in 1954. 
American Motors. 

The m erger of Nash-Kelvinator Corp. and Hudson Motor Car Co. on May I, 1954, tinder the name American Motors, com­ bined the rich heritage of two pioneer automotive companies. This heritage was broadened with the acquisition of Jeep 
Corp. in February 197o. 

Nameplates 

Such honored nam eplates as Jeffery. 
Hudson, Nash, Overland, Essex, Terra- plane and R am bler are enshrined in autom otive history. Each contributed im portantly to the developm ent and grow th of p erso n a l m o b ility w hich changed the face of America. 
American Motors today carries forward a tradition of innovation and product excellence rooted in decades of engineer­ ing and design leadership. 

The first domestic subcompact car — the Gremlin — was introduced in 197o. In 
1975, the company introduced a totally new concept in small car design — the 
Pacer — which provides interior room and convenience exceeding many m id­ size cars. 
There are currently m ore than four million AMU cars md Jeep vehicles on the road. 

The com pany’s products cover a broad range of transportation needs, including buses, trucks and postal service delivery vehicles, in addition to its lines of Grem ­ lins, H ornets, P ace rs, M atadors and four-wheel-drive Jeep vehicles. 

2,5oo delaers 

AMU cars and Jeep vehicles are re­ tailed through a national organization of 
2,5<K) dealers. 
American Motors products are m anu­ factured at 22 plant locations in the United 
States and Canada, com prising 22 million square feet. Employment totals 29,ooo at its various plant locations and at the com pany’s headquarters in Southfield. 
Mich. International operations include 25 m anufacturing, assembly plants and li­ censees in countries outside North Amer­ ica 
With its growth and diversification into other product fields in recent years, the company derives about 5o per cent of its 
$2.3 billion annual sales from operations other than passenger cars.

Chevrolet’s H ouston zone sales post gain 

SPECIAL TO THE EXPRESS NEWS 

HOUSTON — Chevrolet dealers in the 
Houston zone posted strong monthly sales gains during February with deliveries of 
8,795 new passenger cars and trucks, 
Harry Bradshaw, zone m anager, report­ ed. 
The February total of 8,795 cars and trucks topped the figure of 8,331 deliveries in February 1976. The total included an 

C l A U i m h DISPLAY 

 especially strong showing In trucks with 
4.969 deliveries, compared with 3,585 in 
February 1976. 
“The sales gain in February gives us a atrong impetus for the upcoming spring selling season,” Bradshaw said. 
The Houston zone includes 163 dealers in south Texas in an area hounded by the 
Gulf of Mexico, the Mexican border. Del

CHEVROLET 

San Antonio EXPRESS-NEWS— Saturday March 12 1977 

G ille s p ie c ite d b y F o rd a w a r d 

Gillespie Ford has been honored by the Ford Parts and Service Division for outstanding customer service. 

And as a resu lt, Robert B ridge. 
Gillespie’s service manager, has won a four-day trip for two to San Juan, 
Puerto Rico. 

The trip is in recognition of Bridge's contribution to improving his dealer­ ship’s owner relations performance. 

“ This contest, for dealership parts and service personnel, is part of Ford’s new MVP (M ost V aluable P layer) owner relations program,’’ said WX. 
Crew, the division's Houston district m anager. “ G illespie Ford and Mr. 
Bridge can be justly proud of receiving this recognition for their service de­ partment employes. 

G illespie Ford is one of a limited number of Ford and Lincoln-Mercury dealerships across the nation to be honored for improving customer satis­ faction. 

 jlgMHR 
ROBERT BRIDGE 
. . . service pays off 

AUTO TALK 

Continued from Page I right back where we were in the 6os. 
What the anti-pollution system on your car does is remove about 8o per cent of the carbon monoxide and hydrocarbons from the exhaust gases. The catalyst does not do it all. but it does the m ajor part of the job- 
. 
. 
. 
From the very beginning people were concerned about these strange new de­ vices. At first nobody wanted to buy a car with a catalytic converter because they were concerned about the availibilily of unleaded gas. 
There were scattered instances of peo- 
'ple having to funnel in leaded gas because they had run out of gas in an area where unleaded was not available. Unleaded gas is available almost everywhere now. 
Smelled 
The early catalytic converter sm elled1 like rotten eggs. Yes. some of them did. I had personal experience with one in my garage. The odor was really bad. Now we know that such odors were caused by im proper settings of the carburetor. 
Catalytic converter caused grass fires. 
Well that did happen. 
The device operates at very high tem ­ peratures. and if you drove your car into an area of high dry grass and parked it, there was a possibility of starting a fire. 
The Society of Automotive Engineers 

 looked into the grass fire situation. Their report concluded that an overheated ex­ haust system , with or without a converter, could cause a grass fire under the proper conditions. 
The catalytic converter does what it is supposed to do, and as an added bonus, it has helped Increase the overall mileage of cars that use it. 
So I really don't see why anyone would want to remove the device from their car, unless they w anted to go as fast as possible. 
The police may have a point. I would hate to see a m urderer, or a bank robber, or any crim inal escape the law because he could outrun the police cars. 
★ Ar ★ 
On the heels of the announcement that the O ldsm obile D ivision of G eneral 
Motors will offer a V-8 diesel in the 1978 line-up, cam e word from Pontiac Division it too will soon have a diesel. 
Alex C. Muir, president of Pontiac, said experimental work on converting the 
/ ‘Iron Duke,’’ Pontiac’s new 2.5 litre cast iron four-cylinder engine, to diesel is go­ ing nicely, thank you. lf everything works amt — and there seems little reason to doubt that it will — the little Pontiac engine could be on the m arket as early as 198o Jn fact, if Abe law allows and the public reaction to diesels is good, they could be on the m arket sooner 

AUTOMOTIVI DISPLAY 
AUTOMOTIVI DISPLAY 
AUTOMOTIVI DISPLAY 

 than that. 
It s really am azing how fast General 
Motors started moving once Volkswagen announced it would import 1o,ooo diesel 
Rabbits into the U.S. this year. It’s also am azing how fast Volkswagen brought the diesel on the m arket. 
★ 4r ★ 
Form er T ransportation Secretary Wil­ liam Coleman should have been retained by the Carter adm inistration. 
He made some of the most controversial decisions in recent vears. But he made the decisions, he did not bow to the enormous pressures from lobbyists. 
Ralph Nader and others have heaped abuse on Coleman for not requiring air bags in autom obiles. Colem an finally made a compromise decision that called for a program that would have General 
Motors and Ford sell air bags below cost. 
Coleman’s refusal to make the air bags mandatory may have been the result of an 
“ inside’’ report that auto insurance in­ dustry data on air bags was misleading. 
The report cites the case of the Illinois man who walked away from a head on collision at an estim ated combined speed of 6o-7o m iles an hour. 
John P eterson, D etroit News w riter, said the official National Highway Traffic 
Safety Administration records showed the combined speed of the two cars was 23 m .p .h ., 

~AUToMo1lVi DISPLAY 

C a r s h in e is l i k e m i r r o r 

SOCIAL TO THE EXmSS NEWS 

DEARBORN, Mich. - In the race to determ ine the fairest, the new Lincoln 
Versailles will give any m irror a run for its money. 

A new light m easuring instrum ent — the Distinctness of Image (DI) m eter 
— was developed by Ford Motor Co. to ensure the “ Clearcoat” finish on each 
V ersailles m eets strin g en t quality control standards. 

The DI m eter reads a m irror as KIO and a Versailles in the high 9os. 

The new “ Clearcoat’’ finish — stan­ dard on Versailles — consists of a highly pigmented base coat sealed by two applications of clear acrylic. 

The final clear coat gives the car a glossy, highly reflective appearance and increases the resistance of the color coat to chemical fallout and stone pecking. 

The Lincoln Versailles will debut in 
Lincoln-Mercury showrooms April 15.

By SA R A M A R T IN E Z 
T he poet who said, “ I am the m aster of my fate, I am the captain of my soul.” was wrong, an intelligence officer aboard the USS Pueblo when it was seized by the North Koreans said 
F rid a y night. 
“ T h i s is t e r r i b l e t h e o lo g y . " said 
Ut. 
Cm dr. Stephen K 
H a r­ ris' . guest speaker at the Christian Business 
M en s C om m ittee D in ­ ner meeting 
“ E v e r y o n e on the 

 ship realized we were not in charge when the five Korean ships sur­ rou nd ed u s , " H a r r is said. 
“ We all realized the course of our lives was going to change drasti­ cally. I also realized I w ou ld need s tr e n g th that this w orld alone cou ld not p r o v i d e . " 
Harris said. 
B ib le 

“ This strength was to be found in one of my personal possessions — 

 m y B ib le,” H a rris said. 
“ W hen the N o rth K o r­ eans confiscated it and tossed it aside, they did not re a liz e that b la c k book w as f a r m o re powerful than any wea­ pon I could conceal ." 
A fte r th e ir c a p tu re , the m e n a b o a rd the 
P u e blo w e re ta k e n to the N o rth K o re a n c a ­ pitol 
“ W e w e re conscious of a godlessness there," 
H arris satd 
“ I t ’s hard to d e s c r ib e the e e rie feeling that perm eates 

 the atm osphere.” 
“ K o r e a w a s once a center for great C h ris ­ tia n a c t i v i t y b e fo re 
C o m m un ism ,” 
H arris said 
“ But none has survived.” 

No ch u rc h e s 

H a r r i s said his c a p ­ tors told him there was r e lig io u s fre e d o m in 
N o rth 
K o r e a , 
" b u t w hen they took us on tours, 
I never saw a church." 
Im m ediately after the 

 prisoners arrived at the 
N o rth K o re a n c a p ito l, they w ere sentenced to die. 

“ I waited for an em o­ tion of f e a r . ” H a r r i s said “ But fear was re ­ placed by joy at the ab­ solute knowledge thai I w ou ld soon be w ith 
H i m . ” 

“ We have an eternity w aiting for us and if we go to God His way, we are assured of everlast­ ing life ,” H a rris said

By CEC IL CLIFT 
T h e old f a m i l y h o ­ mestead of an elderly couple plagued in r e ­ cent months by sandals and b u rg la rs was e x ­ tensively d am aged by fire of unknown origin 
Friday night. 
T h e I s to ry r e s i ­ d e n c e , o c c u p ie d by 
L um ^lounger, 95. and his wife, Aline. KH, is at 
13(1.1 W averly St 
F ir e m e n suspect a r ­ son in the $14.IHM) blaze. which was reported at 
7:22 p.m. and was under c o n tro l 
23 m in u t e s later, according to Act­ ing Hist 
Chief Henry 
Vidal 
The couple was not at home at the tim e of the fire 
M rs . 
M o u u g e r said the c o u p le has been troubled by vandals and b u r g l a r s in re c e n t months. She said they have carted off valuable fam ily heirloom* 
A n tiq u e s

She said she believes the fire was started to cover up a b urglary at­ tempt 
M r s . M o u n g e r said she and h e r h u s b a n d a re now l iv in g in a house they own nearby.

Ft. Sam Houston M ilita ry Police are look­ ing for a man who may have witnessed a traffic fatality on the m ilita ry post Tuesday afternoon 
A m ilita ry spokesman said the young p ri­ vate. Debra Frost, IK, apparently lost control of her m otorcycle and struck a telephone jade. 
The accident re p orte d ly o ccurred about 
3 3o p m Tuesday on Stanley Road just west of North New Braunfels Avenue

He re ­ portedly slopped at the scene of the accident to give aid ad left when his help was not needed. the spokesman said

Luxury homes open in San Pedro Hills 

The best affordable luxury living is in San Pedro Hills, an estab­ lished community of fine homes in north central San Antonio. The beautiful, rolling hills of San 
Pedro Hills are blossoming with luxurious new homes by 12 of 
San Antonio’s finest custom builders. These distinctive new homes will be open for a Spring­ 

 time Showing this weekend. Cus­ tom homes in San Pedro Hills are especially designed for hillside and tree-covered sites which overlook the city and country­ side. Soaring ceilings, large fire­ places, expansive indoor-outdoor living areas and easy-care kit­ chens compliment the gently 

 bending oaks which surround most homes. Quality in design and construction is a trademark of San Pedro Hills builders. To this exclusive group of builders, each home is a statement of craftsmanship and pride. The workmanship is excellent, and the tradition of quality construction is 

 felt in every home. Visit San 
Pedro Hills this weekend and, in addition to the fine quality homes, you will discover a pri­ vate swim and tennis club. Mem­ bership is included with the pur­ chase of a new home and allows the homebuyer use of the pool and two new tennis courts. The 

 club is just another part of the total community in San Pedro 
Hills. A shopping center is avai­ lable at the entrance to San Pe­ dro Hills, and a park is centrally located in the community. North 
East District schools serve the area, including Churchill High 
School. Visit San Pedro Hills this 

 weekend. New homes are priced from . $5o,ooo and will be open this weekend. To reach San Pedro 
Hills, take San Pedro Avenue north from N.W. Loop 41o four miles to Brook Hollow, turn right and go to Heimer Road, turn left and follow the signs to Shadow 
Cliff and new homes.

Everywhere you look, there is careful attention to design, styling, practi­ cality and energy-effi- ciency.

America homes are strik­ ingly individualistic. Each hom e is designed for its particular homesite. Some are traditional, others reflect the informality of 
California styling. Some have soaring rooflines,

Twin Creek 
Professional planning by Homecraft Corp. has made Tw in Creek one of the fastest growing com­ munities in the San An­ tonio area. 
The northwestern Bex­ ar County developm ent offers the kind of homes m odern fam ilies are looking for today and can afford. 
Twin Creek, now con­ sidered one of the estab­ lished neighborhoods for 
San Antonians, has a c ­ quired a large populus since It opened. 
S treets in the n e ig h ­ borhood necessitate slow traffic, and house exter­ iors along each create an 
Im pressive blending of both colors and styles. It was all planned that way. 
The co m m u n ity also features its own private clubhouse. 
It offers green-surfaced, fenced tennis courts lighted et 

 nights, a swimming pool, wading pool, clubhouse with equipped kitchen and a c h ild r e n ’s p la y ­ ground. 
Although surrounded by nature, Twin Creek also has a location of ut­ most convenience. Here deer are seen running or feeding and city noises never are h e a rd , even though the thoroughfare 
Bandera Road is just a m ile away; NAV. Loop 
41o, one mile more. 
Of course, no city taxes apply to home payments made by Twin Creek res­ idents because the com­ munity is outside any ci­ ty limits. 
Located in the p r e ­ ferred Northside School 
District, Twin Creek is also close to UTSA,

Center,

Kelly and

Ownership yields tax deductions 

By FRANK 
MANUPELLI 
PRESIDENT, GREATER S A. 
SURGERS ASSOCIATION 
The home you ow n is a shelter not only from the elements but from many of the federal and state taxes paid bv non-home owners every year. 
As a homeowner, you can deduct mortgage in­ terest payments and real estate taxes from both state and federal tax re­ turns, The re su lt, for you r bank b a la n ce , argues strongly for home ownership as soon as you and your family can meet the down p aym ent r e ­ quirements, 
Situation 
Here’s a typical situa­ tion: 
The monthly mortgage p aym ent on a $36,oo1) home is $262 (based on IO per cent for 25 years with a 2o per cent down pay­ ment). Real estate taxes, insurance and m ainten­ ance might bring the to­ tal to $36o. In the first year of ow nership, the incom e tax sav in g s on interest and real estate taxes and the equity gained in the home could amount to $85 per month 
— dro p p in g the net monthly cost to $275. 
Tried renting a $36,ooo home for $275 lately? 
Meanwhile, of course, 
.your home is gaining in 
______ CLASMfMD — HAT 
~~ 

F R A N K M A N U P E L L I 

 value every day. T h at makes the monthly sav­ ings even greater. 
Should you sell your hom e, any p ro fit you might make is not taxed if you reinvest it in a n ­ other home within a year. 
For example, the home you purchased IO years ago for $2o,ooo might be worth $28,ooo today. Its sale would net you $8.(MMI profit. But. lf you buy another home within a year and reinvest the en­ tire $28,ooo or more, the profit on the old r e s i­ dence will not be taxed. 
Persons 65 or older can exclude from income any profit up to 
$2o,ooo gained from the sale of a p erso n al re sid e n c e in which they have lived for at least fixe of the last eight years prior lo the sale.

3 things looked for await Wildwood buyers 

There’s a saying in the home building profession that there are three things the homebuyer is looking for: location, location and location. 
While thai may be an obvious exag­ geration, it is true that location is a key factor in the homebuying decision be­ cause so many elements of a family’s lifestyle are dictated by location. 
Fulfill all hopes 
Ray Ellison homes, located in the northwestern quadrant of the city and of Bexar County, offer every choice location feature the homebuyer could hope for: excellent schools of the 

Northside School District; easy access to major arteries and expressways; proximity to key employment centers like UTSA, USAA and South Texas 
Medical Center; convenient access to prime shopping malls; and location beyond the reach of city taxes, thus lowering monthly house payments. 
This weekend, 
Ray 
Ellison representatives at the Wildwood sales office, just off Bandera Road, are of­ fering an incredible value in new home availability: a four-bedroom, two-bath home with built-in electric kitchen, central heating and air conditioning and energy package for less than 
$27,ooo. 

This is a unique opportunity for the young family seeking to break the apartment habit and move into a home of their own in the popular northwes­ tern quadrant of .San Antonio but out­ side city limits. 

Besides the advantages of quality construction through and through, along with the desirable northwestern location, the young homeowner will find income tax filing time a much more enjoyable task because of the tax advantages inherent with home ow nership. 

For those who would like to investigate the possibilitie of this Ray 

W ildwood really measures up to homebuyers’ expectations, with its “ back to the country” en­ vironment and its sophisticated, contemporary 

 designs. W ildwood's wilderness look doesn t hide its easy proximity to shopping centers and major expressways.

San Antonio EXPRESS-N EW S— Saturday March 12 1977 

Homes priced, sized for you 

A house price and sized just right for you and your family is bound to be waiting for you this 
‘weekend in one of the leading 
Morton/Southwest com m un­ ities. 
The building-developing firm s two most recent series of affordable hous­ ing arc drawn from ingenious floor plans which have revolutionized the market for new homes here by making them much more affordable and use­ ful, square foot by square foot. 
Freedom, Success 
Freedom Homes and Success Homes are modeled in Lakeside, located in southeastern Bexar County off U.S. 
Hwy. 87 outside S.E. Loop 41o; Valley 
Forge, off O’Connor Road between 
Nacogdoches Road and N.E. IH 35; and 
Cimarron, just south of N.E. FM 16o4 east of Kitty Hawk Drive. cU tillW IiHIU i 

The two series are aptly named, too. 
Freedom Homes are called that be­ cause they, literally, set buyers “ free from rent” and put them into a new world of home ownership. Success 
Homes are named after the series’ un­ ique features that would make the purchase of any a certain success. 

“ Affordability” is a key word for each series. Freedom Homes are priced from as low as $28,5oo; Success, 
$34,ooo. No comparable homes are built for those kind of prices these days; so, Morton/Southwest has a valid claim to leadership in San Antonio are housing. 
Freedom Homes go far beyond the basics, despite their low price range. 
They feature all the frill modern fa­ milies have come to expect in a new home. This, indeed, is just one of the many reasons the series has become so popular. 
Freedom Homes’ three- and four- c Las u n to DUMAY' 
CLASSIFIC) D IS M A Y 

 bedroom plans include two complete baths generally sought by buyers to­ day. All this is offered as an attractively affordable package fa­ milies can afford today. 
Pantry kitchens feature the right kind of appliances to lessen the work­ load for today’s homemaker. Dish­ washers. disposers, ranges, vent hoods and abundant cabinetry are provided in Freedom Homes. All appliances wear the reliable Magic Chef brand name. 

Other extras Morton / Southwest has made available in Freedom Homes are wall-to-wall closets with storage space extending all the way to the ceiling and sliding doors of panel designs, finished two-car garages, utility and work ar­ eas, patios with sliding glass doors, clever blends of masonry’ and wood for striking exteriors, carpeting of buyers’ choices of colors and styles. Friedrich central air and heat systems and, in 

------------------- CLA V Sm ib 
~ciAssmco w IWa y " 

 most, woodburning fireplaces. 
Success Homes vividly reveal that an enjoyable home remains the “ great 
American dream’’ and one that can be % realized without great sacrifices. 

The large amounts of total square footage in the Success plans can be seen in spacious family rooms, separ­ ate dining areas, large family rooms and sizeable living rooms. In fact, the patios for Success Homes are family sized. 
Also included are large, decorative kitchens which boast space-saving built-ins like Magic Chef ranges, ovens, vent hoods dishwashers and stainless steel Waste King disposers. 
The scope of Success Homes, how­ ever, goes far beyond their useful space. The luxury appointments add much to how they present more than the money's worth. 
They include shag carpeting in liv­ ing rooms, master suites and hallw ays; 

DISMAY 

M O R T O N /SOUTHW EST presents affordable housing 

 privacy fences; woodburning fire­ places in family rooms; abundant ca­ binetry in pantry kitchens; compart­ mented ceramic baths; walk-in or wall-to-wall closets; handsome paneling; carefully chosen wall fa­ brics; and beamed cathedral ceilings. 
Buyers can choose the colors and pat­ terns for carpets and wallcoverings. 
Each home in this ingeniously planned series also features a utility area, finished two-car garage and at­ tic-installed central heat and air.______ 

Lakeside is a neighborhood unique in its recreational offerings. They include a lake for boating and fishing, tennis courts, swimming pool and park area. 
School district is East Central. 
Valley Forge, also with a swimming pool and tennis courts, is in the North 
East School District. 
Cimarron, with access to a number of amenities like a swim club. Scout hut and playground, is in the Judson 
School District.

San A n to n io EXPRESS-NEWS— S aturday M arch 12 1 9 7 7 
MIS gains over year 

Ri'ul estate continues to be bought anti sold in brisk activity throughout the San Antonio area. 
In figures released by the M ultiple Listing Ser­ vice operated by the San 
Antonio Board of R eal­ tors. the lum ber of lis t­ ings av ailable for sale in 
February totaled 4.199. 
. 
Most homes 

Most of these were hom es, and many of t hem o lder homes, ac­ cording to Ray Ragsdill, p re sid e nt of SABUR. 
From these listings. 571 sales were made for a total of $19,915.47. 
New listings obtained 

 during February totaled 
1.445. 
The MLS provides an a rra n g e m e n t w hereby each broker brings his listings to the attention of other members. When a sale results, the commis­ sion is divided between the broker bringing the list ing and t he b ro ke r making the sale. . 
The MLS works to the advantage of both seller and buyer by placing in­ form ation about a piece of property in the hands of a ll m em ber brokers who in turn pass it on to their clients. 
There are 238 residen­ tial brokers in MLS, said 

Long-term leases becoming rarer, 
SAAA head says 

CIA M in t o W IS 1A T 

RAY RAGSDILL 

Ragsdill, and 1.494 resi­ dential salesmen. 
The d o lla r volum e of consumm ated sales for 
February was up 24 per cent over the same per­ iod in 1976. The number of new listings filed was up 7 per cent over Fe­ bruary, 1979.

BURNS C O . home boasts innovative built-in units like this recessed bed alcove com plete w ith foam m attress, toy storage beneath the bed and nearby com partm ent closet, each helping first-tim e ho­ m eowners reduce the cost o f furnishing a new home. The child's bedroom pictured is featured in the furnished Rockwood model in 
The G re a t N orth w e st at 8 7 o 6 Tim berw ilde. 

By FRANK J. CORTE 
PRESIDENT, S A APARTMENT ASSOCIATIO N 
So you’ve been sitting through this cold, wet winter in your warm, snug apartment. You let the landlord foot the high heat­ ing bill. 
Enjoy it w hile you can, buddy. If your rent hasn't increased, it w ill be and d on’ t expect m ore lo n g -te rm leases. 
IO per cent 

Some apartment project rents have gone up ll) per cent iii recent months, due to big increases in u tility costs and tenant fuel abuse. 
“ And the ones who- haven’t w ill be soon,” predicts 
Frank 
J. 
Corte, president o f.the San Antonio A p a rt­ ment Association. 
“ Some apartm ents’ owners need to hike rents another lh per cent just to keep in the fiscal o perational ball game,” Corte added. 
“ Some landlords can't raise rents fast enough to keep up with utility in­ creases.” he said. 
And a long, hot summer lies ahead. 
This is one reason that short leases are more in order. Landlords can better pass on some of the added costs every few months, instead of slapping a ten­ ant with a giant hike annually and risk offending him so that he moves out. 
‘ ‘ A nybody in a m a ste r-m e te re d apartm ent (where the landlord pays utilities as part of the rent) can look for continued rent increases unless u tility rates stabilize,” he added. 
“ Where tenants pay their own heat­ ing and air conditioning, it’s amazing how energy-conservative they can be,” 
Corte said. “ But about 99 per cent of the major complexes here are on m a s­ ter m etered heating units, most of which are electric.” 
“ We have a very serious problem ," 

Corte said, “ and one tn a l average renters don’t fully seem to realize or try to understand and respect. 
“ Apartm ent owners and managers are very concerned. Raising rents is not popular. But we have little else to do It’s about our only alternative,” he said. 
“ Ifs sort of a bleak answer, but it’s a problem where the tenant and owner are caught in the same tra p ,” Corte said. “ I wish I had an answer. But if I did. I'd do nothing else but go around selling it.” 
Apartment owners have tried to en­ courage tenants to turn off lights or adjust their thermostats up or down, including contests and cash bonuses for top fuel-saving tenants. “ It hasn t worked, for renters can’t seem to see that they u ltim a te ly pay these fuel costs through rent. And the more en­ ergy they waste, the more they are going to have to pay,” he added. 
“ I had a friend who owns a 9o-unit apartment complex tell me his u ti­ lity bill ran him $15,ooo a year in 1972. 
It was more than $9o,ooo last year,” 
Corte said. 
U tility expenses have now ap­ proached the very high rate of nearly 
25 per cent of an apartment landlord’s total operating costs. 
“ You can budget in garbage and general m aintenance cost increases and control th a t,” Corte said. “ We could probably handle a IO to 2o per cent energy increase, but not when utilities go through the roof at 3oo or 
4oo per cent like ours have been over the past two or three years." 
Corte said maintenance and repair costs probably average 12 per cent and real estate taxes close to 9 per cent a year. 
He said long-term rental lease con­ tracts are things of the past. “ I know a few g iv in g longer leases than six months and some are on a month - to - month basis," he said.

Rear 

SPtCIAt TO THI GOtDEN TWINS 
NEW YORK - The traditional home mortgage and its method of repaym ent over a 2o- or 
3o-year period at fixed rate of interest is inadequate to meet today’s housing needs. 
. 
T h ese w o rd s of m o rtg a g e re fo rm w ere m ade recently by Leon T. Ken- tdall, president of M ortgage Guaranty 
Insurance Corp. (MGIC), (hi- nation’s largest private insurer of mortgages. 
‘Tailor-made’ 

Speaking at the 32nd annual Senior 
E x ec u tiv e s’ C onference of M ortgage 
B a n k e r s at N ew Y o rk U n iv e r s it y , 
Kendall said this country now needs ta ilo r-m a d e m o rtg a g e s d e s ig n e d to meet the varying requirem ents of in­ dividual families. 
He noted that, in almost every area of business and finance, diversity is the order of the day, with the exception of the standard m ortgage, a heritage of the great depression. 
Kendall outlined several innovations that would update the m ortgage as a 
“ debt Instrum ent.” These included: 
GRADUATED PAYMENTS - They would v ary a c c o rd in g to the h o m e buyers* incomes. P aym ents could start low and increase as the hom eow ners’ incom es in crease . Such a m o rtg a g e might mean paym ents on interest only for the first five years. 
INTEREST ONLY LOANS - For a specif ied period, only interest would be paid; then the principal would be re ­ paid in a "b allo o n ” paym ent, or the loan could be renegotiated. 
RATE- and TKRM R E N E G O T IA ­ 
TION — E very five years, this could benefit the transient home buyer or the person who p la n s to ch a n g e ho m es within that period. 
PERMIT SKIPPED PAYMENTS - 
A seasonal worker, for example, could m ake m ortgage paym ents according to his own income flow. 
OI I EK LINE OE CREDIT - This would enable the home buyer to bor­ row against his increasing equity in his home to meet m ajor family expenses. 

C IA M W M O D tft*L A Y t l i l f i m b D U K A T 

 such as college education or hom e im ­ provements at economical rates. 
SHAKING VALUE - I n c r e a s e d value of the home with the builder or lender could be shared in return for a lower down paym ent and a lower rate of interest. 
SEPARATION - D istin g u ish the land from its im provem ent and am o r­ tize them on two different bases. 
K endall said p re s s u re from borne b u y e rs and c o n s u m e r s for a m o re flexible m ortgage instrum ent, as well as increasing interest in the subject by the fed era l g o v e rn m e n t, le g is la to rs and the news m edia, are forces that lenders and m ortgage bankers can no longer Ignore. lie pointed to a M ortgage Instrum ent 
Research Study by the F ederal Home 
Loan Bunk Board (FHLBB) and bills, recen tly in tro d u ced in C o n g ress by 
Sen. E d m u n d Brooke and R ep. Lud 
Ashley, as exam ple of governm ent in­ terest for change. 
Ile added that the m oney crisis of 
1974. along with double-digit interest rates, inflation in hom e p ric e s, the cyclicality of housing and the economy and other forces, exposed the s h o rt­ com ings of the present-day m ortgage structure. 
“ Usury ceilings, EHA ceilings, cost­ ly EHA origination procedures, c u m ­ bersom e foreclosure p ro ced u res and restricted powers of thrift Institutions were but a few of the weaknesses laid b are ," Kendall said. 
Kendall said the dem and for housing by first-time hom ebuyers between 25 and 34 years of age will continue for the balance of this decade and beyond. 
In 1975, households in this category to ta le d 13.5 m illio n . By 198o, th e num ber will bo 18.8 million. 
Ile explained the trend toward flexi­ bility of Hie m ortgage instrum ent p re­ sents both a challenge — and a threat 
— to m ortgage lenders. 
“ You face a conflict between sta n ­ dardization and diversity and between federalization of the m ortgage instru­ ment and p ressures in the consum er m ark etp lace for flexibility, tailoring the mortgage instrum ent to the needs of individual hom ebuyers.” *

Solar energy goes to work for La Quinta 

SPECIAL TO THE G O LD EN TWINS 
DALLAS — La Quinta Motor 
Inns Inc. has completed the first solar-heated lodging facility in the United States at the La 
Quinta Motor Inn at 1B25 Regal 
Row (N.E. IU 35) here. 
Operational since last Nov. 12, the solar energy system provides space heating for an addition to the inn comprising 2B guest rooms, two meet­ ing rooms, a private club and a suite of c o rp o ra te offices. The so la r unit supplies approximately 9o per cent of the hot water for the rooms and laundry in the 131-unit motor inn. It will also provide hot w a te r to the 
Denny’s Restaurant adjacent to the La 
Quinta Motor Inn. 
Privately financed 
No federal funds were used to fin­ ance the project. The solar energy system was paid for entirely by La 
Quinta Motor Inns Inc. The company decided that one of the major problems facing lodging operators — increasing utility costs — warranted an experi­ mental program. So, La Quinta rein­ vested company profits in an effort lo find a way to conserve n atural re ­ sources, reduce our dependence on foreign energy supplies and cope with escalating fuel costs. 
“ La Q uinta Motor Inns Inc. has made a com m itm ent to turn to the sun," said Sam Barshop, president. 
"We regard our first experiment with solar energy as highly significant for our company and our industry. Not only does it represent an opportunity for La Quinta to participate in the de­ veloping field of solar heating power, but it also enables us to make an im­ portant contribution toward helping solve our nation s energy problem." 
More than 3o.5oo motels and motor hotels in the 
United 
States, representing more than 
4 million rooms, are operating 24 hours a day, 
365 days a year. That means providing hot water at a moment's notice as well as a clim ate-controlled room year-round. The American Hotel and 
Motel A ssociation, reports energy costs (heat, power, light) for motels increased dram atically from 1972 to 
1975. Almost one quarter of the na­ tion’s innkeepers have indicated the supply and cost of energy will be their major concern during the next decade. 
Solar energy has the potential to miti­ gate the problem. 
“ This could be termed a research project,*’ said Marvin Rubin, vice president-project development for La 
Q uinta. “ We learned and adapted procedures while we installed the sys­ tem. Now it remains for us to evaluate operational performance. If everything goes well, we will investigate installing solar energy systems for both heating and air conditioning in our new con­ struction and will also take a look at converting older properties to solar 
Lifestyles m ade easy in Cam elot 

 energy. 
Although a few resorts and motor inns in Florida and California have utilized solar power to heat swimming pools and hot water for several years, the solar energy system employed at the La Quinta Motor Inn is the first to also provide space heating. 
The La Quinta system operates in conjunction with conventional water- to-air heat pumps located in the rooms of the addition. These heat pum ps perform both heating and air condi­ tioning functions. The heating cycle of the heat pump is the only function that is solar-assisted. In cold weather, they transfer heat from water circulating iii a closed loop to the air in the rooms. In w arm er w eather, they re v e rse the process and cool the rooms by trans­ ferring heat from them to the circu­ lating water. 
The solar collection system has 19 flat plate collector panels that are 49(1 sq. ft. in area and black-lined to absorb the sun s heat. T hese p an els are mounted on the roof of the motor inn facing south to receive maximal sun­ light in this latitude. The heat a b ­ sorbed from the sun heats a solution of water and antifreeze that is in contact with the panels. 
This solution, in turn, becomes a heat-exchange medium for warming water in a 2,5oo-gallon insulated stor­ age tank that is part of the circulating loop mentioned above. This substan­ tially improves the efficiency of the heat pumps in warming the rooms and reduces the am ount of energ y r e ­ quired. The hot water in the storage tank is also used to preheat the regular water supply for the motor inn. 
In warmer weather, the sun’s heat continues to be used to preheat the water going to the motor inn s regular water heaters. It also helps the water supply for an adjacent Denny’s Res­ taurant. 
Another interesting energy-saving feature of the overall La Quinta system is the use of the large amounts of heat taken from the rooms during warm wcalhct by the heat pumps to heat the domestic water supply for the motor inn and the restaurant. In most com­ mercial or residential heat-putnp in­ stallations. this heat is not put to any effective use 
The solar energy system, which cost approximately $35,ooo more to install than a conventional heating and air conditioning system , is expected to yield a payback period of approxima­ tely seven years depending on fuel es­ calation rates. 
The solar energy designers and me­ chanical aud electrical engineers are 
Travis-Braun and Associates Inc. of 
Dallas, Houston and San Antonio. The water-to-air heat pump recovery sys­ tem is from the F ried rich Clim ate 
M aster Series, a division of Wylain 
Inc. The solar collectors are manufac­ tured by Northrup Inc. The mechani­ cal contractor for th** solar system is 
United Airconditioning Co. in Dallas.

Despite one of the wet­ test Winters on record for 
San Antonio, c o n stru c ­ tion of new homes in Ca­ melot is hot and heavy these days to meet the growing demand for Ray 
Allison homes in tin* popular northeastern section of San Antonio — outside the reach of city taxes but close til the center of action in the growing northeast. 

Many of those looking at C am elot hom es a re apartment dwellers who believe rising rents and individual metering for utility costs provide a good reason to look into the investment advan­ tages of a new home. 

Lower bills 

The econom ic adv a n ­ lages of adopting a ( u- nielot lifestyle a ren ’t li­ mited to equity buildup

Ray 
U nison hom es c o n stru c te d since .Jan­ uary, 1976 feature com ­ p le te e n e rg y -sa v in g p a c k a g e s design ed to save up to a th ird or more on utility costs. The 
Unison energy package consists of extra wail and celling insulation which exceed VA/FHA s ta n ­ dards; double-paued win­ dows; special caulking a ro u n d w indow s and doors; power attic venti­ lators; and e n e rg y -effi­ cient air conditioning and heating systems 
W hile C am elo t e c o n ­ o m ies a re m any and varied, the fundamental 

 economv of reasonable monthly payments is still a reality for Ray Unison homeowners. In Camelot, hom es in the popular 
Classic series are availa­ ble in the mid-$2os with H per cent VA financing available.

Gardeners’ Questions— Answers 

B y T F R R Y W IL B O U R N 
COUNTY EXTENSION HORTICULTURIST 
The leaves on my magnolia tree have been turning brown down the center and on the edges and are dropping off. What is the possible cause? 

NOW IS THE TIME 
TO BUY A IJEW HOME 

'SaSSVSSRZ? 
* 
‘ ■ 
"aXSMFBSHSr 
'cLAfiumD wipca r 

By TERRY WILBOURN 
COUNTY EXTENSION HORTICULTURIST 
As mentioned in last week's column, I wish to give you a list of recommended varieties for the most commonly grown ve­ getables in this area, but first, let's discuss cold tolerance of all vegetables. 
Many of our so-called “cool season” vegetables could have been planted several weeks ago, reason being that they will withstand cool temperatures, cold soils and light frosts. Examples of these vegetables are cabbage, carrots, beets, broccoli, lettuce, onions, pars­ ley, collards, cauliflower, radishes and mustard. 
Those unable 
There are many vegetables, though, that will not withstand any light frost. 
Also, cool nights and cold soils will cause them not to germinate properly, if started from seed; or, they will stunt and stop growth in transplants. 
Once a plant stops growing because of cool temperatures or other environ­ mental conditions, it is very difficult to start the plant growing‘ again. All transplants, therefore, should not be planted out in the garden until the danger of all frosts is passed. lf they are planted, protection should be provided. A hot cap should be placed over them at night if there is a danger of frost. March 15 is generally thought of as the average last frost date. This doesn't mean that there will not be any more frost; it only means that the probability of having a frost is less. Tomatoes, eggplants, peppers, squash, cucumbers, melons and okra are vegetables that fit into this cate­ gory. 
Listed below are recommended var­ ieties of many types of vegetables commonly grown in this afea. I am sure there are vegetable varieties that can be grown here but are not on the list. Listed varieties are proven var­ ieties, though, and ones that will help make your gardening efforts more successful: 
Lima Bush Bean — Jackson Wonder, 
Henderson Bush, Fordhook 242, Ne- magreen 
Lima Pole Bean — Florida Butter, 
Sieva (Carolina), Willow Leaf. 
Pinto Bean — Pinto IIL Luna. 
Pole Bean — Blue Lake, Romano, 
Dade, Kentucky Wonder. 
Snap Bush Bean — Contender. Wade, 
Topcrop, Greencrop, Tendercrop.

These are typical symptoms of cold injury. 
I have seen quite a bit of this on magnolias. Some­ times, secondary fungi will further deteriorate 

 the leaf. Spraying with a fungicide, such as maneb or captan, will prevent this. Fertilize the tree now to help the tree grow out of this problem. 

Is there any way to keep sandspurs from coming up? 

Putting out a pre- jaiPr on Suggested pre­ em ergence herbicide em ergence herbicides now will help keep most are Balao, Dacthal or of these sticky pests from 
Betasan. popping out of the ground 

W hat is a good way to keep cutworms from cutting off my vegetable transplants? 

Either spraying dia- zinon liquid or applying diazinon granules around 

 the base of the plant will keep them away. 

Questions on various aspects of lawn, garden or plant care, as well as landscaping, can be answered in this column. Please address any correspondence to the columnist himself and not to this newspaper. 31o, San Antonio, TX 782o7.

19:3o a.m. (Ch. 9) - RE­ 
BOP * This edition in­ cludes a 17-year-old vio­ linist from Belmont, 
Mass.; a 16-year-old La­ tino who is facing a cul­ tural conflict; and two 
West Indian boys who are adjusting to life in Bos­ ton, Mass. 

11:3o (Ch. 4) - OUT- 
DOORS - “ Those Amaz­ ing Stuntmen” features a school in 
Hollywood where students are taught to fall off build­ ings, dive into rivers, tumble down staircases and other daring acti­ vities. 

11:3o (Ch. 12) - AMERI­ 
CAN BANDSTAND - The 
Emotions and 
Brian 
Ladd are Dick Clark’s special guests. 

Noon (Ch. 4) - FISHIN’ 
HOLE - Brook trout from 
Northern Ontario are sought today. 

12:3o (Ch. 4) - NCAA 
BASKETBALL SPECIAL 
- “ On To The Omni” takes a look at NCAA 
Tournaments past and present, providing an in­ troduction for 
NBC 
Sports' 11-game coverage of the 1977 NCAA Tour­ nament beginning today. 
Host Dick Enberg is joined by Indiana head basketball coach Bobby 
Knight and coach Dave 
GaVitt of Providence. 

12:3o 
(Ch. 
5) 
- CBS 
CHILDREN’S 
FILM 
FESTIVAL - (R ) “ Winter of the Witch.” Herm tone 
Gingold stars in a story about the transformation of a lonely, ill-tempered old crone into a happy eccentric who spreads joy. 

4 (Ch. 5) - CBS SPORTS 
SPECTACULAR - To­ day’s show features the 
Motorcycle 
Jum poff 
Competition from the 
Astrodome in Houston and the USAC Indy-Type 
Midget Car Champion­ ship from 
Trenton 
Speedway in New Jersey. 

4 (Ch. 12) - ABC’S WIDE 
W1DRLD OF SPORTS - 
Features include the 
Wur3d Professional Ski­ ing 
Championships, featuring champion Hen­ ri Duvillard; the fourth and- final race of the 
Wo fid Series of Auto

Race of 
Champions; and Men’s and

World

Championships.

4) - EM ER­ 
GENCY! - “ The Boat.” 
When members of E n ­ gine Co*. 51 learn that 
Charlie the mechanic is being forced to sell his speed boat, they devise a plan that will benefit the whole company.

Cover-Up.” The hotel management wants

7:3o (Ch. 5) - THE BOB 
NEWHART SHOW - Bob tells Emily and his ther­ apy group to keep it cool when it comes to anger. 
But when he and Emily fail to get satisfaction from a garage mechanic, he blows his top. 

7:3o (Ch. 12) - FISH - 
Fish is contemplating a second job as insurance against the day he must retire, and Mike is trying to fend off the amorous advances of a neighbor­ hood girl. 

7:45 (Ch. 9) - THE RISE 
AND FALL OF THE 
THIRD REICH - The do­ cumentary is based on a book by 
W illiam 
L. 
Shirer, about 
Adolf 
Hitler, spanning the years 1899 to 1945. 

8 (Ch. 4) - NBL SATUR­ 
DAY NIGHT AT THE 
MOVIES 
- 
“ Mean 
Streets” is the story of 
Johnny Boy (Robert De 
Niro), a product of the streets in New York’s little Italy. A shadow hangs over his empty life because of his erratic behavior and his pen­ chant for making huge debts and not paying them. When a loan shark pressures him for pay­ ment, a friend intercedes for him. but then the friend realizes the action could cost him his life. 

8 (Ch. 12) - ST ARSKY A 
HUTCH - “ Long Waak on a Short Dirt Road.” A country and western singer (Lynn Anderson) gets threatening phone calls, demanding money, in every city she plays. 
When her manager calls the police, the tormentor takes out his wrath by killing innocent people.

“ Spellbound” stars In­ grid Bergman and Gre­ gory Peck. A young man, suffering from amnesia and accused of murder. is helped by a female psychiatrist who loves him. 

It ’s time for another one of those bright Shir­ ley MacLaine specials. 
The latest one can be seen tonight at 9 p.m. on 
KENS-TV7. Carol Burnett and troupe get a night off. 
There will be singing and dancing and a lot of merriment in the hour- long “ The Shirely Mac­ 
Laine Special: Where Do 
We Go From H ere?” 
Joining Shirley will be the Les Ballets Trocka- dero de Monte Carlo and 
Don Ellis and His Elec­ tric Orchestra. The show will be taking a musical look at the beginning of our nation’s second hundred years, using a laser beam for visual ef­ fects at times. 
In two previous outings on television, Miss Ma- cLaine’s “ If They Could 
Sec 
Me 
Now” and 
“ Gypsy in My Soul” both won Emmys in several categories. “ Gypsy in My 
Soul was awarded an 
Emmy as Outstanding 
Special in Comedy, Var­ iety and Music. 
Look at future 
“ It’s a kind of a look at possibilities of the future of entertainment,” Shir­ ley disclosed during a press conference in Los 
Angeles several weeks ago. She said she had just seen a preview of the show the night before and liked it. “ It is good,” she felt. 
“ In an entertaining fashion,” she continu­ ed. " It ’s not a look into the future from a society point of view. Ifs from the entertainment view.” 
The entertainer said some of the ideas on the show were hers, others came from the producer. 
“ What we did. we sifted it out together,” she said. 
“ George Schlatter is the producer, and, she said, this is the first time she has worked with him “ I have wanted to work with him for ten years,” was her comment. 
Broke ground 
Miss MacLaine was one of the first big-name movie stars lo invade television. That was back in 1971 when her series, 
“ Shirley’s World,” ap­ peared on ABC. In that series, the auburn-haired 

Shirley 

 months later. Miss Ma­ cLaine made her film debut in “ The Trouble 
With Harry.” More films followed, plus three Aca­ demy Award nomina­ tions. 

 was “ You Can Get There 
From Here,” 
The actress was born in Richmond, Virginia. 
Her father was a mu­ sician, her mother taught dramatics at Maryland 
College and also per­ formed. Her brother is actor Warren Beaty.

Miss 
Ma­ cLaine had weak ankles, she started ballet lessons very young to strengthen them. Miss NacLaine be- fan 'Z.Tfn-^V: that She enjoyed the trip, ht oarly aO s in the woujj never have been

China trip 

It was in 1974 that Miss 
MacLaine headed up a delegation of women on a visit to the People’s Re­ public of China. She said fiat she enjoyed the trip, 
.’ould never have been able to go if Nixon had not opened up the way, and would like to go back 
,,r> . again. She said she came n 
. 
,, 
,a£an?a back from the trip with 
Game when Carol broke film 

Miss MacLaine said that she usually ends up not making any money when she does vision specials. When questioned about that, her reply was, “ I spend the money CBS gives me 
(on the show). That’s what I do. I end up with nothing. Which I am happy to do because I don’t think you should do television for money anyway.” 
“ I do television because I want to bring some quality to tele­ vision,” she continued. 
“ I love working for CBS. 
And I love working in television. And I don’t mind. I never ask any­ body what it is costing.” 
Of course, she said, she doesn’t make her living doing television. So she can let her money go back into the show to make it that much better. 
An author 

The entertainer said she was now working on her third book. “ If s a novel, almost done. If I had a day off. I ’d finish it." 
As yet, she has no title for the book, she said. In early 197o Miss MacLaine wrote her first book, en­ titled “ Don’t Fall Off the 
Mountain.” It has been published in ten lan­ guages and tells the story of the search for her own identity. Her second book

6:oo VOYAGE OF THE HOKULE A 
A 
National 
Geographic 
Special 
In a large double-hulled canoe, Hawaiians undertake a 3,ooo mile epic voyage from 
Hawaii to Tahiti in search of their ancient heritage. 
7:15 THE RISE AND FALL OF 
THE THIRD REICH 
A special three-part documentary based on the monumental best-seller of the same name by William Shirer. The film examines the life of Adolph Hitler from his 1899 Austrian birth as Adolph Schick- 
Igruber, his 
Chancellory of 
Germany, impassioned speeches, bookburning, ex­ tinction of Jews and eventual fall of power, 
11.o5 THE RISE AND FALL 
OF THE CIA 
Traces the origins and development of the CIA from World War ll to the 196o's and beyond, when the CIA emerged as the vastly wealthy and scarcely restrained secret arm of the U.S. Presidency, engaged in covert operations around the globe.

Energy nonsense 

I am so mad, I can hardly contain myself. 
I just watched an hour-long special on energy on 
\RC and heard the most ridiculous junk I have ever seen on the television screen, 
This is even worse than the baby at Green Hospital in the CBS “ Hunger in America” documentary. 

Some reporter (whose name I didn’t get) said that everything is fine in Texas gas-wise because Texans don’t have federal regulations on their gas and that by paying more they are getting more gas —unlike the eastern states. 

Now this is the biggest pile of baloney since ldi 
Amin said that Anglican Archbishop died in a car crash. It is nothing but oil and gas industry propaganda — if you all pay more, we’ll give you the gas. 

Worse, is that the show featured San Antonio and said there were no gas shortages this year. I have read in the Express about shortage's from Lo-Yaca. 
Now, just who is correct? ABC-TV or the Express? 
Will you please set the record straight and let me know the person who made those statements so I can write' to ABC and let them know his “ facts’’ were wrong? 
R. L. V. 

W E w e v t k L E T ^ 3 
F a c t s s t a n d i n t h ' 
W A Y O E A G O O D 
5TO«Y I 

Okay, Action-Express 

 went over to Channel 12 where they allowed us to watch a replay of that show which was titled: 
“ The Winter That Was . . 
The 
Energy 
That 

Wasn’t.” 

The reporter who did 

 the segment on Texas was Roger Peterson. The thrust of his report was that Texas natural gas prices are unregulated and that while there were shortages in 1972, the prices were raised by the state (since there are no federal price controls) and “ the shortages end­ ed.” 

He then focused on San 

Antonio in particular and said during that seg­ ment: “ Even this year, there were no gas shor­ tages here.’’ That, of course, is not true 

 whether he was speaking of San Antonio in parti­ cular or Texas in gener­ al. 

San 
Antonio has experienced 36 cu rta il­ ments in natural gas de­ liveries since the first day of winter — that is one almost every three days. And three of those curtailm ents were IOO per cent cutbacks in gas 

 for electrical generating purposes. 

Of course, everyone 

 here recalls all the trou­ ble they had in Wichita 
Falls where schools were closed, industry was shut down and other severe problems resulted from gas shortages in that ci­ ty. 

The same segment on 

San Antonio also erron­ eously identified 

( o u i in ii (lilies Organized for 
Pu b lic 
Service 

(C O PS) as Citizens O r­ ganized for Public Ser­ vice. 

We only concerned 

 ourselves with the mis­ leading or erroneous statements about San 
Antonio in the show and cannot recap all of the errors which cropped up in the hour-long special. 
We contacted ABC in 

New York and after talk­ ing to people represent­ ing the producer, the re­ sponse we got was this 
“ Well, there is nothing we can do now. The pro gram has already been aired, we will not air a retraction. Thank you for telling us. we will toss it around up here.” 
Now,. isn ’t that 

 interesting? 

More on Tex-Mex 

In response to the recent letter a tx tut Mexican- style food in Oui magazine, I read something in 
(here I find incredible It said the Caesar’s salad wus invented at Cesar's hotel in Tijuana, Mexico. 

Isn t this some local faille or something? I had never known the Ceasar's Salad to Im1 a Mexican dish and certainly do not believe it was invented in some hotel in Tijuana. Wasn’t the salad named after 
Caesar, of the Julius variety? 

DOUG M. 

No, the Caesar Salad 

 was not named after Ju ­ lius Caesar. 

The concoction of Ko 

 maine lettuce, oil, 

 cheese, raw egg, an chevies, croutons and other ingredients was in vented at a hotel smack in the middle of Revolu­ tion Avenue’s “ strip” in 
Tijuana. 

There is a plaque near 

 the front door recounting the hotel's more famous days and the event 

 marking the creation of the Cesar Salad (Caesar in 
Spanish). 

Almost every restaur­ ant in Tijuana that is not in the tourist /one serves 
Caesar’s Salad. 

As an addendum to the 

 article in Oui magazine about 
Mexican food, 

 there was considerable attention given to various kinds and varieties of chili. 

Our friend Ford Green 

 tells us the Santa Marla 
Dictionario de Mexican- ismos published in Mexi­ co City has this to say about chili: 
“ A detestable food with 

 the false name of Mexi­ can that is sold from 
Texas to New York.” 

Actually, what we 

 think they are trying to say is that chili con carne is not sold in Mexico and whoever wrote the de­ scription of it didn’t really like it much. 

Government ear 

Last Sunday an Inter-Agency Motor Pool govern­ ment station wagon wus pulling away from a store on V alley View. 
Was tins the rightful use of this vehicle? 
I. H. 

We occasionally get 

 complaints of this nature and have found that go vernment vehicles are operated by so many agencies and offices it is difficult to determine if the vehicle is being used for unauthorized pur­ poses. 

Poverty agencies, fe­ derally-funded programs for migrants etc, often have access to govern­ ment cars, trucks, buses etc. 
The last complaint we 

 got was a government station wagon loaded with 
“ hippie-looking 

 characters.” We checked thai out and found it was in the proper hands. 
However, if you see a 

 government vehicle be­ ing used for purposes other than those for which you believe it was intended, call the Gener­ al Services Administra­ tion (GSA) and report It and lf there are enough complaints about a cer­ tain vehicle they uilj in­ vestigate.

Sleeping pills are not cure 

Dear Dr. Thosteson: I gel pains in my legs about IO or 15 m inutes after I go to bed. 
They get so bad that I either have to take something or I cannot sleep. I have been taking one “ 222” tablet every night, and this helps a lot. I was wondering if there is any danger in taking these over a long period of time. Another thing, do they affect the blood pressure, which I ani also taking medicine for? I am 58. — Mrs. K.B.B. 
That tablet you are using is a low-close narcotic, ll is effective, but it isn t advisable for long term use 
And. of course, it’s not going to have any effect on the cause of your pains, whatever that may be. 
Do you have varicose veins? If so. treating them would ease your problem. Another caufle of these pains in women are high heels, which sad to say (medically) seem to be making a comeback. These do not give proper arch sup­ port. Being overweight can multiply problems, especially if you an* on your feet for long per­ iods. 
Low heels 
By George €. 
Thosteson, M.D. 
You might try walking about in low-heeled slip­ pers before retiring. A good old hot luh souk never hurts. lf by chance you .are taking tranquilizers, you should not be using sleeping pills. The combination may result in severe depression of the nervous sys­ tem. 
Dear Dr. Thosteson: I have heard where women are experiencing menopause earlier than in the pas!. 
Is it true, and, if so. why? — Mrs. IT Y. 
Menopause conies between the a g o s of 45 arui 5o for most women. It is true, though, that later men­ opause (in the early 5()s) is occurring more today than that in the past. Why? Probably for the same reasons girls are reaching puberty earlier (asubject 
I discussed recently — better nutrition and general health. I am not aware of the actual physiological reasons. For the booklet on menopause send a stamped, self-addressed envelope and 35 cents to cover costs of mailing and handling to me in care of this newspaper. It treats the subject in terms I believe you’ll understand. 
Dear Dr. Thosteson: Where can I write to find out if the American Diabetes Association has research programs which volunteers can participate In? I live in Minnesota. — Mrs. B T. 
Check your phone book for a chapter of file asso­ ciation. There is a very active one in your state. 
Otherwise write to the national headquarters at One 
West 45th Street, New York. 1oo2o 
Dear Dr. Thosteson: Is there pain involved in 
Parkinson’s disease? — B R, 
The symptoms of Parkinson's are muscle weak­ ness. rigidity, and tremor. However, cramplike pain in the limbs and the spine can develop from the chronic muscle spasms. 

H ow lo get rid o f leg cram ps and fo o l pains? The answer may be 

 simple — write to Dr. Thosteson, in care of this new spaper, for a 

 copy o f his booklet, " H o w To Stop Leg Cram ps and Foot Pains 

Enclose a long, self-addressed, stom ped envelope and 35 cents.

Your Birthday Sunday: 
Move right ahead with a wide range of learn-by- doing enterprise*. 
Preliminary results are somewhat uneven, but prospect* are good Rela­ tionships are headed toward happy and poten­ tially permanent lies. 
Today’s natives are gen­ erous, impulsive, enthu­ siastic. delight iii exper­ imental or adventurous arrangements. 
Those 
Itorn this year will bring a mudcap sense of humor to original thinking. Most w ill get far aw ay from early environment, at a youthful age.

EXCLUSIVE DEALER FOR... 

Tindall and Son Motor Homes, TWX) San Pedro, carries three of the finest motor homes available in the recreational field, according to W. F. “ Wes” 
Edens, manager. 
The homes include the Itasca, constructed by 
Winnebago; the Executive and the Explorer. 
“ All three are beautiful units and they come in various sizes and equipped in various ways, accord- ng to what the custom er might want in extras, hut 

CLASSIFIED n t S .I * Y 
CLASSIFIED PIS RIA T 

 original furnishings alone are something to behold,” 
Edens said. 
As an example, Edens points out some of the units come with microwave ovens, color television, stove, shower and self-contained holding tanks. 
“ In short, you have a complete, self-contained unit and can travel anywhere in the country as if you were in your o w n apartment at hom e,” the manager added.

Van is 
'i' in SA 

It is so in that it now has a name: Yan-mania. 
If you happen to have missed out on the latest 
West Coast fad. there’s good news in San Anton­ io. 
Je r r y .Mum a of the 
Hemphill 
- 
McCombs 
Good Times Center has issued an invitation for 
South Texans to visit the tenter right across from 
Hemphill 
- McCombs 
Ford. 1o1o San Pedro. 
Je rry can not only show the latest in Ford vans. but also in 
Chevrolet and Dodge styles, all decked out in high fashion by the Good 
Times Van people. Hem­ phill-Met airn bs is the ex­ clusive distributor for 
Good Time Vans within a 
5o-mile radius. 
So you won’t sound like you just came to town on a load of cabbage, here’s a little "van talk’’ to keep you from sounding like a hick. 
Don’t talk about the fat radial tires. Make a cool remark like. "Those are sure wide weenies." 
And. if you want, talk price, trade and delivery time. 
Good Time Vans are built by Ford. Dodge arid 
Chevrolet, but the custo­ mized finishing is done right here in Texas, so if you want something not in stock, delivery time is normally less than two weeks. 
If you want to buy a barefoot van and start out with your own con­ version or you want to install a regular Good 
Times kit a little at a time, Jerry will Im * glad to show you how easy it is to do

Founded in 1967 in San 
Antonio, Certified moved to Selm a a couple of years ago for better ac­ cessibility. 
Besides selling equip­ ment. including Kit Road and Ranger brands. Cer­ tified also installs hitches md electric brake con­ 

 trols. sells trailer insur­ ance, services all trailers it sells, offers security storage, rents luggage and trailers, installs roof mount air and all type of awnings, installs au to ­ mobile w iring co n n ec­ tors, sells 
Colem an stoves, lanterns, sleeping bags, tents, coolers and catalytic heaters, repairs 

 parts for all equipment sold, provides financing at bank rates and pro­ vides emergency referral service for all RV prob­ lems. 

Certified, 651-6o62, in­ vites South Texans to v is it and inspect its wide range of c a m p e r equipment and supplies.

Mobile 
H om es, 
2271 
A ustin 
Hwy., has expanded its line of recreational vehi­ cles during the past year land is offering travel­ conscious custom ers an outstanding line of vehi­ cles. 
With its theme, “ Bring 
A m erica to your door­ step” in mind, officials 

 at Rahmberg now feature an extensive line of travel trailers and campers in­ cluding the highly popu­ lar Venture tent camper, the Aristocrat and the 
Nomad travel trailers. 
A sp o k esm a n at 
Rahmberg points out the firm offers the finest in trailers and also the fin­ est in service with a full 

 se r v ic e d ep a rtm en t ready to meet the needs of the company’s many customers and also new ones visiting the center for the first time. 
Rahmberg is starting off the new year with some outstanding motor vehicles such as the 1977 
Titan and Champion mo­ tor h o m es that offer 

 rugged all-around steel frame construction and ureth an e foam in s u la ­ tion. 
Rahmberg is particu­ larly proud of its Titan mini-motor homes, fully self-contained, at a rea­ sonable price, making this ou tstan d in g buy available to most lovers of the open road.

Special service offered

Cobra m otor h om es.

San Antonio.

Super sales seen 

Veteran automan Bill 
Poults, general manager or North Central Ford. 
98tHI San Pedro, sees 1977 as a “ super sales year.” 
And 
North 
C en tral owner and president Don 
P. lin kman has reason to 
In' optimistic. 
With one of the finest lines of Fords ever to hit sh ow room s a c r o ss the country, North Central 
Ford has been enjoying m a jo r tra ffic and in­ c r e a se d p u rc h a se s by happy customers. 
G oing from the o u t­ sta n d in g all-new 1977 
Thunderbird to the full* size. highly desired LTD to the great intermediate 
Granada, North Central is displaying what Poulos feels are some of the fin­ est products ever in the long and prestigious his­ tory of Ford Motor Co. 
“ B u sin ess looks real good,” says the smiling 
Poulos as he notes the other eye-catching cars such as the Torino, Mus­ tang and Pinto also are 
“ moving right along” in sales. 
Poulos points out that in addition to a complete and varied line of spank­ ing new Ford products, 
North Central Ford also features one of the most extensive lines of first class uses! cars. 
“ We only carry late models and extra clean used cars that have been thoroughly tested and checked by our expert m e c h a n ic s and test drivers," Poulos says. 
North C entral F o rd , just noQth of Loop 41o on 
Sun Pedro, has am ple space for customers and a large showroom with a giant lot for its used cars

Poulos.
